response.answer_text: If you want to be rich ... - First, find your reason: WHY do you want to become rich?  Becoming rich is hard. This is self-evident; if becoming rich weren't hard, we would ALL be rich. It is the WHY of becoming rich that provides the passion. It's the passion that drives the massive action. It's the massive action that makes you rich. HINT: simply wanting to be rich won't do it. You'll give up at the first roadblock ... or the next. It's simply too hard without an all-encompassing reason that drives you on. - Secondly, you need to find your method. There are three ways to become rich ... you must choose at least one: 1. Luck: you can win a lottery; be born into wealth; or, marry wealthy. Aside from the obvious, there are two other problems with this option: a) if you don't learn the lessons of money on the way up, it will be a fast fall on the way down. 90% of lottery winners are broke within 5 years. Greater than 50% of marriages break up. Wealthy families often use the threat of money to ensure compliance to (their) family values in their children: ie golden handcuffs. b) there's no fulfilment in simply 'making money out of thin air'. 2. Risk: you can gamble your way to wealth in the casino (e.g. play poker; count cards); in the stock market (options trading); or, aggressively trading ('flipping') in the real-estate market. The problem with this strategy - which has been successfully employed by some of the wealthiest people in history (eg Jesse Livermore & George Soros in the stock market; Donald Trump in the real-estate market) - is that it's a white-knuckle roller coaster ride that ends in financial suicide for over 99% of those who go 'all in'. 3. Add Value - the BEST way to become rich is to add massive value. For example, in business, find a problem that affects a huge number of people and solve it. Turn that solution into a product or service. Turn that into a business. Scale up fast. Sell well before your Solution's natural lifecycle ends. Or, in real-estate, find underutilized property and add value by building, rehab'ing, or repurposing. - Thirdly, you need to protect your wealth. You need to learn the hard Financial lessons that will stop you from losing your money when you have it.  This includes: i) earning more than you spend - if you earn $20m don't spend even 10% of it a year. Instead, spend it in this order: pay Uncle Sam any & all taxes due (don't be tempted to skimp; it WILL, come back to bite you); take a small salary; reinvest in your business; then, if you have anything left over, invest (real-estate is an ideal accompaniment to business income because of its low-risk profile, stability, and tax-advantages). BONUS: in addition to your small salary, here is how you safely reward yourself for all your hard work - you can spend 5% each year of the accumulated total in your investment accounts. This should give you an enviable - and, completely sustainable, ever-increasing - standard of living. ii) pay down your expensive debt as quickly as possible - but, don't make the mistake of paying down ALL debt. Debt is an investment like any other; remember the saying "a dollar saved is a dollar earned"?  Well, that applies equally to debt: a % in interest saved (after tax) is EXACTLY the same as a % in interest (after tax) earned. - Finally, the most important thing to remember is that being RICH is hard work, and probably not worth the time, effort, or risk. Instead, aim to become WEALTHY: this means having enough to sustain YOUR chosen lifestyle in perpetuity, no more and no less. POSTSCRIPT: 99% of people reading this will dismiss it. They will discount the source (some random on Quora). They will harken back to some contrary advice they read somewhere (e.g. "Pay down ALL debt"; "flip houses to make millions"). They will say it reads hokey (true: this is a Quora answer written in my bathrobe). They will say: you pay for what you get ("I need to buy that $4k eCourse on wealth that Robert Kiyosaki wants to sell me"). They would be wrong.

I’ll never forget that scene. The first time when I saw my mum cried… My dad worked hard, very hard. And I hardly see him around most of the time. He will only come home once every 2 months due to his job - to put food on the table for his family. I had no idea about our family financial situation that time… until one day, I saw my mum cried… for the first time, because she can’t take the struggles inside herself anymore. And since then, I swear that I’m going to be rich! Filthy rich! To solve all the problem once and for all. To cherish my parents. To make sure my children won’t need to experience what we went through at that time. . . . I was 15 at that time… The first solution I came up in order to get rich is to work, as much as I could, to trade time with money. So I started looking for a job during my school break… Grabbing on any opportunity to earn every single penny as I able to. After 3 years of working as a waiter part-time during my school break, and finally, I graduated from my secondary education. Most of my friends are thinking to continue their studies at famous university, while I have only one aim - to make more money, fast… I got a full-time job as a waiter again in a Japanese restaurant. That’s obviously not the only plan I have, I got to know some new friends, and joined them in the Multi-level marketing business because they promised that I can make a fast passive income within 2 to 5 years. It didn’t work out as planned. But. One of the best habits I picked up from these group of friends (MLM) is to read. So, I started to read all sort of books about financial management, sales & marketing, self-help and much more. PS: I bought them from a pirated bookstore because they are cheaper, at around 80% off the original print book. And one of the most important books I ever read on the topic of becoming rich is Rich Dad Poor Dad by Robert Kiyosaki. He became one of my idols when I was 18. Although I don’t like every single thing he published now. But there is ONE single piece of information you must know if you want to get rich. The real definition of asset and liability.  . Traditional definition Assets: Everything that you own - house, car, even your sofa Liabilities: Your debts to banks and others Real definition Assets: Everything that put money into your pocket Liabilities: Everything that takes money out of your pocket . With this, you’ll have a very clear vision on how you should spend money without falling into the financial traps. Most of the thing we own, our house, our car, our sofa are actually liabilities. By mistaken them as the assets, we’re going to fall into a financial black hole without us even realising it. And I am seeing many people around me making these mistakes now. I’m glad that I learned about this at the age of 18 and firmly stand behind it regardless how others around me have an objection about this. . . . But the truth is, I was still poor… I had a low pay job, and I was far from rich yet. At the age of 19, my focus was “how to make more money, fast?”, while working for a boss is clearly not the answer for me. So, I tried everything that came to me. I become an insurance agent but no one trusts me on that... Failed. And messed up with my reputation.I involved in FOREX trading without learning the nut and bolt of how the system works… Failed. And lost five thousands bucks of savings and borrowing.I started a catering business with a few partner… Failed. And get into ten of thousands of debts, slept at McDonald for months.While I was doing all that, I still have a job. But without paying any effort on my job in the restaurant (another restaurant), I ruined the relationship with my employer and colleagues. It came to a point when I was asking myself… Really? What really makes one rich? It seems like working smart and hard don’t really pay off. Everything became a mess. I decided to stay low and only focus on what I can do to survive - get a full-time job as a waiter again, focus on my side freelance work (I learned design online while I’m doing all those ventures just because I like it). Slowly, I came to realise that there is only one thing is out of the equation. I always aim to get rich fast. What about instead of that, I aim to get rich - without the fast behind it? With the craving of instant gratification (get rich fast), I never persisted in working things out, I dabbled all the time. That's the main reason I failed, and the same reason failed so many others. And this makes so much sense when I came across this video by Anthony Robbins.  Getting rich is just like every achievement in life. It’s not about how smart you do it or how hard you do it. Yes, they count, only when there is consistency. With that said, it’s about mastery. . . . So, here is the bulleted format for you to digest everything I just said easier: Learn about personal financial management. Understand the real definition of asset and liability. Read Rich Dad Poor Dad. Start budgeting - I highly recommend YNAB (what I’m using now since 2 years ago).To make more money, pick one or two skills or things you love the most and master them. Practice it deliberately. Create a system and start by taking tiny actions. Always focus on the progress but not just the goal.Remember that being rich is just the mean goal. Often time, our end goal is not to have more money or becoming rich. What is life means to you if you have all the money but no time and health to spend them. Get clear on what really money can do for you, understand exactly how much you need to live your desired life.. . . To help you get rich a little bit faster and extra action steps you can take: Focus on providing value to others. This applies to both work and business. When you’re providing more value to your employer or customers, you will get more in return.Don't spend all the money you make (again, read Rich Dad Poor Dad and YNAB's blog). Invest in yourself and invest in assets that pay you additional income.If it’s possible, start a business. It’s not for everyone, it’s not easy, but it’s worthwhile. Simply because you can have more leverage from a business by getting out from the system of trading time with money.Leverage the internet, use it the right way. I can’t imagine how hard is it for my parents to work their way out from financial struggles without the internet. Now is the best time to start because of the internet. Ease of information and communication is a huge leverage that people don’t have 20 years ago.Work hard.. . . I'm yet to achieve all my financial goals, but I strongly believe I'm on the right path. - Dean Yeong

By just being around all of them you can actually recognise how they did it. Exactly what practices performed they use? Performed they start a tried and true business or get into something much more innovative? Performed they are doing it strictly by milling and dealing hard or by pure intellect and imagination? The more you're around wealthy folks you more you learn that you will find various ways to have here which your mileage will change.. a whole lot. find out a skill intensely. Regardless of if its becoming a jack of all positions. earning money and getting deep is a function of worth. More value, more money (usually) so you must develop a technique for creating worth. Hedge fund managers do so by predicting the markets, sales people take action by getting individuals to purchase the product and pc software designers get it done by building something. Regardless of what you want to-do you should be able to deliver value. Therefore discover location or places that you experienced that you've a comparative benefit and go after that entire heartedly. When you start to build up value you are begin to develop riches. work tirelessly. Very very hard. really the only individuals every become rich by not working hard are the people who were given it through the lottery or inheritance. You simply will not have the ability to be rich if you don't're working hard. This goes hand in hand with my point above. Lets state you can create 1 piece of worth an hour. There ARE secrets to getting rich. And they aren’t well kept secrets. They all revolve around a number of concepts that when combined are extremely effective. There is the mathematical aspect. Save. Use money to make money. Compounding investments. But there is more to it than that. It’s the concept of momentum. It’s a very simple yet effective principle that can be applied to all areas of life. If something has worked in the past. It may work in the future. If a business reports record earnings it may report record earnings again in the future. If a business reported a loss it may in the future report a greater loss. If a girl cheated on her ex, she may in the future cheat on you. It’s not 100%. It’s just more likely than 50–50. How can you use this concept to earn money? You could translate it straight to momentum investing and that would work. Sure you wouldn’t be right 100% of the time, but you could be right over 50% of the time. Similar to this principle is the concept that the hungry don’t get fed and the rich attract what they already have. What I mean by this is that people tend to ignore the homeless man who is barely scraping by yet offer opportunities to the business man in a suit and tie. Men with an entourage of women get the looks from even more women. Celebrities who have more than enough money don’t have to pay for anything. People who work two jobs easily find another. The guy without a job is less likely to find a new job the longer he doesn’t work. Another concept is belief, identity and attitude. Give 10 homeless people a million dollars and 9 of them will end up homeless again in the future. Take 10 self made millionaires and make them start from scratch. 9 out of 10 will become rich again. The next concept is adding value. An example would be the housing market. Someone could say: “The housing market is overpriced. There is no money to be made.” but that person is expecting to buy a house and resell at a profit, WITHOUT ADDING ANY VALUE. A smarter individual knows there is ALWAYS opportunity. I’ll get to that later. One could build a house and sell it for the inflated market price. People are so accustomed to the rat race that they completely miss the fact that money (building materials) truly do grow on tree’s. Assets truly are built from scratch. If you build something it has value. Period. The next concept is that there is ALWAYS opportunity. Chores always need to be done, maintenance always needs to be done. New things are always being invented. Assets are always being built. Old assets are always dying. It’s fact. Someone who says there is no opportunity has no idea what opportunity is to begin with. Next concept. Don’t listen to anyone if you’ve done your research. Think for yourself. Do you know how many people once asked me “why are you buying bitcoins?” “You can’t cash them out.” This statement was made to me by dozens of people who were certain of what they were saying. “Bitcoins can’t be cashed out because they aren’t real.” Those same people don’t believe that I’m now rich from bitcoin and other investments that were signaled to me through momentum strategies. I myself was skeptical of bitcoin but decided to throw logic out the window as an experiment in trading strategies. These people are still laughing at me, but I’ve definitely cashed out on my bitcoins lmao. They can laugh all they want. The most important concept is optimism. A positive mind will think up positive solutions and bring about more positivity. A negative mind only comes up with negative outcomes. I learned these strategies and many others from rich people and I’m now rich. I think the biggest barrier people have is themselves. Everyone thinks it’s difficult. 99% of people will not do things that they perceive as too difficult. There is incredible opportunity due to this as the majority of people are not competition in the slightest. Ironically it is their competitive, dog eat dog type thinking that causes them to run around without getting anywhere. The human species could build and work together to solve every problem. Instead we war and fight because of the illusion of scarcity. Which brings me to another concept. There is more than enough to go around. People are poor because of war, inequality, fear, greed… The earth itself is abundant. Human beings are very resourceful. We get things done, period. If there is suffering it’s because humans thought up and caused that suffering. If humans want to accomplish something they will. If YOU want to accomplish something you will. Period. The last concept. Do. Simply act. One step at a time. Mistakes are fine, setbacks are fine. But never give up no matter what. If you want something bad enough you’ll make it happen.

Pick one or all three. There are three primary ways people become “rich” (stock market, real estate, own a business). You must do your own research and determine which path(s) you might want to follow. Stock Market (7-11% return) Pros: It is easy and can be done with little capital. You can purchase parts of it every month, even automatically. A company will never come to you asking for more money (unless you short trade and deal with options). Your money will grow with everyone else’s (hopefully), or goes down with everyone else’s. The US stock market has a good record of steadily going up, 7-11% a year.Cons: You can lose all your money (especially if you purchase individual stocks). You don’t really own anything tangible. There are expenses associated with most trading. You are not an expert, large companies pay millions of dollars to people with PhDs to figure out the market and they still cannot do it. You will rarely ever beat the market in the long term; you only want to be the market. There are not many tax breaks.Real Estate (5-15% return, depends) Pros: You actually own an asset and it will generally appreciate. People will always need a place to live. With only paying a portion of the price of the house, you can immediately begin receiving rental income for the full value of the house. The government incentives home ownership; therefore, there are many tax breaks for owning a house (all rental expenses, maintenance expenses, mortgage interest).Cons: There are normal annual expenses and then other random expenses. Need to maintain a larger emergency fund to immediately fix issues. Dealing with tenants and finding new tenants. Quality of tenants usually correlates with quality of the house (more expensive house, better tenants). If you have a property manager, it will significantly reduce your return.Own a business (unlimited return) Pros: You control everything and there is a lot of active work, time consuming. Lots of tax breaks.Cons: Extremely high failure rate. You will never retire, unless you sell the business. You need a fairly high amount of capital to start, unless you want to be in a lot debt before you even start (if a bank will even loan you the money).Of course there are many more aspects to becoming “rich,” but the basics are usually the same, simple math and time. Good luck!

The answer should be pretty obvious to your right now. BUY BITCOIN! No. I’m only joking. Seriously, do NOT buy bitcoin or any other crypto unless you’ve done a significant amount of research, know what you are getting into, and are only buying as much as you can lose. Becoming rich is not easy (to do legally). It takes a lot of hard work and a lot of intention…but it is possible. For one reason or another I’ve always wanted to be “rich”. I just had this obsession even as a child of making a lot of money. I owe a debt of gratitude to my parents who were super frugal/typical first generation immigrants into the United States. They were as frugal as frugal got and so when I was younger growing up, I wasn’t able to have a lot of the toys that my friends had. You have to understand though, my father used to be a janitor when he first came to America. He made $2 and hour. So to give it some perspective, why would he spend $15 on a toy for me, when he would only earn that in one entire day of manual labour? I don’t blame him. In fact, I thank him. You see frugality is one of the core tenants of the wealthiest people in the world. That’s why you see billionaires driving around in Ford Focuses and conversely you see professional athletes declaring bankruptcy just years after they make it big. The former understood frugality and the latter did not. So how do you become rich? 1). Be obsessed with generating wealth. Think about it constantly. From the moment you wake up to the last thought you think about at night, dedicate all your energy every day to learning about how to get rich. 2). Be Frugal. This one should come easy if you master step 1 above. If all you think about is becoming rich then you certain won’t be happy seeing money leave your bank account. If you are spending more than you are earning then your progress will be backwards. Learn to control your desire for immediate gratification (buying material goods) and instead learn to be frugal. 3) Invest in yourself . Being frugal does not mean you should never spend a dime. Learn how to invest in yourself. If that means spending some of your hard earned cash to take a class on investing, leadership, or a new skill that you could market or earn more money from…then you should do it! 4) Be patient. I know, I know…this is probably the hardest one especially with all these bitcoin/crypto millionaires. I used to look at my peers making more money than me and get jealous…and even worse the ones who had inherited their wealth and thought they were so “lucky”. In truth, I was the lucky one to have not been given anything…because it just further fueled my obsession to get rich. I don’t want to get too esoteric and Tony Robbins like on you here but the secret to getting rich does inf act lie within your mindset.

Anyone can start to create wealth with any amount. With today's technology and mentoring there are much easier and faster ways to achieve wealth, but this is basically how I did it. I hope that it will give you an idea that you can build on. I started in 1981 with $167. I bought a gun at a flea market that I knew was worth more. I took it straight to a gun shop about three blocks away that paid me $210. I put the $167 back in our savings account and started buying and selling with the $43 profit. Before long, I was buying and selling guns at gun shows and making $200 to $300 a day. I was buying at one table and selling a few tables away. Sometimes I would only make $2, sometimes I could make $50, but I was making a profit in every sale. I took that profit and bought my first car for sale from the back lot of a big car dealer. Now I was making $200 to $2000 on each car I sold. Then I started buying wholesale pre-owned Rolex watches. I could make $100 to $1000, but I could carry ten watches on me, where I couldn't carry ten cars without my neighbors getting really upset. Before long I had enough to start buying wholesale diamonds. I could make $100 to $5,000 and carry $50,000 worth of diamonds in my shirt pocket. It was no time until I had enough money to start buying real estate. It took me four months from the time I bought my first investment property to get paid, but I made $29,000 after commissions. I had saved and made enough to start buying and holding properties. I leased the properties out and had income coming in each month. More than enough to cover the mortgages, so I bought, or built more properties. I eventually bought the pawn store company that I was working for, as it fit well with my Rolex and diamond buying. That new increased income gave me enough income to purchase more properties to rent out. I started buying commercial properties and putting my pawn stores in them. The pawn stores would pay rent that would more than cover the mortgages. I sold the last of my pawn store's in 2015 and still continue to collect rents from the owners of my old stores. I started a gold buying business in 2010 with $16K for fun and a little additional income. We will do around $2MM this year from one small location. I tell people that have very little to take a quarter, or a dollar or two to a garage sale and buy something that they know is undervalued, and list it online. I have several people that I suggested that to that have made an extra $20 to $600 a week reselling their weekend finds. They sell their jewelry finds to me. Take the money that you make and keep it seperate from your household funds. Reinvest that money into the next bigger venture. A college education will help, but you can take the specific classes that you need to run your business online or at a community college. There is no need to have massive debt and stress that goes with student loans. The trick is to use the funds that you make to do the next bigger deal. Keep doing bigger and bigger deals until you either find something that you excel at or that you truly live to do. Then it doesn't feel like you are even working. At some point your wealth will have built to more than you ever imagined that it could be. Don't forget to help others less fortunate, and to take a break or two along the way to recharge and enjoy the journey.

You are obviously not the only one asking yourself this question. Know that to become rich, you must first of all have a very particular state of mind. People who become rich have adopted the millionaire state of mind that the American author Harv Eker describes very well in his book "The Secrets of a Millionaire Spirit".  In what follows, I propose that you return to the main lines of this book, which aims to show how to become rich. Thought patterns define wealth If knowledge remains important to achieve wealth, it is not the knowledge that plays the central role. Indeed, Harv Eker argues that it is unconscious thought patterns that will define our future success. Better still, they play a decisive role in our future level of wealth. These patterns of thought and behaviour have been shaped by our experiences since childhood. Our parents play a central role in the mindset we develop During our childhood, our minds are shaped and programmed by our parents. Indeed, we absorb everything they say about money all the time. Even if we do not accept simplistic ideas and statements such as "Money is the root of all evil" when trying to resist them, our state of mind suffers. The result is dramatic because once adult, it becomes even more difficult to unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind. Worse still, children who have grown up with this thought pattern tend to want to prove to their parents that they can make money. This willingness to rebel does not represent a real financial plan. On the contrary, it tends to blind them and drive them away from success. On the other hand, those who learn that anything is possible with money, from an early age, leave with an advantage in life to earn a lot of money. In addition to words, our parents' behaviour also has a huge impact on our adult lives. For example, how they save, spend and earn money. If your father was an entrepreneur who wasn't afraid to take risks and invest, chances are you have a natural propensity to take risks too. On the other hand, if your father was much more conservative about money, there is a good chance you would do the same. Switch to introspection mode to modify your mental programming and unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind Once the awareness is achieved, you must do a deep introspection to find your own mental programming. Forget that your parents programmed you to believe that you will never be able to afford luxurious things. Put aside the subway-business-sleep routine and think about leaving the Rat Race by acting now. To do this, implement Tim Ferriss' 4-hour week to adopt a rich lifestyle now.  Have high self-esteem If you want to become rich, you have to believe in yourself. In this way, you will lead others to believe in you. Be careful, it's not that easy to achieve. Indeed, most of us are raised with the conviction that it is impolite to have high self-esteem. To unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind, you must understand that millionaires think differently. They don't care what other people think about them. You must fully commit to becoming rich to unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind Gathering information on how to change is unfortunately not enough. You will have to replace old habits with new ones. Thus, you will have to move on to new wealth-oriented thought patterns. To do this, you will have to follow 12 tips to become mentally strong. Dare to believe in yourself and repeat every day that you will achieve your goals will lead you to a millionaire state of mind. Nevertheless, we have nothing for nothing in life. You must be willing to make the sacrifices necessary to become rich. If this means working 16 hours a day for a given period, you must accept it and stick to it. In order to unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind, you must constantly search for the growth area. Wealth does not come alone, it must be sought. As you move towards wealth, you will have to make the choice to leave your comfort zone to reach this growth zone. Learn how to take control of your destiny to unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind You must take your destiny into your own hands to unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind. Thus, you will not be able to do so by remaining a spectator on the side of the road. In his book "The Secrets of a Millionaire Spirit", Harv Eker invites you to take the wheel of your destiny. The goal is not to do what the poor tend to do. They give up control of their income to others or throw their money out the window for fun. All this in the hope of getting lucky. This attitude will get you nowhere. Don't complain anymore and act. Only you have the keys to your present and future situation. Take action and make the changes that will lead you to prosperity. Think positively about money People who want to become rich must love and admire rich people. Indeed, if you despise rich people, thinking they are ruthless and worthless, then you will prevent yourself from becoming rich. So you need to adopt a positive attitude towards money. It allows you to do what you want in life. Think of it as a means. So, if your goal is to do good things, then money will allow you to do more. Set high goals and partner with the right people to unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind In life, to reach the top, you have to aim high and be ambitious. In addition, if you want to achieve your most ambitious goals, you will need to partner with the right people. Don't stay locked in your corner. Instead, you must learn to think on a large scale! Do not set a limit on your income Every time you make your income depend on your time, you limit your income. Thus, Harv Eker highlights the fact that we only have 24 hours a day. Once this time has elapsed, you no longer increase your income. Fortunately, there is a solution to this problem. Rich people, who are able to unlock the secrets of a millionaire mind, are rewarded in proportion to the quality of their results. Instead of looking for a well-paying job or producing goods that depend directly on their time, they have learned to automate their business. Here again, we come back to the approach put forward by Tim Ferriss in his book. Conclusion Achieving wealth requires unlocking the secrets of a millionaire mind. In his book "The Secrets of a Millionaire Spirit", Harv Eker brilliantly highlights everything it takes to become a millionaire. To do this, it is necessary to cultivate a state of mind oriented towards wealth from an early age. Secondly, you must not be afraid to take risks to succeed. Indeed, people who become rich play to win, not to avoid losing. By telling yourself every day that you can do it, you will be able to cultivate a millionaire's state of mind. You will then be able to see opportunities where normal people see obstacles. This will maximize your chances of becoming rich in turn.

F*CK STATUS SYMBOLS I see so many people waste money they don’t have on Gucci and Supreme. Spending money on assets that immediately depreciate like cars, only to feel less worthy whenever someone with a later model drives by. Make your own clothes! Tailor t-shirts to fit your exactly right. Find the designs you actually want get them laser printed on. Take UberBlack if you need to pick up a date and want to ride in style. Most of all, stop chasing self worth by chasing the latest trends. Trends come and go, but debt can be forever.Hang out with Rich People Hanging out with James Altucher has lead to so many lucrative opportunities. From getting investment and trading advice, to learning how rich people think about situations, to introducing me to other people who have helped me make money. When you hang out with wealthy people you access to their ideas, network, and habits, and these are the three things that wealthy people use to become wealthy.Invest Time and Money in Developing Skills What makes people make money isn’t how well they save, but how well they do things that other people need (or think they need). So by taking money that you earn and investing it in classes on coding, sales, trading, etc. you learn how to do a profitable skill better. The better you get at a skill that’s profitable, the more people will want to pay you for it.DON’T BUY A HOUSE Go this advice from the homie James and my Dad. Houses seem like a smart investment but a lot of time their a money sink. You have to pay state taxes and they appreciate a lot slower than the market while also being a lot harder to liquidate. Also when you rent, if you lose a job you can just sublet and dip to a smaller joint until you get employed again, which is a lot less of a headache than worrying about your house getting foreclosed and having your credit take a dive. “The problem with owning a home is that when you need to sell you can’t because it’s usually during a recession and that’s when no one is buying” - James AltucherStay Away From Strip Clubs and McDonalds Strip clubs, binge drinking, fast food and drugs are all places where you will invest money but see close to no return.Now some people would argue that doing these things gives you an experience, which I would agree with, but after you experience these things a few time, that novelty becomes part of your identity, which makes it harder to kick, and a whole lot more expensive in the long term.I wrote a book called “The Power Bible” click this link to find out more!

I will give you the secret that isn’t really a secret. The key to becoming wealthy has nothing to do with how much money you make. That is why there are minimum wage millionaires out there and the majority of millionaires have never had an income as high as $100k per year. The secret to becoming wealthy is how you spend the money you make. It doesn’t matter if you make $5 or $5000. If you want to be broke, spend that money on something consumable, like food, music or clothing. Broke people also spend on high price, low value items, like “bling.” If you want to be middle class, spend the money on something that has lasting but not permanent value. Think a home, furniture, vehicles. If you want to stay middle class forever, develop a real high FICO score and buy these things on credit. If you want to become rich, spend as little as possible on consumable goods and lasting but not permanent value goods. Spend as much of your money as possible on things that MAKE YOU MORE MONEY. Most experts say that 15% is the minimum, but the truly wealthy spend between 30% and 70%. The press and most that report on this get the relationship backwards. You will here them say that the wealthy are able to do this because they have a lot of disposable income. That is completely false. They have a lot of disposable income because they have sacrificed to buy things that make money. Some of them for decades. In the beginning you will only be able to stockpile money in savings. then maybe you can get some mutual funds or other simple investments. Finally you can get into real estate and all sorts of other exciting opportunities. You can also work 80 hours per week for 45 years and have a really nice home, car and furniture. Your answer to this simple question will tell if you will be rich in the future. Are you willing to drive a $1000 car or take the bus when you are only worth $10,000 (a car that is 10% of your worth), so that you can drive a $100,000 car when you are worth a $1 million (still 10% of your worth)? Many will answer “YES,” but actions speak louder than words. Broke people will get a $2000 car and rent $1000 rims to put on it. Middle class people will say, “But I need a reliable car,” “Repairs will cost too much,” etc. and be stuck in a car loan or lease for most of their adult life. Future rich people will buy the car for $1000 or less. Sell it to a junkyard and get another when it can no longer be repaired. They will then use their money to buy things that make more money and pay cash for a $2000, $5000 and $10,000 used car as they can afford it. Most I have known never get to the $100,000 car. When you are worth $5 million, nobody, including yourself, cares that you drive an old Toyota, Chevy or Crown Victoria.

I got rich because I wanted to help my sister. I didn’t want to be an entrepreneur. I knew nothing about business. I wanted to make a TV show. I was working at HBO and I pitched them the idea of a “web show” called “III:am” (3AM). The CEO said, “go for it”. [This is the story of my first time, after many attempts, making real money. Summary of what I learned is at the end]. I started going out at three in the morning in NYC on Tuesday or Wednesday nights and interview everyone I ran into. Maybe I could say now it was “the first podcast”. This was 1996–1998 that I did this. I interviewed prostitutes, drug dealers, homeless kids, mentally ill people who felt comfortable wandering the streets only at night. The experience changed my life. These people didn’t fit in. Would never fit in.  Some were good people trapped in bad circumstances. Growing up abused in foster care systems. All of them had something in common. They couldn’t live by the rules of nine to five. They found their energy, their life, outside when there were fewer rules, less judging, an upside down world, a world that almost seemed like a dream or a nightmare while everyone else was sleeping. I wanted to turn it into a TV show. I loved what I was doing. HBO gave me money to shoot it as a pilot. It was an adventure and in the middle of that adventure my sister called me: “Michel needs help with his business. Can you look at what he’s doing and maybe give him some advice?” Sure. He was in the CD-ROM business. What? What’s that? Back then, music was sold on CDs. Back in the dark ages. And then other things started being sold on CDs: games, books, information. This no longer exists. First DVDs, then the Internet replaced it. I started using the Internet in 1987. I started using the “World Wide Web” days after Tim Berners-Lee created the first web server. I was a programmer and learned how to make my own web server, my own search engine, my own websites. There were no tools to create websites. Everything had to be programmed from scratch. But I loved it. While I was trying to create a TV show I was also trying to write a novel. And when the web came along, it seemed like it would be this amazing new art medium: three dimensional novels, TV shows, and who knows what else. I wanted to be an artist on this medium. I was so excited that I became addicted. Maybe there were a few hundred websites at this time. I wish I could find the first website I made. It was a “home page” where I put stories I had written. Isolated pockets from all over the world started using this new medium. I was excited once when I got an email from Germany from someone who read one of the stories on my page and really enjoyed it. I kept up with all the new possibilities with the web. The browsers, the software, the possibilities as bandwidth on the network quickly increased. The first music I ever downloaded on the Internet was “Yesterday” by the Beatles and it took over an hour to download. I took a job at HBO to get physically closer to the decision makers. The people who could say “yes” to a novel I wrote or “yes” to a TV show. I moved to NYC. This is where opportunities were. This is where money was. When I first walked to work I felt like I was living a famous life. Not that I was famous, but that somehow I had stepped into this incredible movie set that I had always dreamed of being a part of. My job was to help HBO set up “interactive TV” across the cable lines. I was programming the remote control and also creating the software for the network that would ship HBO shows straight from a central service onto your TV screen. I said to my boss, “why are we creating an entire network? Let’s use the Web as out backbone since the software is already done for us.” His name was Ken. Ken said, “James, settle down. The Internet might be good for academics but why don’t you let the cable guys do what they are good at.” Ok, ok. But I still kept obsessing on the Web. When I visited Michel, I told him about the Web and showed him what you can do. I said to him, everyone who is using the web now is obsessed with it. I showed him how to make a web page. How to use his design skills to make a page go from basic text (most pages were just text and links on a gray background with no images) to a beautiful page. I showed him how I used software to ad functionality, like a game or a quiz or a query or to take items from a database so that a page could be different every time you loaded it. I showed him so pages I had made, including HBO’s intranet, maybe one of the first intranets created. After I programmed it and convinced HBO to start using it (everything from their movie database to putting the cafeteria menu online so employees could see) other divisions within Time Warner (which owned HBO) started asking for my help to build their intranets. I said to Michel, “this is going to replace CD-ROMs. You have to get good at this and start selling it to your clients.” One day, a company approached us. They said they had a big client who needed a website. Well, they said, actually Arthur Anderson (the biggest accounting firm in the world then, and now out of business because of the Enron scandal) had a big client that needed a website: American Express. Arthur Anderson had no idea to build a website. Particularly a website that would have over 60,000 pages on it. The company they went to had no idea how to build a website. So they came to Michel, who came to me. I had $0 in my bank account. My HBO salary was $40,000 and I thought I was rich! My prior job had a $28,000 salary and I thought I was getting away with murder when HBO paid me $40,000. I don’t know what American Express paid Arthur Anderson. I don’t know what Arthur Anderson paid USI, the company that came to Michel. All I know is that Michel and I made $230,000 on AmericanExpress.com. At the same time we did another website for $35,000. I couldn’t believe how much money I had all of a sudden. Michel and I decided to go into business together. HBO decided to do HBO.com. I was one of the people deciding who to hire to do the job. Three companies pitched us to do HBO.com. I picked the best company for the job! I hired Reset, Inc. The company Michel and I had started. We did HBO’s website and all the websites for their shows. We also started doing websites for every division of Time Warner that had reached out to me, and we even did the website for Time Warner. Then other entertainment companies heard about us and heard about my III:am site. They loved the creativity. “We want that!” they would say to us. So we did the websites for Bad Boy Records, Loud Records, Interscope, Miramax, October Films, New Line Cinema, and the websites for many movies, albums, artists. The website for the movie “The Matrix” paid us $150,000. The website for “Scream 2” we only charged $1,000. We just simply wanted to do it.  I was now making $60,000 a year at HBO and was working out of my cubicle during the day. At night I’d go over to Reset, 20 blocks downtown, and work all night. Sometimes I’d go in the conference room at HBO, lock the door, and make calls to clients during the day. I was scared of getting caught. But I didn’t want to give up my job at HBO. I didn’t enjoy business. I didn’t like dealing with clients. I didn’t like selling although it turned out this might have been the one business skill I was good at. I had such passion for the Web. I knew every customer of every company was going to use it. I would tell companies like JP Morgan that soon everybody would do all of their banking on the Web. I would tell Interscope records that soon everyone would be listening to music on the web. They laughed but they said, “ok, build us a website.” In every meeting with a client, I would over promise. I would take what they wanted and then start suggesting more ideas but within the same price. “You can do that?” they would always ask and I would say “yes!” even though I had no idea. But then we would do it. “over promise and over deliver” became my mantra. People ask me, “Don’t you mean “under promise’?” No, I don’t! Why would I lie to customers? It’s not impressive to under promise and over deliver. Its impressive to shock and awe them on every conversation. “Yes, I can do that and MORE!” and “Here is the site. We did what we said and MORE!” I never lost a client that way. They always needed more and more websites. And they referred us to other websites. Because Michel and I had many of the skills (I was software, he was design), we didn’t have to hire as many people so we also were able to charge less than the few competitors we had. Eventually, when we did hire employees, I couldn’t believe it. This was an actual business! And people were doing my work for me! Which freed me up so I could find more customers. We were growing. And growing. During this time I made so many mistakes. I knew nothing at all about business. There is no such skill as “Business”. Business skill is really a collection of micro-skills: ideas, follow-through, sales, negotiation, execution, management, motivation, communicating vision, hiring well, psychology, and even a subtle skill such as “business valuation”. I had “sales” skill. I had “ideas” and “communicating vision”. I had no follow thru skills. I was horrible at calling people back, even customers who were huge who were begging to hire us. We lost many opportunities that way. The worst is that I didn’t understand how to value a business. Why did Yahoo buy an “internet calendar” for ten million dollars? This seemed silly to me. I didn’t understand why, RESET, which was profitable and had great clients, was valued less than a single piece of software that had no customers and was losing money.  Every day I wrote software that I could have made into products but I just used that software to provide services to our customers. I had no idea how to make my software into a product and then sell that product. I wrote software to easily make websites. I wrote software to create graphics on the fly. I wrote software so that everyone on a team could communicate with each other over the internet to keep track of tasks for that team. I wrote software so that everyone in the company could manage projects and keep track of sales by looking at pages on the web that were private to them. I wrote software to help companies set up e-commerce stores. But I just used that software to help me provide better services. I didn’t realize that a service company was valued at a much less value than a software product company that could scale. I also didn’t know anything about raising money or “going public”. Many people wanted to invest in us but I would say, “we don’t need it. We’re profitable.” I didn’t understand that many those investors could’ve helped me figure out how to be a much more valuable company. Eventually I wanted to sell the company. I hated the clients. All of them. I hated selling. I hated asking them for money. And I hated doing their websites. For fun, Michel and I would make our own websites and part of our sales pitch was showing them sites we made. They would always say, “We want that!” And I also hated being poor. I was making money but we were also using money to pour back into the business. And after 18 months of juggling both HBO and RESET, I jumped ship to work fulltime at my own company. By that point, we had about 20 employees and were on track to do three million in revenues. But I had never wanted to take the risk of leaving HBO. Being an entrepreneur seemed too risky! And it was. Every day a client threatens to leave, or drops a project that you thought would’ve made a lot of money. Every day I had to sell. I was the only salesman for the company and I was the CEO and the programmer. And you can’t leave the work at the office. It was 24 hours of worry. I’d stay up at night wondering how I was going to pay people if clients left. I was sick with worry all of the time. I spent a lot of time trying to get a bigger company to buy us. I met with everyone. They always asked, “why do you want to sell?” The answer, to me, was obvious, I wanted money! But I couldn’t say that. Theres always a good reason and a real reason. The real reason was I wanted to be rich. The good reason was what I gave, “we are expanding so fast that I want a partner so we can keep achieving bigger and better.” We got several offers. When you get an offer for a company its rarely, “here’s $5 million in cash and now we own your company.” So I had to learn the skills of structuring a deal. A deal will usually look like: part cash, part stock, part “earn-out”. So you are tied to the company who buys you via the stock you own, plus your ability to grow it (and so the earn-out would kick in and give you more money over time). I am skipping a lot of the story. The time we tried to start a record label. Or a tea company. Because we felt we should diversify. Or the time one of our competitors threw a chair at me when we ran into them at a restaurant (which was the first of two times that a competitor threw a chair at me). Or the time we [well known rap group] visit us and pull out their guns while checking out how we were doing with their website. Or the many many times that people at companies would ask us for bribes if they threw the business to us. Many, many stories while my brother in law and I simply just tried to wing “business” as best we could. We had no idea what we were doing. And, we didn’t even know what we didn’t even know. And I was scared all the time. Finally, someone made us an offer that looked good. We took it. And the worst period was that while I had been busy selling the company, I hadn’t been focused on getting new clients. That’s ok, I thought. Because once we got an offer to sell the company I figured the deal would close fast and I would have money. MONEY! The lawyers would always say, “next week”, when we would ask when the deal would close. But next week turned into next week turned into next month. I couldn’t tell if the buyer was getting nervous (“buyer’s remorse”) or if this was normal. But I really wanted to go from almost no money in my bank account to millions and I was getting terrified it wouldn’t happen. And meanwhile we were losing customers. My eye was off the ball. I just didn’t know what to do. And we didn’t really have anybody at an executive level that could help me. We had never hired for that because we were cheap and always wanted to have the cheapest services so that people would hire us. Finally, the deal closed . Seven months after we got the offer. Millions of dollars were wired into my bank account. Oh my god I was so happy. I had totally cashed out. I was rich. Two years later I had $143 in my bank account and lost my home. But that’s another story.  Summary: I had to go from zero to rich several times. I was always making money, going broke, starting from scratch, and making it again. Each time I succeeded was because of the following: have a vision for the future that is unique. If you aren’t the only one in the room, you’re in the wrong room.be able to sell that vision: why it’s unique, why the customer will benefit, why you are the best qualified to execute for the customer, what is the concrete value of what you are selling?Microskills: build the skills needed to be a part of that vision so that the future doesn’t leave you behind. Software skills, or writing skills, or negotiating skills, etc.Spoke and Wheel rule: share that vision with everyone. Create projects just for you that others can see. Build a network of people who want to hear your vision and participate in it. You can do this by writing articles, building a website, offering free services, participating in social media groups, etc.Use the above to get customers.Give your customers new ideas every day. Write down 10 ideas a day to keep the “creativity muscle” exercised.Customer rule #1: “touch” your customer every day for at least the first 100 days they are a customer.Customer rule #2: your best new customers are your old customers.Customer rule #3: 16 touches. To get a customer, you have to communicate with them, on average, 16 times. Share ideas, make introductions, go to dinner, go to a charity event with them, help them out for free - each one of those is a single touch.Surround yourself with good people. Without a good partner, you are dead. Without good customers, you are dead. Without good people to help you execute, you are dead. Without good friends, you are dead. You can’t make money if you are arguing with spouses, friends, employees, customers every day.Stay healthy. You can’t build your business if you are sick.Turn services into products. For example: if you like giving investment advice, figure out how to automate that or scale that to large numbers of people. The dream is to scale. Valuation is when you sell that dream.Sell the business as soon you can. Particularly your first business. This way you have money and can relax a bit when you start your second, hopefully bigger, business.There are three skills to money: making it, keeping it, growing it. When you “make it”, make sure you learn how to “Keep it” before you try to “grow it”. If you skip that part you WILL go broke.Finally, read real stories like the one I just told. There’s too many people talking about “Uber” and not enough talking about real business. Real business is about reducing risk. Not taking risks. Real business is about providing value. Not smoke-and-mirrors value. Real business is about relationships. Not about money. Real business is ugly and dirty. Real business has problems every day. The highs and the lows are brutal. Don’t believe specific tactics (like “buy on Etsy and sell on Amazon”). Every business carves it’s own path. Study all the paths. Come up with ten ideas a day to begin exercising your “idea muscle”. Then you come up with something unique. Something that is YOU and nobody else. Stay healthy, exercise creativity every day, have good people around you, don’t try to control things that are out of your control. That’s how you get rich.

By NOT saving money! Savers are losers in this economy! Let me explain: The rules of money were changed in 1971 when President Nixon broke the Bretton Woods agreement.This is what took the U.S. dollar off the gold standard!The rules of money changed as the U.S. dollar stopped being money (backed up by gold) and became an instrument of debt.After 1971, savers became losers!Here’s the depressing truth: Millions of people still believe that wealth is created by saving money. Millions try to cut back on their expenses to save money, while the federal government prints trillions of dollars, which destroys the purchasing power of your savings!This is how it works: Have you heard of Quantitative Easing? What about QE1, QE2, QE3?  When Central Banks create money out of thin air they call it “quantitative easing.” Why call it quantitative easing? It’s simply a cover-up name to “printing money.” It sounds more complex and interesting. It's a fantastic way to deceive millions of people who will try to work harder and save even more while this brings terrible inflationary effects to the economy. Luckily the quantitative easing has temporarily stopped, but the result is this:  Your purchase power decreases as time goes by… and it's still falling fast! But… I have “millions” saved!Good for you!Better start investing your money on ASSETS!But… I’m making compounding interest on my investments!That’s not good enough!Are your compounding interest investments helping you feel more financially safe or not? Most likely not!To answer your question: You need to invest in assets to protect your wealth from the inflationary effects on your money! Assets that keep their intrinsic value over time like Real Estate. A car is NOT an asset because it depreciates over time… unless its a 1962 Ferrari 250 GTO, which sold for a record $34.65 million! How is money made in the Information Age? Here’s what I wrote a few days ago: How can I become rich?

According to me, being rich begins in your mind — not in your pocket. To get rich, you have to believe that something so extremely far away from your reach, with a little hard work and determination, is actually possible. Several people aspire to break bad habits but habits can impact your performance and productivity. Actually, it is habits, that separate the rich from the poor. That’s why I would share 8 good habits that will help you become rich in life. Spend judiciously: Wealthy people prevent over-expenditure by rewarding their future selves first. Nearly all of those who struggle financially are living beyond their means. They spend more than they earn, and their debt is daunting. If you want to put an end to your financial problems, you need to make a habit of saving, investing, and budgeting what you spend. Must Read: Rishabh Surana's answer to What are effective ways of saving money as a student?Challenge yourself : If you want to get rich, then you should surround yourself with people who question your beliefs. Being surrounded by people, who don't confirm your perceptions of life will inspire you to think outside the box. Hence the famous saying "birds of the same feather flock together".Read every day : Learning information that will improve your awareness of your industry or profession will make you more important to friends, customers, or clients. Most rich people read 30 minutes or more every day.Monitor your emotions : Not every thought has to come out of your mouth. Not every emotion has to be expressed. If you say something in your mind, you risk offending someone. You need to realize that allowing your emotions to dominate them will ruin relationships at work and at home. Wait to say what’s on your mind until you are calm and have had time to look carefully at the situation.Talk Less and listen more : Wealthy people are good communicators, and they're good listeners. I realize that you can learn and teach yourself only by listening to what other people have to say. Just as the ratio of ears and mouth is 2:1, you should hear more and then talk only after you are confident enough to confront!Impossible is possible : I agree there are things that are really impossible but becoming rich isn’t impossible. Some dreams do come true when you work for it. Talk to yourself each and every day with full zeal and zest and compel your mind to get convinced. When your dictionary is full of affirmative words, there is no way to look back. Wealth will knock your doors automatically.Live in the future : “I am living in the future, so the present is my past.” – Kanye West. Those who have made or who make a lot of money are not prophets who predict the future; they are ordinary people like you. They give an attempt to look into the future on a regular basis. I know of a man who demonstrated this so perfectly and we all are aware of Steve Jobs the apple guy. Steve seemed to know what people would want even before they knew they would want it.Networking is Important : You'll create meaningful connections that can lead to more sales, or help you get a better job if you spend time pressing your flesh and giving back to your community. Must Read: Rishabh Surana's answer to Why should you meet as much people as possible?A wise man once said, “Someone is sitting in the shade today because someone planted a tree a long time ago.” So you want a better tomorrow or accumulate wealth then change your habits now. Visualize your dreams and start working for them with a positive attitude.

This is Charles M. Schwab.  Charles Schwab was an American Industrialist and a manager in the beginning of 20th century. He was one of the first person in America who was paid annual salary over one million dollars. That time in America there were no taxes. A person who was earning 50 dollars a week was considered as well off. Andrew Carnegie selected Charles Schwab to become the first president of a Steel Company in 1921. This steel company was newly formed, and its name was United States Steel Company. At that time, Charles Schwab was only thirty-eight years old.  As soon Charles Schwab joined United States Steel Mills, he turned it into a profitable business. And later, he took over a troubled Bethlehem Steel Company and transformed it into one of the most profitable and successful companies in the United States. How Charles Schwab did it? What was that ability for which Andrew Carnegie hired Charles Schwab and paid him over 1 million dollar? Was Charles Schwab a genius? No. Was Charles Schwab a technical expert in the manufacture of Steel? No. There were many engineers who had far more expertise than Charles Schwab. However, the sole reason was that Charles Schwab had an admirable ability to arouse enthusiasm in the people. Charles Schwab himself told the reason of his success, a question which people frequently used to ask him with a lot of curiosity. Below golden words of Charles Schwab need to be written on the walls of our homes, in the notepads of our mobiles, in the computers of our offices and most importantly in our brains. “I consider my ability to arouse enthusiasm among my people the greatest asset I possess. And the way to develop the best that is in a person is by appreciation and encouragement”. “There is nothing else that so kills the ambitions of a person as criticisms from superiors. I never criticize anyone. I believe in giving a person incentive to work. So I am anxious to praise, but loath to find fault. If I like anything, I am hearty in my approbation and lavish in my praise. This is what Charles Schwab said and this is what was his practice in his life.  But, what we do in our life. In fact, we do exactly the opposite. In our office, if we don’t like the work of our subordinates we severely criticize them for their incompetency. We directly say that you are wrong. We threat them of not giving good appraisal and even sometimes we threat them of terminating from the job. In our homes, we criticize our kids for not doing their homework. We criticize them for not sleeping on time. We criticize them for always keep asking for toys. This criticism creates a stressed atmosphere around us and drops our enthusiasm to put more effort in our works. On the other hand, when we appreciate people, science tells us that this appreciation releases a chemical in their brains called as dopamine. This dopamine makes people more energetic and active. Ultimately our appreciation enhances people’s capacity to do more work with greater energy. So those who were previously not giving any useful input, get more involved in their work.  So let’s decide today! We will not criticize people for their wrongs. We will not insult them for their bad behaviors. We will not use negative language with them. Instead, We will appreciate people. We will give them a sincere guidance that is without any greed or lust. This is a best kept secret for any kind of success. (This event was given as an example by Dale Carnegie in his book How to Win Friends and Influence People)

After three years of work, my friend at work told me he had saved $20,000. He told me it happens automatically into his savings from his paycheck. I looked at my statements and there were hundreds of dollars unaccounted for last month, no doubt spent on “women, wine and song”. I started doing what he was doing. Save when you are young to get the benefit of compounding. What Is Compound Interest? -- The Motley Fool I have always kept a fund called a fu*k you fund where I could leave a company if I so desired and go to another. Keep a budget, many templates online. Know your expenses. Have 6 months in expenses saved away and do not break the glass unless an emergency. Develop a written financial plan. Save, save, save. Try to devote no more than 28 - 33 percent of your gross monthly income to your mortgage or rent - some experts even suggest 25 percent. Another way to look at it is that your home should cost roughly no more than four times your annual income. In terms of prioritizing a budget, it's never too early to save for the future. Start with retirement savings, then credit card debt, and then your emergency fund. Allocate 10 percent of your income to savings. When it comes to discretionary spending, plan to save 10 percent for the basics, 15 percent for comfort, and around 20 percent to escape. After your mortgage or rent, that leaves roughly 12 - 20 percent for the rest of your household needs, perhaps more if you're frugal. In the past, a rule of thumb was to set aside three months of expenses in an emergency fund. In this economic climate, consider planning for six months. Include your mortgage, car payments and groceries. If the figure is large, think about opening a money market account to earn interest. If you're just starting out, try to save 10 percent of your income. If this is difficult, start small and build toward your goals: set up a direct deposit with your employer, and direct $10, $25 or $50 into your savings instead of your checking. This can add up quickly! If you are farther along in your career, include investment goals in your savings strategy. Don't overlook the small stuff for potential savings. Every dollar counts. Whether it's packing a lunch instead of eating out, opting for a regular coffee instead of a pricey specialty drink, or using your cell phone as your primary telephone, there are many ways to better budget your money. Keep a record of expenses to help identify wasteful spending and opportunities to cut back. This leads to the level of accountability you'll need if you're serious about saving for the future Live below your means. Power is not getting what you want; it is wanting what you have Lay off the credit. Invest in ways that work for you. Get professional advice. Get a 15 year mortgage not a 30 year Don’t miss out on being a parent All material objects fade and rust, no matter how they glitter. You don’t need money to happy forever. Success is not getting what you want, it’s being happy with what you have. I will say that money buys security. Figure out what your monthly expenses really are and multiply that out by your life expectancy online that is a total you will need for the rest of your life. It does not have to be much just enough. There are some big-ticket items, as you grow older. Education for the children, health insurance and long-term disability care when you were in a nursing home. INVESTMENTS There are two kinds of investors- those who like to eat well and those who like to sleep well. :) Invest in mutual funds that have 1000 stocks Add to the fund automatically Never touch it, do not time the market. When the market is down keep buying. When you are 50, put 1/3 in bonds. Remember this- You will run out of time before you run out of money.

Most people, if not all of us, want to live in financial comfort and stability. We want to be rich, to be able to buy anything we want, and to have access to a premium lifestyle. While the end goal is clear, it’s hard to know where to begin your journey to being wealthy. Before you get started, it’s important to acknowledge that becoming rich takes time and effort. There are very few ways to instantly have large amounts of wealth, and all of them are luck-based. Not all of us can win the lottery or inherit a fortune from a mysterious rich relative. Becoming rich in most cases involves a lot of hard work, patience, and time. There are some tried-and-true things you can do that can help you get rich, but the key is to constantly and consistently work hard, keep track of your personal finances, and keep your eyes on the prize. 1. Add Value Something many self-made wealthy people have in common is that they are valuable in specific ways. Even when millionaires and billionaires are taken out of the equation, many rich people — doctors, engineers, filmmakers — have gotten rich after adding value to themselves and then adding value to the world. For example, a rich neurosurgeon may be specially talented and skilled. This surgeon added value to the world after improving their own skills and quality of life. Adding value to yourself is a good foundation to begin your journey to being rich. Develop some knowledge or skills that justify someone paying you a good amount of money. Convince people that you are worth a large paycheck because you will add value to their lives in return. 2. Tax Yourself  The concept of saving money is not a new one. However, it is extremely easy to “dip into your savings” when you want something badly enough. The key to accomplishing your goal of amassing wealth is to actually try and save money. A different way of looking at your savings is to view them as taxes. Once you pay your taxes, you never get the whole amount back. Treat your savings the same way. Set money aside in a savings account or transfer it to a totally separate account where you cannot touch it. Treat your savings like money that you will never get back, until the day that you get it all back at once. 3. Create a Plan and Follow It  The likelihood of suddenly stumbling upon unlimited riches is extremely low. While it may seem that a lot of the success stories you hear are luck-based, this is actually not true. There is probably some chance and luck involved, but most rich people became rich through meticulous planning and discipline. This includes things like budgets and timelines, as well as a plan of what to do at every step of the way to success. It is important not to get complacent and do your best to keep going, and having a plan helps without wasting unnecessary amounts of time. Creating a budget and following it is only one part of this process. 4. Invest The core principle behind investing is that you end up making more money than you spent. However, it is important to choose your investments wisely. There are plenty of places for you to sink your money into, but figuring out which one of these will result in you profiting is difficult. Real estate is sometimes a good investment, but it is expensive. Investing in the stock market does not have to be expensive, but it can be risky and unstable. A 401K is a wise investment that you should invest in, but it can depend on how well the business you work for is doing. There are plenty of factors to consider when investing, so make sure you think about it rationally. Talk to experts or friends who are experienced in investing before making a decision. 5. Start a Business This is much easier said than done, but the last four steps lay the groundwork to be able to start your own business. If you have a knack for business or want to be your own boss, this can be a great step to making some money. However, as many entrepreneurs will tell you, creating your own business requires massive upfront costs and low revenue in the beginning. Being an entrepreneur is not a quick way to get rich — it is a massive change in lifestyle. It has its unique trials and rewards, and in many cases is totally worth it. However, this is not a choice to be taken lightly. It requires commitment, grit, and some luck to be successful. While it may take some time, it can certainly help you get wealthy. 6. Be Grateful Becoming rich does not only require external factors to fall into place — many personality factors have to align for you to succeed at whatever venture you’ve started. Staying humble and grateful for the progress you’ve made at every step of the way is essential. People do not want to give their money to someone who does not appear to appreciate it, or gets too carried away with any moderate amount of success. Keeping your life in perspective and having a considerate, thankful, and humble attitude is the way to go. 7. Develop Patience  Another important personality trait to being successful and rich is patience. Nothing big is accomplished overnight, and you cannot and will not get rich in a matter of days. All the efforts you put towards accumulating wealth could take months or even years to pay off. It’s easy to get frustrated early on, especially when it seems like there’s a new wealthy person in the news every other day. However, realizing that your pace of success does not have to compete with theirs is crucial. In the long run, patience can be extremely rewarding. This does not mean that you should get complacent or wait things out instead of taking risks. Success can take some time, and getting frustrated is detrimental to your efforts. 8. Educate Yourself  It is key to try and educate yourself, not only in your chosen field but also in the ways of the world. Keeping up with the news, for example, is extremely important if you want to make a decision about investing or find out about upcoming trends. Ignorance is the prime killer of any efforts to make money. This means you have to constantly educate yourself. You cannot let major events or trends slide, because in each of them there is a threat or opportunity for you. Staying aware and educating yourself about current events is essential. 9. Take Calculated Risks There is no money made without a risk taken. Whether it’s starting a business or investing in stocks, every avenue to making money requires some risk. Even selling your old furniture requires you taking the risk that the buyer will show up and will pay you. It is a comparatively small risk when compared to deciding whether to spend millions of dollars on a new product line, but it is still a risk. In order to make money, you have to take a chance that a venture or idea you have will pan out. Therefore, it is important to think deeply and evaluate multiple possible outcomes before you decide that an investment is worth it. Taking risks without thinking about them beforehand is an incredibly quick way to lose money. To earn, you should take risks, but they should be calculated. 10. Give Back  It is important to give back to the community. This leads back to the first point about adding value to the world around you. If you earn some money, give some back to a cause you believe in. This way, you are adding value to the world after having added value to yourself. Another benefit of giving to charity is that people perceive you as a better person when you give to causes they care about. They are likely to trust you more when they see that you aren’t intent on hoarding the money they give you, and that doing so will benefit their community in turn. Of course, the tax benefits of giving to charity are also a great incentive to do so. Being rich means something different to every individual. Some people are happy with a decent-sized home and a moderate-income job, while others want to be millionaires and billionaires. Regardless of where you feel you fall on the spectrum, these steps can help you achieve the level of wealth you want. Before you get started, though, make sure to sort out your current finances so your bank account is ready to expand.

Meet Gary Dahl, The guy who invented of the Pet Rock.[1] Gary proved that you don’t need to be a rocket scientist to get rich. What you do need to do is think different than the majority of people. That’s what Gary Dahl did, and it made him very successful. Gary Dahl sold rocks. But not just any rocks, he sold Pet Rocks. He marketed the Pet Rock to parents as a solution to one of their biggest problems – a nagging child who keeps asking for a pet. The Pet Rock is cheap, it’s a pet, and the best part? You don’t have to clean up any poop. The craze around this “toy” was high up there, alongside the Hula Hoop and Slinky, though it’s production was much more, well, simple. For about $4, you can buy a simple, oval rock in a box, with the idea that you present this rock to your child as a pet. In 1975, over a million customers did just that (remember there were no social media at that time) – and he proved, once and for all, that good marketing really can sell anything. He sold the Pet Rocks for $3.95 and walked away with $15,000,000 (that’s not a typo, he really made $15 million).  So how did Gary Dahl do it – and what can we learn from his success? Gary Dahl, who passed away in 2015, got his start as an advertising copywriter, which doesn’t really come as a surprise. The idea behind the Pet Rock supposedly started as a joke, inspired by the popular children’s story, Stone Soup. The idea was dreamt up over a few alcoholic beverages in Northern California, during which he listened to other patrons complain about how difficult pets were to take care of. Legend has it that Dahl imagined that the Pet Rock was a “packaged sense of humor,” according to an interview with People he gave that same year. Whether it was the appeal of a fantasy pet, or it was simply for humor, the new toy made him very wealthy, very quickly. WE JUDGE BOOKS BY THEIR COVERS This is the most obvious point we can all learn from the Pet Rock. The reason why the product flourished, despite the fact that it was just an ordinary stone you could find in your backyard or in the park, was that it was packaged and marketed perfectly. It came in a small container with air holes, similar to the ones that real pets might come in from the pet shop. The rock itself was laid in a nest of hay, making it look like an egg. And it even came with a detailed care guide with instructions on how to care for the rock – which was a genius stroke of cynical humor. We’ve all heard the popular saying, “don’t judge a book by its cover.” If we actually listened to that advice, authors wouldn’t bother paying designers thousands of dollars (and sometimes tens of thousands of dollars) to make their book covers beautifully. Your packaging tells the customer what their buying, but it can also be part of the product – and experience – itself. SELL AN EMOTION, NOT JUST A PRODUCT The Pet Rock catered to customers in the 1970s, who were feeling restless, bored, and cynical. Remember, this was the time that not only the Pet Rock became popular, but also Magic 8-Balls and mood rings. The most popular movies were about mental hospitals abusing patients (One Flew Over The Cuckoo’s Nest) and sharks eating tourists (Jaws). There was an aura of disillusionment throughout.
