Dahl knew that people were unhappy and looking for escapism, and his product hit at just the right moment. Sometimes it’s not a product that the consumer wants, it’s a mental state they’re after. Whether it’s to laugh, fantasize, feel safe, or feel smart or powerful, cater to that. If Gary Dahl can be successful by selling rocks, you can do it too. So what are you waiting for? Footnotes[1] How Gary Dahl Became A Millionaire By Selling Rocks - Minority Mindset

At heart I am a value investor. I look for out of favour companies with strong financials and growth prospects, sometimes with near future catalysts. But over the last few years I have developed a ridiculously simple new strategy. I haven't got a name for it, so I'll call it the 'Do I really need it' strategy. It goes something like this:I wanted the new iPhone 5 when it came out, but I didn't need it.So I bought the stock instead. I wanted the iPhone 6 when it came out, but my iPhone 4 still worked great.So once again, I bought the stock. I wanted to save for a Tesla, or at least buy one on lease.I didn't really need a Tesla, I use public transport for all my travels without a hitch.So I bought the stock instead. When Netflix came out a few years ago, I thought 'Netflix is super cool! But I never have time to watch TV.'So I bought some stock instead. I've repeated this with quite a few big potential purchases.Obviously I do a qualitative and quantitative analysis of the underlying businesses before I purchase the stock. If I didn't understand the underlying business or it didn't fit my criteria, I'd usually just buy SPY or something instead.It's actually been quite an eye opener, realising that we're made to believe we need so many things when in reality, we don't. And even better, all these items I would have bought would have depreciated and lost value.My life is no worse off for not having them, and in fact, I'm much wealthier.The returns from my alternative investing method have been far greater than I ever could have imaged.

Anyone can become rich, but not everyone does. For starters, “rich” depends on a host of factors. If you’re earning $100,000/year in Atlanta, GA, then you’re doing pretty well. If you’re earning $100,000/year in San Francisco or NYC, however, then you might be having trouble even paying the rent. You’re probably living with roommates. Living in an area you can afford improves your chances of ending up rich. If you had been living in the year 1900, then $100,000/year meant you were almost living like a king or queen. That amount is only somewhat above average in 2019, thanks to inflation. Inflation grows as the global economy grows, meaning that it’s unavoidable unless an economy quits growing (unlikely). That’s why, when wages fail to keep up with inflation, it becomes a serious problem. Your income can’t buy as much as it used to. That means you must earn more and more income over time to overcome inflation and improve your chances of becoming rich since inflation erodes your income. If you’re earning $500,000/year from one stream of income such as a job, then while you’re making a fair bit, your income comes from one income source. Lose that income source, and your income falls right down to $0. On the other hand, if you’re making $100,000/year at a job, but you have other income streams that pay you $50,000/year, $1 million/year, $400,000/year, $7 million/year, and so on, then you’re doing much better financially than in the other scenario. If you lose one income source, at least the others are still making bank for you. That’s how a guy like Warren Buffet can be a multi-billionaire, despite “only” earning $100,000/year as the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway. Owning income-producing assets can really boost your chances of becoming rich. Examples include: Copyrights (ownership of intellectual property like artwork, a book series, a movie series, a media franchise)Business or series of businesses (restaurant chain, chain of spas, chain of computer hardware stores, etc)Real estate (multi-family properties, single-family properties, land, etc)Savings account,Retirement accountPatents on an inventionLoansShares in a companyBonds in a company, country, etcThe point is, many things dictate whether someone becomes rich or not. Those things include living costs, inflation, the income-producing assets that you own, and other things. Anyone can become rich, but not everyone does due to a lack of control over and understanding of these factors. Chasing money isn’t the way to become rich. Understanding and taking advantage of things like income-producing assets, the cost of living, and inflation are the ways to become rich. It’s easier said than done. That’s my two cents, anyway.

Six secrets to know to become a millionaire  Many millionaires now live in the middle class, work full time and shop in discount stores like everyone else. Wondering how rich they became? These are the six secrets to know to become a millionaire. The secrets of millionaires To make a fortune, it is not as sorcerer as it seems. 1. Concentrate on your goal to become a millionaire Wanting to be rich is condition number 1. "The biggest obstacle to wealth is fear," says T. Harv Eker, author of Secrets of the Millionaire Mind. People are afraid to think big, but if you see little, you will only realize small things. " 2. Make your education to enrich yourself To make money, you need to know as much as you can about finance. Read books and magazines about money management and investing. Ask everyone who knows about it to explain how it works and start applying what you learn: living below your means, not making impulsive purchases, always trying to negotiate better prices (on cars , cable bills, supplies, etc.), stay in one's home even if one has long been able to afford a more expensive one, and invest 20% of one's annual income.  3. Passion, it pays According to research by Thomas J. Stanley, author of The Millionaire Mind, over 80% of millionaires say they would never have succeeded if their main occupation had not been something that was close to their heart. So, if you want to get rich, and even if it's not always easy, focus on your passion rather than the paycheck. 4. Make your money work and become a millionaire Put money aside for the sole purpose of investing in something that pays off, whether it's in your retirement fund, in a particular business or in real estate. The most important thing is that this money pays you back. This means that you have to place it where it will work hard for your own profit before using it for another purpose, like offering you the latest flat screen TV model. 5. Know, future millionaires, that there is often no glory without risk! To make a fortune also requires taking risks. At age 29, Dave Lindahl opened a landscaping business by purchasing all equipment on credit. When things went down in the winter, he took home renovation contracts. After a few contracts, he thought he'd better buy houses and sell them for profit. He took the risk and bought a first house. With the profits, he bought another, then another. Today, Lindahl owns more than $ 143 million worth of rental properties in eight US states. 6. The ultimate secret to becoming a millionaire? Stop spending! There is no chance ... According to the 2007 US wealth survey, some of the wealthiest 'spend their money as the middle class'. They cut out coupons, wait for sales and buy luxury items when there is a discount. If you want to become a millionaire, cut into unnecessary spending and focus on setting the conditions that will lead you to fortune.

Work hard. Don't pass on lucrative opportunities. Take risks, but get lucky by having the risks you take work out rather than imploding on you. Be in the right place at the right time to be able to take advantage of opportunities. Invest your money wisely. Delay gratification in order to invest in your future. Almost every single person used as an example by the other answers worked hard, took advantage of opportunities, wisely invested, didn't give up after failing. And they were all in the right place at the right time and were lucky enough to have their risk taking pan out. That's why there's a lot of people posting about other rich people, quoting them, but most of these plebs aren't themselves rich despite taking the advice. This isn't a Disney movie. Time for everyone to grow the fuck up. There's a finite amount of opportunity out there. Not all of you will have those doors open for you even if you all followed the advice. That's a fantasy. You can not completely control the luck component: being in the right place at the right time, having your risks pan out. All you can control is being prepared if and when the opportunity does arrive. You can control your investing, you work ethic, your networking, etc. But, don't any of you fucks delude yourselves. There is a chance component to all of this whether you like to admit it or not. Bill Gates happened to have been surrounded by the right people who helped him along and an environment that afforded him opportunities other people didn't. Read about his early life if you don't know what I'm talking about. Zuckerberg also was surrounded by some very smart, hard working people that did a lot of the heavy lifting in making Facebook. Those are variables neither Bill, nor Zuck had full control over. However, both of these guys took full advantage of those opportunities when they present themselves. That's all you can do. That's all I'd tell you. I'm not going to blow lofty smoke up your ass.

How to Get Rich: 11 Bold Moves That Guarantee Wealth Everyone has dreams about winning the lottery and getting crazy rich overnight. People want to get rich. Just do a search on Google Books and you can see that it’s been a rising trend since the 90s.  Many people are looking for ways to get their first 100K, or ways to invest for a better retirement. Some are trying to succeed as entrepreneurs. People want to have enough money to buy beautiful homes, powerful cars, and great vacations. But not many know what getting rich really means and what it takes. Being rich is more than about the dollar amount. Being rich is a state of mind. In a sense, you could be rich but still poor, and vice versa. You can define “rich” in different ways. There are a lot of people who simply consider it as having a lot of money. For them, rich is equivalent to a being a millionaire. But rich can also be psychological richness. It is an achievement of being able to live without the worry of money. You don’t necessarily need to own a castle to be considered rich. Everyone can be rich as long as we are able to do what we desire freely and to have the fulfillment in life. The key of it is to live with or even less than what you have. To be “normal” even when you are financially capable to do a lot more. You might have your own preference on which definition suits you better, but here are some ways on how to get rich. It may help you achieve either (or both) of them. If you want to become really really rich, make bold moves. It’s an ambitious goal to become a very rich person, and if you’re aiming for that, do something big, and make some great changes in life. 1. Exploit your skill as a self-employed expert and invest in it. Make it your goal to do one thing better than anyone: Work on it, train it, learn it, practice, evaluate and refine it. You may find most sports-players or entertainers are millionaires, and that is because they are utilizing their skills fully. If there’s something you’re good at, it is likely you can reap considerable rewards out of it. It is the same concept of being the top of a particular field. When you are the best at something, you find that opportunities come to you. To become an expert of something, it is crucial to never stop improving. Successful people invest time, energy, and money in improving themselves, and it might just be the most rewarding investment you can ever make. To get started, figure out what skill you want to cultivate. Make a list of the world’s ten best people at that one thing, and use this list to define criteria and track your own progress toward becoming the best. If you’re a writer, for example, you might consult the New York Times Bestseller list, and identify the ten successful authors that you admire the most. Learn more about these writers, what they did to be successful, and read some of their work. Invest the time and energy in improving your own craft, by looking at successful past models. 2. Hit $100K, then invest the rest. Everyone wants to be a millionaire. But a goal like this isn’t something you can easily achieve in a short period of time. Aim at saving $100K first. The small amounts you save daily is powerful. You might only be able to put away $5 or $10 at a time, but each of these investments are your financial foundation. 3. Be an inventor and consider it as an opportunity to serve. Stop thinking about making a lot of money and start thinking about serving a lot of people. If you think about what people need, or things that could improve society, your insights will have more impact. Not only that, you could be the first to produce a trending product in the future. When you start to serve a lot of people, the effect of word of mouth is magnified – not to mention, you’ll have much more helpful feedback to improve what you do. Having the patent of a popular invention could be the fast-lane ticket to prosper. Just look at Snap-chat. It would definitely be challenging, but consider it to be a way of serving, to benefit those who actually need your invention. No business is successful without the support of the public. Rather than squeezing every single dollar out of your customers, show them you are actually working to make them better. 4. Join a start-up and get stock. Using the same potential consideration of start-up in the above points, owning stocks of one or more start-up companies could be a valuable investment if the company thrives and either floats or is sold to a larger enterprise. Only a small minority of start-ups succeed in realizing large capital gains, so the odds are not good. However, you can use your judgement to see which business idea and which management team are likely to succeed. Early employees in Apple, Google and Microsoft became millionaires on this basis. 5. Develop property. Buying, developing and selling property has always been a major way for people to accumulate capital. Borrowing could be a key element in this method. Say you borrow $200,000 and put in $50,000 of your own to buy a property for $250,000. Then you develop the property and sell it for $400,000. The property has increased in value by 60% but your $50,000 has now grown fourfold to $200,000. You have to select the right properties in the right areas and develop them wisely. You are at risk from booms and busts in the property market. However, in the long term this remains a proven way to accumulate wealth. 6. Build a portfolio of stocks and shares. If you can make steady investments in stocks over a long period, choose wisely and reinvest the dividends then you can build a large store of wealth. Of course stocks can go either way and many small investors lose heart when their portfolio plunges. But over the long-term, equities are as good an investment as property and much more liquid. Stock market crashes represent great buying opportunities for those with cash and strong nerves. 7. Start your own business and eventually sell it More and more startup have seen success with great return in recent years. If you can find a new approach towards a specific corner of the market and build a business that addresses that need, then you have a potential of success in it. It literally can be anything: a cleaning business, a food delivery service, or a blog. It will probably take years of very hard work to build up the enterprise. All entrepreneurs will have to endure great risk and stress. But if you can pull it off, the potential rewards are huge. This is how many of the seriously wealthy people did it. If you want to become wealthier and live a better life, build simple habits. If you’re aiming for a stable life with enough money to support a living, start with the everyday things you can do. 8. Find a job in the right vehicle. Choose a job of your interest – do what you love and love what you do. No one succeeds in doing what they hate. You might have to start at the bottom and work your way up. But chances are, if you love what you do, it’s easier to make that happen. You’ll actually enjoy the process of getting to the top. Earn the experience through different levels of work and when you feel like you have gained all that you can from it, consider moving on in other companies would widen your horizon on different business cultures. Putting more experiences in various positions would make you a more valuable asset for companies and making you a better option for higher rank duties. Consider how the rich are able to get in with the right companies, where there are plenty of opportunities for growth. Seek places where you can grow your skill and and are able to multiply your monthly income many times over 9. Cut your expenses. The biggest problem in some people’s path of getting rich is that they always spend more than what they earn. Living below your means will be the easiest to get rich. Consistently track your progress on how much you’re spending. Use an app or simply an Excel spreadsheet to make sure you always know how much money you have what where it’s going. This gives you a proper place to review and refine what does and doesn’t make sense in terms of your spending. Start cutting the unnecessary spendings in your life. Do what you can to reduce your bills: make sure you turn off the lights, plan meals to save at the grocery store, and be disciplined about eating in. Focus your life with only the necessities and in no time you will be saving a lot more than what you previously did. 10. Save it in your bank. Set savings goals and routines to support those goals. Figure out ways that work for you in saving money, and refine what doesn’t. Many banks have the option of creating separate savings accounts, as well as automatic withdrawals. By setting up these automatic transfers, you save passively and have to make an effort not to save. Another thing you can try is to increase the amount of savings by 1% in every interval you wish. At first, it will be an insignificant change, but as time passes, you will notice a big difference. Give yourself a reason and motivation to save as well. It is always important to plan for the future and saving for retirement could be a great point to persuade yourself to stay away from excessive spending. 11. Make investments wisely Investment is much more than pure luck. One investment mistake could tear away a large chunk of your assets. So make sure whenever you are making decisions on investments, whether on properties or stock, think twice. It will be better for you to consider opinions from professionals and experts. To give you some ideas, legendary investor Warren Buffett suggested to put 10% of the cash in short-term government bonds and 90% in a very low-cost S&P 500 index fund, so that if the market crash, you will still be fine by cashing the 10% rather than selling the stock with a bad price. Getting Rich the Wise Way There are a lot more important things in life than accumulating wealth. Who wants to end up rich, unloved, lonely and in poor health? However, if you can enjoy a balanced life and at the same time become rich, why not do so? Taking combinations from the above suggestions may not guarantee you a prosperous future, but it will surely eliminate a lot of financial troubles in your life. With one step at a time, maybe you will also become the one you dreamed of.

Avoid debtLive within your meansPick your partner (spouse) carefully and make sure you’re on the same page about money. My initial choice (AKA: Practice Wife) set me back 10 years, but I was able to recover quite nicely (she didn’t).Avoid stupid “investments”, stick to solid mutual funds with 10 year + track records of high returns. I lost around $35,000 in my early 30’s in the dot com bust of 2001… that would be worth over $92,000 (post taxes) in 2019 - DUMB move on my part, but I learned. That was the Bitcoin on the late 90’s… some made money, a whole lot more took it in the back side…Invest every month, 15%… hold on tight when the economy is in the toilet, but KEEP INVESTING… stocks are ON SALE at that point, and your dollars are going a lot farther - things always recover and as you’ll be in mutual funds, the fund managers will be looking to avoid companies that are in bad shape.If you want to get into real estate, do so AFTER the 15% and use cash. It’s slow to start, but use the “no debt snow ball” method to get the first house, then the second… and the third. This approach has you saving to buy your first rental for cash, then keep saving and adding the rental profits for buy the second house (in about 60% of the time as the first), Keep saving and add both rental incomes to buy the 3rd house (about 33% of the time as the first), keep this up… you’re saving the entire time and rolling all the rental profits into the “next house” buying fund. It’s a technique that has so little risk that you’ll be fine AND gives you the ability to pay cash when the economy tanks and homes are cheap.

Warren Buffett was asked “how to becoming rich?” Most expected a reply long & sour, but he kept it short & sweet: “If you don’t find a way to make money while you sleep, you’ll work until you die!”  BECOMING RICH IS A RESULT, NOT A GOAL  I. The SCIENCE of MAKING MONEY  A few weeks ago as my uncle and I cheered for Tiger Woods, my aunt Sandra wasn’t in the least bit interested in making golf putts. Rather, she was more interested in making money! “Nephew,” she mumbled to me, “since you’re supposed to be a ‘genius’ and all, why don’tcha tell your favorite auntie how to become rich?” Inwardly I chuckled. “Sure thing, auntie.” I wrapped an arm around her as we strolled to the kitchen. “Auntie, ever heard of Socrates?” She nodded while saying, “I heard of rocket science too, Nephew, but that don’t mean I know a damn thing about it!” “Well,” I continued, “in ancient times they called Socrates the wisest man in the world.” “So what did he say about making money, Nephew?” I whipped out my phone and leaned on Google for help:  With eyebrows raised she asked, “So what does ‘making money’ mean, then?” Again I leaned on my pal, Google:  Given that example is better than precept, I had just the case in mind. I told my teenage cousin to let me borrow her iPhone 8 Plus. I then jokingly asked my uncle, “Hey, would you be willing to TRADE me your iPhone 6 for this shiny, new iPhone 8? Without blinking he said, “You damn right I will!” I turned to my auntie and said, “Bingo! Now you know why the expression ‘having a job’ is used interchangeably with ‘having a TRADE’.”  Aunt Sandra’s blank expression suggested I needed to fill in the blank. “Auntie, you see, before money became currency, it was first known as the barter system,” I said. “In other words, back in the day one farmer TRADED his bushel of corn for another farmer’s, hmmm, bushel of wheat. Got me? She nodded. “And so, when you ask ‘how do I make money?’ in reality you’re asking ‘how do I make enough TRADES so as to qualify for my definition of rich.’ Naturally she asked, “Well, how do I make these trades, Nephew?” “By simply following Einstein’s advice, auntie!”   II. In CLOSING: The SCIENCE of GETTING RICH DECODED  Long before the word genius got distorted, it had a far simpler meaning. In fact, the original meaning of genius is Latin: “attendant spirit present from one's birth, innate ability or inclination [aka, passion].” Bingo! According to the ancient Romans, then, each person comes into the world stamped with a genius! In the Vedic tradition, this ancient wisdom is known as one’s dharma(धर्म). To put it simply:  To state it simply: the entire economic system was set up for individuals making good on their natural talent (genius) to be compensated by making money. Bingo! You see, in the Game of Life everyone is supposed to bring their special talent to the table and thereby receive their “slice of the pie.” You know: this lady paints in a special way . . . that guy dances in a special way . . . and so on.  Ahhh, but since we’re living in the “real world,” the way the Game of Life is played in real-time was best summed up by Gandhi:  Hey: DON’T HATE THE PLAYERS, HATE THE GAME! And so, given the cards dealt to us all, the Science of Getting Rich boils down to this: Only YOU . . . and you alone can figure out what constitutes your gift, aka your genius potential. For the above reasons, Warren Buffett went so far as to say:  And so, the Science of Getting Rich inevitably poses questions such as the following: Are you one of those people who naturally cracks people up? Are you the person about whom friends and family make comments such as “you sure can argue well . . . should’ve been a lawyer—I tell ya?” Do you naturally sing with a voice so lovely even the hummingbirds stop chirping just to hear you perform live in the shower? What’s your hobby? If money were no object, what would you do for a living? In other words, the Science of Getting Rich boils down to this:  Bingo! In short, aside from lucking up and winning the lottery . . . Or inheriting a fortune from some rich relative . . . Uncovering your God-given genius potential is the only way to guarantee you’ll secure your financial future! Hey, that’s just the way the Game of Life is setup! Mostly, it is about controlling competition through aggregation. The closer you can get to a monopoly or a monopsony on a certain market, the richer you can be. Ideally both at the same time. Creating a bottleneck of sorts in the economy. This is how most of the current, successful businesses work. Let me give you an example: There are many restaurants delivering food, and many customers ordering food. Delivery men work for the restaurant, or for the customer, or can even try to be independent, but wont be rich. Now imagine you create a website to order food. Customers get all the options for food in one place, isnt that great? And restaurants get to sell their food without having to organize delivery, or deal with customers. So at first, you will be losing money. You pay people to make a website (or invest your time) for no financial return. You invest money or energy advertising, etc. After the initial investments, business will start, but probably not be profitable at first. There might be competitors too. You need more advertising, or discounts, or something. You need to invest in a trademark, and patents, and make sure people cant copy you. Maybe fight off some patent trolls, competitors wanting to boot you out, etc. The vast majority of businesses fail around this stage, mostly because of lack of capital. Another large portion gets bought out by competitors. But if there is enough capital, if expenses are low enough, and at some point you can grow, if you can buy out or take out competitors, or if there are none, if at some point you can end up taking a large market share, then you can start to dictate the market, and make huge amounts of profit. If you can end up being the only one, since all restaurants have to go through you, you get to dictate your terms, and since you are the only website available to customers, you can also set your prices there. Even for paying your delivery drivers. Huge profits. Now you can make billions. Amazon is a very similar idea. And so are all sorts of businesses. People search for stuff on the internet. Pages on the internet want to be seen. Google is the bottleneck. Farmers want to sell product, people need to buy stuff, supermarkets are the bottleneck. People want to go someplace for a little money, people want to make a little money driving, uber is the bottleneck. Some people need money, some people have money, banks are the bottleneck. Owners want to sell/rent, people want to buy/rent, real estate companies are the bottleneck. Etc The bottlenecks are completely arbitrary, you can create one wherever you want if you have enough ressources. With enough ressources, you could lobby for a law and create a bottleneck that way. Lets take something simple, like a tomato. If you can own most of the fertile land, you can set your prices when renting it, and make a huge profit that way. If not, you could aggregate all the land owners, and be a renting company, all the owners go through you to rent it to someone. Or you could be a farming company, trying to control most of the farmers in the area. Or a work agency selling farm work to farming companies. Or control the market in seed distribution. Or in fertilizer/pesticides. Or a trucking company. Or market distribution.Or delivery company to your door. At any point, you could create a monopoly or a monopsony, or be part of an oligopoly. And that is how you become rich.

I’m seriously pissed. Because I went through many answers below and there wasn’t a single mention about Naval Ravikant’s amazing twitter threads or “tweetstorms” around this topic. It’s titled, “How to Get Rich (without getting lucky)” You might have gone through several articles, books, videos, and courses about this topic but trust me nothing comes close to how this man puts it together and that too each thought in a tweet—140 words. Let’s begin: How to Get Rich (without getting lucky) by Naval Ravikant Seek wealth, not money or status. Wealth is having assets that earn while you sleep. Money is how we transfer time and wealth. Status is your place in the social hierarchy.Understand that ethical wealth creation is possible. If you secretly despise wealth, it will elude you.Ignore people playing status games. They gain status by attacking people playing wealth creation games.You’re not going to get rich renting out your time. You must own equity - a piece of a business - to gain your financial freedom.You will get rich by giving society what it wants but does not yet know how to get. At scale.Pick an industry where you can play long term games with long term people.The Internet has massively broadened the possible space of careers. Most people haven't figured this out yet.Play iterated games. All the returns in life, whether in wealth, relationships, or knowledge, come from compound interest.Pick business partners with high intelligence, energy, and, above all, integrity.Don't partner with cynics and pessimists. Their beliefs are self-fulfilling.Learn to sell. Learn to build. If you can do both, you will be unstoppable.Arm yourself with specific knowledge, accountability, and leverage.Specific knowledge is the knowledge that you cannot be trained for. If society can train you, it can train someone else, and replace you.Specific knowledge is found by pursuing your genuine curiosity and passion rather than whatever is hot right now.Building specific knowledge will feel like play to you but will look like work to others.When specific knowledge is taught, it’s through apprenticeships, not schools.Specific knowledge is often highly technical or creative. It cannot be outsourced or automated.Embrace accountability, and take business risks under your own name. Society will reward you with responsibility, equity, and leverage.The most accountable people have singular, public, and risky brands: Oprah, Trump, Kanye, Elon.“Give me a lever long enough, and a place to stand, and I will move the earth.” - ArchimedesFortunes require leverage. Business leverage comes from capital, people, and products with no marginal cost of replication (code and media).Capital means money. To raise money, apply your specific knowledge, with accountability, and show resulting good judgment.Labor means people working for you. It's the oldest and most fought-over form of leverage. Labor leverage will impress your parents, but don’t waste your life chasing it.Capital and labor are permissioned leverage. Everyone is chasing capital, but someone has to give it to you. Everyone is trying to lead, but someone has to follow you.Code and media are permissionless leverage. They're the leverage behind the newly rich. You can create software and media that works for you while you sleep.An army of robots is freely available - it's just packed in data centers for heat and space efficiency. Use it.If you can't code, write books and blogs, record videos and podcasts.Leverage is a force multiplier for your judgment.Judgment requires experience but can be built faster by learning foundational skills.There is no skill called “business.” Avoid business magazines and business classes.Study microeconomics, game theory, psychology, persuasion, ethics, mathematics, and computers.Reading is faster than listening. Doing is faster than watching.You should be too busy to “do coffee," while still keeping an uncluttered calendar.Set and enforce an aspirational personal hourly rate. If fixing a problem will save less than your hourly rate, ignore it. If outsourcing a task will cost less than your hourly rate, outsource it.Work as hard as you can. Even though who you work with and what you work on are more important than how hard you work.Become the best in the world at what you do. Keep redefining what you do until this is true.There are no get rich quick schemes. That's just someone else getting rich off you.Apply specific knowledge, with leverage, and eventually, you will get what you deserve.When you're finally wealthy, you'll realize that it wasn't what you were seeking in the first place. But that's for another day. In case you don’t know who Naval Ravikant is. I don't normally answer questions with so many answers, not least because I feel obliged to read what everyone has written first and who has the time and energy (and frankly the mental fortitude required) to read 43 answers about becoming rich? But I was asked to so I thought about it for a bit... My first reaction to this is one that Benjamin Johnson would apparently not approve of - you should re-evaluate what you want from life because "become rich" isn't a particularly good goal. After all, becoming rich isn't easy so the chances are good that you'll fail and even if you succeed you might well find you're not happier as a result. Why put all your efforts into something so clearly misdirected? Try becoming happy instead. And if you can't manage that, maybe try becoming content? Those strike me as being better, albeit hopelessly vague goals too. My second reaction is that without any further details there is little specific advice I can offer. I could take the perfectly reasonable approach Brian Leyde took and just tell you how I made my money but (a) his approach is probably easier and more likely to be successful (b) I've already explained that in Hedge Fund Managers: How do you become a hedge fund manager? What prior experience and qualifications are needed?  so if you want to copy me that's the route and (c) I'm not rich - though see my answer to How do you know if you're rich or, going to be rich?  for my thoughts on that. I could give you what I think is the right advice - working hard is the key factor that you control that determines how successful you are. I would take (and have taken) a hard worker over a more talented one. After all it's not *that* difficult to become moderately rich - How hard is it to become a millionaire? - if you're prepared to put in the work required. But that's so boring! Even with an exclamation mark after it! Who wants to hear they need to work hard? Especially someone who only devoted nine words to the question in the first place. So I'll point out that there is an alternative to working hard Is there no substitute for hard work? Unfortunately I think there's probably a positive correlation between how boring the advice is on this site and how good an idea it is to follow that advice, though I'm sure James Altucher would have other, much better written and far more exciting, things to say about that. I could also give you vague but reasonable sounding advice like Nolan Ross or a more specific answer in a niche area like Lilly Grace but those people have already done that, and there's plenty of useful tidbits already thanks to people like Kendrick Bowman for my thoughts to add much there. ...and I've come to the conclusion that I shouldn't answer questions that already have 43 answers.

The path to getting rich is really pretty simple. You 1) spend less that you make so that you are building up wealth and 2) you find ways to increase your income so that your wealth builds faster. The first criteria is actually far easier than many people realize. If the average person would buy $3000 cars for cash their whole lives and not hold car payments, or eat most meals in, they would generate plenty of free cash flow to have several million dollars at retirement. You can find the analysis for how buying used cars will make you a millionaire here. The second criteria, increasing income, is often done by going to college to get a higher paying job and working one's way up in a company to higher paying jobs. In general, the more money you make for a company, the higher you can be paid, so being able to manage othes pays better than just performing a task yourself. Other people start companies or find side jobs to increase their income. When you work for yourself, your ability to increase your income is only limited to how big a company you can grow and manage well. Note the more people you serve, the more money you make. Another way to increase your income is to invest. By buying assets like stocks and rental buildings, you can increase your income since these assets will generate income for you once you buy them. It is like you're running a business except it is much easier to do. Being able to invest requires that you have some free cash flow available, which goes back to criteria one for growing wealthy. You need to free up cash each month to allow you to invest and it is by steady investing that you become wealthy. Both budgetting and investing are therefore required. If you increase your income but then just spend the extra, you won’t become rich. If you can create a circular loop, where money from your investments are used to buy more assets, you can grow wealth very quickly. Plus, once you set it up, it builds on itself with no more work by you.

Work. And saving your earnings. I’ve been working since I was 15. I grilled sausages for the yearly christmas market in my town.  I sold lemonade all summer long. I got a percentage of whatever I was making.  I was waitressing almost full time when I was getting my high school diploma.    I looked after children.   Waitressed even more.   And worked part-time in a local theatre at both the bar and as a vendor for their tickets.  Many people in my circle couldn’t do what they had wanted because they had no money. I didn’t want to be one of them. I had big dreams. Most of what I had earned enabled me to travel throughout Europe and the US. Some of it I had invested and the rest of it is going to help me finance law school. There’s no way of getting “rich” without putting in the work into gaining your own capital first. I knew there was no one paying anything for me, which served as a huge motivation. People would tell me all the time, “You’re so lucky you get to travel and meet people”, “I could never afford what you’re doing” Yet they didn’t see how many nights and mornings went into building my safety net for travel (and my future study program) whilst going to school full-time. I was busy 24/7. Hard work is behind most people’s wealth. _ EDIT: Thank you so much for all the amazing comments! The attention this post is getting is overwhelming. It’s so nice to see so many people doing the same. Cheers! xx

I’m not a millionaire - but I really like my chances. I’m 28, I do the kind of work I love, and I’ve been accumulating assets for the past five years. I don’t like the term “net worth,” but if we’re talking pure statistics, mine’s significantly higher than the median in my age group. So without any guarantees or assuming I know it all, here are the steps I’ve had to go through to get to where I am.  1. Stop demonizing money and the people who have it. In Germany we have a saying that translates to “money doesn’t stink.” It goes back to the ancient Romans. They collected urine from public toilets for leather tanning. One day, emperor Vespasian put a tax on it and his son called him out on it. He grabbed some of the money, held it under his nose and said: “Does the smell bother you?!” “No,” his son replied, “and yet it’s made of urine.” That’s why today, the saying usually means the opposite: Something’s fishy here. It’s our default setting. I had no idea how limiting this was until I spotted it in myself, even as someone who never considered himself anti-money. Usually, it’s just jealousy in a clever disguise.  Whether you like it or not, you always act somewhat in line with your true beliefs. This whole “what you focus on grows” thing? That’s real. At least on a long enough timeline. Setting up our beliefs to attract money is the most important part. If you want money, just be honest about it. Don’t hide it, don’t sugarcoat it, and don’t tell yourself getting rich the ethical way isn’t possible. As long as you do, you’ll never get anywhere. 2. Stop seeking status. The reason “money is evil” keeps people from getting it is that it’s a status game. You’re so overly concerned with spreading that message and deriving status from it that you have no time or attention left to do things that, well, make money! But there are many other status games that hinder the entrepreneur: Politics. Politics is one big networking and lobbying game to get the right gatekeepers at the right time to kindly move out of the way for you. Who wants to rely on that?Prestige. There’s a quote along the lines of “rich people stay rich by living like they're broke. Broke people stay broke by living like they're rich.” Take apart your finances. Look at every expense. How many are status-driven? How many are necessary? And how many are really good for you?Prominence. Maybe, you’re the funny one in your social group. Maybe, you’re the slacker. The anti-establishment guy or the riot girl. Over time, we become invested in our standing among our peers and want to maintain it.If you seek wealth, status games are a distraction. You have to play money games. 3. Stop rejecting responsibility and start taking it without being asked to. Why did I just say “hinder the entrepreneur?” Because one way or another, you’ll have to become one to make a lot of money. The reason is simple: responsibility. We pay people based on the amount of responsibility they voluntarily take on their shoulders. That’s why an employee will always have limited earning potential: she caps her responsibility. 99% of people’s actions in corporations are moves in a giant shift-the-blame game. Junior employees blame senior employees who blame their boss so they can blame their boss’s boss. And leadership? They hire consultants and point to the next company, where the cycle starts all over again. Saying “I’ll write two articles each week for you” is taking responsibility. Saying “I promise this lemonade will taste good” is taking responsibility. Saying “We’ll deliver the shoes you want for free” is taking responsibility. No responsibility, no wealth. And the world won’t hand it to you. So take it. 4. Stop wasting your leverage and start using your time to build some. The good thing about taking responsibility is that it also comes with leverage. 2,000 years ago, Archimedes said: “Give me a place to stand, and a lever long enough, and I will move the world.” That’s what wealthy people do to this day. They’re thinkers with leverage. I learned this from a man named Naval.  Leverage amplifies your decisions. If you can help one person for $10, but have access to 10,000 people who have the same problem, that’s $100,000. If you can pick a stock that will 3x in value, the more money you can buy of it, the better. And so on. In today’s world, leverage comes in the form of money, labor, the internet, and software. In the beginning, we have zero leverage. No one’s working for us, we have no audience, no product, and very little money. In fact, we often waste the little leverage we have by spending our savings on liabilities, like a car or a house. Don’t! Because up to a certain amount, money is just leverage. No one needs $100 million, but most people can’t live their whole lives on $1 million either. If you never reach the right threshold, it ultimately won’t matter. So when you start out, be tight with your money and use your time to build leverage. Run a podcast, write articles, code little gadgets, rally your friends into offering a service. Whatever costs only time, but gets you precious leverage. 5. Work hard and quit things that don’t work. Time isn’t leverage because it doesn’t multiply anything. So it’s not as valuable. But it’s the most limited resource we have and the one with which we build everything. Therefore, you have to spend a large chunk of your time acquiring leverage. It’s true that what you work on is more important than how much you work, but very few people get rich without hard work. That’s dumb luck and you can’t rely on it. Choose a pace you feel comfortable with and don’t apologize for it. It’s fine if you don’t want to sacrifice your health or friends, but you should also know that it’ll be very hard to become wealthy if you’re constantly obsessed with work-life balance. Most of all, abandon what doesn’t work as fast as you can. If you can’t understand stocks, but get trading forex, do that. If you suck at writing, but look great on video, do that. If you’re bad at coding, but good at talking people into it, do that. And so on. Whatever it is, if it won’t lead to more leverage in a decent time frame, don’t do it. Do all of this long enough and, one day, you’ll be rich.  It’s funny. We think getting rich is about knowing and doing many things and getting lucky. Actually, it’s mostly about unlearning a whole bunch of wealth-rejecting habits. After that, what’s left is rather simple: Taking focused action in a clear direction, all aimed at acquiring leverage and being rewarded exponentially for your good judgment. Stop shunning money. Stop playing status games. Start taking responsibility. Start building leverage. Work hard and drop failures early. To my best knowledge, these are the steps that will make you rich. And I’ll keep doing them until I win.

You went to the supermarket to buy a box blueberries. It’s $3 per box and you buy it. The next day, the price has been increased to $249 per box. Would you buy them? — I don’t think so. On your way to the exit, you hear the telly. There has been a study that proves blueberry can cure cancer. Now, will you buy them for $249? — If you are smart, yes. They are about in-demand with limited supply. That’s how people get rich. Money flows where the demand is more than the supply — You need to increase the demand and the scarcity of your product or service. There are a few ways to do that.  #1 By Increasing Value. From the blueberry's story, you know people pay more when the value of the product/service increases. Whether you in a job or business, focus on increasing the value. How can you provide so much value that people can’t help but pay you more? Make your clients more money, sell a higher-quality product. Only when you serve, you will be rewarded. #2 Money is NOT evil. People have unconscious beliefs about wealth — “Wealthy people are evil” “They take from the poor”. They aren’t true — “Money makes you more of who you are”. If you are a bad person, the money will allow you to do bad things. If you are a good person, the money will allow you to do good things. You aren’t stomping on poor if you earn money the right way i.e. by providing value to people. If your product/service helps more than it takes, you aren’t evil. Not everyone can afford to work but the ones that do change their life. What price-tag would you put to have the business, relationships, or physique you want? What’s the price of being content? — I certainly charge lower than that. I give my clients my all and I get compensated for that highly. I am not bragging, just showing you the universal law of value. #3 Use Money to Make Money. When you make more money you shouldn’t hoard or consume it all. Use that money to bring even more value in the marketplace. — Invest in courses, coaches, books, outsourcing. People will keep paying because you keep adding value. The question should always be, how to provide more? Once you this loop of value going on, you will be swimming in money.

If you want to be rich, do what the rich are doing…and start now. Physical humans are the only ones in all of the universe that believe in lack. Lack doesn’t exist but physical beings have managed to vibrate in a way where they hold themselves apart from the things they want. –Esther Hicks (Teachings of Abraham). We live in a world of abundance; there is abundance of wealth, health, riches, deposits of gold and diamonds… of yet untapped resources… of ideas, and the list goes…ad infinitum. But the question has always been: Why is there poverty in this world? Why is there lack? Why scarcity of basic human needs? The answer is simply because we have been taught to believe in a lie, society has so programmed our minds to believe in scarcity, and this lie-virus has been sweeping through humanity. Truth is, lack doesn’t exist, abundance does. Even the so called recession is a big lie fed upon our subconscious by the so called economist, there is abundance of wealth and riches for anyone who wishes to tap into Universal Source (God). A brief entry into Quantum Physics will help us understand it better… “If you break the solid world down to smaller and tinier components, you will see that what appears to be solid is a dance – a dance of particles and empty spaces. Go to the tiniest of those quantum particles and you discover that it emanated from a source that vibrates so fast that it defies the world of small beginnings and endings. This highest/ fastest source is called Source Energy. We all originated in this vibration and then moved into a world of things, bodies, minds and egos. It was in leaving of this source energy in our minds and bodies that we took on our entire world of problems, illness, scarcities and fears.” Forget all the above mentioned Metaphysics jargons (forgive my lack of modesty), in a nutshell, it means we all came from a source energy (God) that is abundant and vast in resources that is infinitely infinite and cannot be exhausted in a gadzillion years or centuries, and we the physical representations here on earth of that Infinite Source Energy cannot live in anything but abundance. Those who have lacks in their lives do not understand this basic truth, if they do, then they will start to experience the joy of abundance. So what is our job here on planet earth if we are to attract abundance in our lives. We must first believe in abundance of everything we want, think of abundance, speak of abundance always in our lives, take actions that bring  and live in abundance (even if at the moment its not there). Whenever the thought of lack, scarcity or poverty comes our way, we must immediately cast it out and proclame abundance always. Peter Diamandis in his 2012 book, Abundance: the future is better than you think says “History is littered with tales of once-rare resources made plentiful by innovation. The reason is pretty straightforward: scarcity is often contextual. Imagine a giant orange tree packed with fruit. If I pluck all the oranges from the lower branches, I am effectively out of accessible fruit. From my limited perspective, oranges are now scarce. But once someone invents a piece of technology called a ladder, I’ve suddenly got new reach. Problem solved. Technology is a resource-liberating mechanism. It can make the once scarce the now abundant.” Call To Action (CTA): Use the available technology tools to bring abundance to your daily lives. Start today, start now! Ask the Doc - Docotal

Totally agreeing with Howard in writing things down. That’s a must. To younger especially folks, I think we should: SAVE MONEYSAVE MONEYOh and if I missed it, SAVE MONEYNotice I say “We” because I’m learning it myself. Millennials for example, earn to spend, but we have to get back to our old ways for earning to save. The Guardian put it great. Let’s call it the millennial paradox. You’re in your 20s, and suddenly, you’re actually making money. The problem is that something or someone is after every single dollar. You need to pay off your student loans; you need to cover your living costs. You need to save for the short term – the next vacation; an emergency fund – as well as for your retirement. Maybe you’re helping out a family member, as well. The worst of it all is that probably all of these demands on the finite number of dollars you’re making are just as important as each other. And then along comes the Financial Times, with a survey concluding that – tsk, tsk, tsk – millennials are prioritizing short-term spending over long-term saving. According to one calculation, the average 25-year-old should be saving £800 (or about $1,146) a month over the next 40 years, in order to retire at 65 with an annual income of £30,000. We also think logarithmically as humans. Ever heard of the psychophysics of price paradox?  4:30m in, Michael says how the more of something we have, the less of it it means to us. Proportionally, we value money this is not how we should think logically when it comes to using our additive currency of dollars. I’ll give you two more things. The startup methodology, and pitching to investors. If you have a business idea that you want to scale, your 20’s is the time to get your feet wet. Startup Methodology: What I would suggest is to Hypothesize and Test the market to know if your startup is desired in the first place.I suggest making something called a lean canvas. Check this out: LEANSTACK: Lean Startup and Business Model Canvas Tools, Content, and Coaching for Entrepreneurs leanstack.com This website says, A lean canvas is an adaptation of Business Model Canvas by Alexander Osterwalder which Ash Maurya created in the Lean Startup spirit. Lean Canvas promises an actionable and entrepreneur-focused business plan. It focuses on problems, solutions, key metrics and competitive advantages.  The “canvas” movement is part of larger trends in the business world AgileLean startupDecreasing cost of entrySeed investment explosionStartup “hacking”  Yeah so it may help to document how you successfully built your machine, get it down to a science so that it’s replicable! 2. Build it Is it an MVP-only build to prove a point to an investor?Is it already a semi feature-rich MVP?Have you proven proof of concept and want to have a solid architecture that holds a first stage of acquisition?Are you already looking for a website ready to scale?After defining the scope, you need to understand what will be your approach into getting the build done? Are you going to outsource this construction? You can do it via Odesk (oDesk, the world's largest online workplace ) or Fiverr (Get everything you need starting at $5) and it's potential the "lowest short term cost" you might have. Do this short term, because if not, you can get high Technical debt.Are you hiring an agency or temporary contracts to build the startup? Although the cost is higher than above, the access to information and learning from the code that is delivered can be better quality.Are you hiring an in-house technical team? Again, the cost increases as now salaries are in the table but all development is done internally, and control of iterations is not only faster but the learning comes right away.Are you getting a technical co-founder/CTO? Cheapest short term, most expensive long term, and the best value for money.Fortunately, co-founder s are paid in equity so it’s cheaper in terms of instant physical money, but expensive long term in company shares.Unfortunately, can be the most expensive long term because if you get a very valuable business, the equity you granted becomes worth a lot so you paid a lot!It can be cheaper if your company fails. Any equity shared will then be worthless so you only had your time and opportunity cost.Cost matrix:  3.
