You’re going to have to work very hard. First, read ‘How to get rich’ by Felix Dennis. Around the half way point you’ll know if you want to be rich or not. He is very clear on what to expect. Decide what ‘rich’ means, and decide if you will be able to make the ridiculous levels of sacrifice to get there. Work harder than anyone you know. Cultivate a very thick skin because people will be horrible to you on the way up. When you find real friends, do whatever you can to hold on to them. Never lend money to anyone, ever. Decide now to be healthy and strong and love that way. You will need your health. Remember that getting rich is entirely dependent on you making huge sacrifices. Always, always be goal orientated. And remember that you only have a limited amount of time. Practicalities: develop skills the world will need in the future. Watch trends and identify real opportunities. See how you can help people and then scale it up. Focus on finding a product that can sell, not a service. Only think about money until you get to the stage where you don’t have to. Don’t listen to anyone’s advice unless they have actually achieved what you want to achieve. Finally, don’t ever let emotions rule your decisions. If you do, you will fail.

has always been.Today’s 20-somethings and even those in their early 30s came of age in what may have been the worst national real estate market on record since their grandparents were born. Now a major real estate ad company wants to persuade them that it’s high time to take a risk; that it’s time to walk away from paying high rents in some costly markets and pay high prices to buy their own homes.There’s nothing wrong with the mathematics at the heart of the analysis by Trulia: the raw data show that it’s 23% cheaper for a millennial aged 25 to 34 to buy their own home than to rent, based on the fact that they might only be able to afford a 10% down payment and are likely to move every five years or so.The fact that interest rates are near historic lows, while rents are at astronomic levels in many urban areas, also tilts the balance in favor of buying by any objective standard. Trulia argues that the 30-year fixed mortgage rate would have to hit at least 5% to make renting cheaper than buying in Los Angeles, and top 5.1% in New York City (assuming a 10% down payment). While mortgage rates are on the rise, in anticipation that Federal Reserve policymakers will finally begin boosting key central bank interest rates next month, the rate charged on a 30-year mortgage still averages only 3.98%.Trulia is even urging millennials to push the envelope. Buy a house, they suggest, and nosh on ramen noodles to make mortgage payments for a year or so, because after a raise or promotion or two, that new apartment or house in Boston or Seattle will look like a bargain and be a much easier financial burden.But for many Americans, the tradeoff isn’t that easy. And to be blunt, it shouldn’t be. The ideal of home ownership is wonderful – and there are many advantages, not least of them the fact that your mortgage interest payments are tax deductible and your monthly payments help you acquire an asset, rather than assisting your landlord in building his or her wealth. For most Americans, it will end up being the single biggest financial asset.But if you don’t plan carefully, your dream of home ownership can end up as a financial nightmare. Here are the points to ponder.Trulia is arguing that millennials should stretch themselves financially, basing that argument on a hypothesis that may – or may not – be valid: that they can expect their incomes to rise and their personal financial outlook to improve. You’ll need to be ruthlessly honest with yourself: is that likely to be the case with you?More than any other single factor, what anyone wrestling with the buy v rent decision needs to ponder is the extent to which they are stable. That means how stable their job is (and how likely they are to get promotions and raises over the coming years), how stable their relationship or marriage is (is there a risk that they might have to sell the house at a bad time in the market because of a divorce or split?), and how stable their career path is (might they move cities or states to work for a different company or attend graduate school?). If the answers to any of those questions signals doubt – that they might not be committed to staying in that house for the next five or more years – then regardless of what the mathematics says, buying probably isn’t a good idea.That’s because while a house purchase can make sense – even tenuously – when you run the math, it may still not be wise when you examine life circumstances. I learned this lesson firsthand when the house I bought just before my 28th birthday sat unsold for a full year after my employer relocated me to New York to work several years later. I knew when I bought it that I wasn’t committed to staying in Toronto for the rest of my life, but had blithely assumed that I’d always be able to sell it. What I hadn’t counted on was that the timing of my move would coincide with a period in which interest rates doubled; that wiped out every penny of equity and all of my savings – an expensive lesson to learn. A great many homeowners found themselves in precisely the same predicament during the housing crisis: needing to sell because they were relocating, because they were elderly or because they were military families asked to deploy overseas, but unable to find buyers because of the market conditions. So, evaluate your http://circumstances.Be equally honest about your finances. Of course, in some markets where both rents and housing prices are high, the market may impose this discipline on you, making it impossible to save enough for a down payment. (Even Trulia acknowledges that renters and buyers alike are doomed in ultra-tight markets like San Francisco.) But if you’ve got a pristine credit rating and can scrape together a 10% down payment, even banks that have become more disciplined about lending may give you the rope with which to hang yourself in the form of a mortgage.But the costs of home ownership don’t stop with the mortgage. Remember, you’ll also need money to pay property taxes, and the bank that gives you your mortgage will want proof that you’ve got an insurance policy on your new home. When you were renting, there’s a chance that your landlord covered some of your utility expenses: almost certainly he paid a water bill, and possibly either heating or power. Now, all that will be your responsibility. You spot an ominous drip in a ceiling? That’s now your responsibility to fix – quickly, before it becomes a flood. That parade of ants through your kitchen in spring? That’s up to you to control, along with the signs of mice nibbling on the edges of your cereal box in the kitchen cupboard. The refrigerator that you bought along with the house dies, and that’s another expenditure ... and then there’s the time that you invest in mowing the lawn, painting the walls, and so on.You’ll also have to keep putting money into your retirement savings plan, because your house can’t end up being 100% of your nest egg.This might not even be the right time to buy, anyway. Sure, rental prices are high, but chasing housing prices higher is rarely a wise plan. You may feel that houses are becoming less and less available, and less and less affordable, and you’d be right on both counts. Home prices have risen at 13 times the rate of the typical American’s earnings in recent years, which is in part due to the fact that the number of homes available for sale has been running well below the number that realtors say is required for the market to be in balance. Still, it’s rarely a good idea to get involved in a bidding war simply to ensure you’re buying instead of renting.Millennials – and others – who are mulling the renting v buying tradeoff should also ponder some of the long-term market dynamics that will affect the housing market now. If they buy today, with a minimal down payment, they won’t have much of a cushion to protect their primary asset from any erosion in value in the future. And there are at least a few reasons I can think of why such a selloff might occur.First of all, there’s the market itself. We just don’t know what the reaction will be to a rise in interest rates and mortgage rates. Nor do we fully understand how many properties are left over from the financial crisis and the related real estate debacle, that have been repossessed by banks or whose owners still inhabit them but remain in default on their mortgages. Many more of these homes could make their way onto the market in the coming months and years. That probably won’t happen in the most costly urban markets that were least affected by the crash, such as San Francisco or New York, but if you’re looking to buy in, say, Las Vegas, it’s something to bear in mind.Then there are the baby boomers, whose retirement savings fall far, far short of being able to generate an adequate income for their golden years, and whose homes are by far their largest asset. For many, who are approaching retirement in the next five to 10 years, that will mean selling their home – and flooding the market with another wave of properties for sale.And while it’s true that low interest rates are tempting to home buyers, if you’re using those low rates in order to make a costly purchase, that’s problematic. A potentially more alluring scenario might be to continue living, when possible, in a small and inexpensive studio and sock away at least some money in a savings account, and then emerge a few years down the road, able to make a much larger down payment when rivals can’t afford to borrow much at all in a higher rate environment. If you’re borrowing less, your monthly payment might still be the same, but with a big downpayment you’d be a bank’s preferred customer and a seller’s preferred buyer in a competitive bidding situation. Then, too, you’d find that your house appreciates in value as interest rates decline and you’d be able to cut your financing costs as well.We’ve seen what happens when Americans quaff the real estate Kool-Aid. I’m not sure that we can handle a repeat.This article was amended on 15 November to correctly identify the nature of Trulia’s business. It is an online real estate ad company, not a realtor

Without showing private sector as an option Govt should take responsibility for the livelihood and income of its citizens and provide permanent oppurtunities even for illiterates. Now where does the govt get funds from for that lets understand debt and budget of economy. Debt -is it private or govt.  When you can print then ideally govt shouldn't have any debt it gets cleared yearly.  Regarding private companies taking loans and debt then if it is external private debt and there is bilateral issue between nations then the govt pays the external private debt and recovers locally from the company   The formula is very simple in this way you get into no or zero debt. It is as follows  On a yearly basis findout previous years debt and current years requirement of funds or fiscal deficit and the total should be minused from the revenue earned and the remaining balance of requirement of funds should be printed .  Now here there is a trick you can borrow a lot of funds but that is not advisable because you would get into debt trap so instead what happens to the deposits in banks and private lenders interested in lending,the govt provides reasonable interests to these funds as expenditure to it but does not use the funds because it has to payback.  As mentioned by the above formula without getting into debt trap you have print currency as per the requirement.  Now some of them say this may lead to inflation.which is wrong .Inflation is the increase in the price of a goods or services on a year on year basis.This can be controlled.The govt has to provide subsidy or inflationary allowance to businesses on a year on year basis to stabilise prices and this increases the value of currency in terms of purchasing power .  Now there is a private companies gimmick if more cash is circulating in the market then the lending rates would go down but the govt ensures reasonable interest rates to the private lenders and people can borrow at a lesser rate from the govt.  So as per the above formula printing of currency has nothing to do with inflation or prices or quantity of goods and services produced.  In common world scenario whether it is private business or personal finance multiplying wealth is thought as a very intelligent or clever thing and it is a challenging task.This individualistic perception comparing or equating to government is wrong.  Remember my friend dont get into business mindset it is tricky and deceiting because it always looks for profits which is not wrong but remember Government is not a business, it is responsible for the careers and lifes of the people so it owns and has money and need not worry about profit /loss because its an expenditure to the public which is genuine and legitimate  So ideally at the start of the year the country has no debt…if there is it could be private debt otherwise number game played by politicians to coverup under development blaming the debt and remember if we clear the debt early then you dont have to pay interest hence cause of worry for private lenders.

There is no formula for success, but there are things which many successful people have in common. Follow your passion. Not only because it will be something you know a lot about, but that energy will pull you through when things get tough.Take risks. But ONLY with things you know a lot about. Anything else is called taking chances.Make a life plan. Translate your dreams into targets. Then be honest about where you are today and what it will take to achieve your goals. Get clear on the tasks which will move you towards your target. If this involves sacrifice, hard work, retraining, facing your fears, so be it. Then focus ONLY on this roadmap. Don’t waste time or energy on distractions. As Steve Jobs said, focus is not about saying yes, its about saying no.Understand the compound effect. In England we have a saying, ‘look after the pennies and the pounds will look after themselves’. Be very clear that small things count enormously over time. Darren Hardy showed that the real cost of a $4 a day coffee adds up to $51,833 over only 20 years. The good news however, is that this effect also works for the small improvements you add to your daily rituals too.Understand the difference between debt and leverage. Debt is borrowing without a plan. Leverage is borrowing against a plan.Believe in yourself. Learn to keep your own counsel. If you need help or advice ask for it, but ask people who are positioned to give it, not people who don’t understand.Don’t give up. The difference between winners and the rest is not just talent, it’s about hard work, focus, determination and resilience.Get up and work hard on your mission every day. It adds up. It adds up exponentially in terms of output, experience, contacts and results. Just do it. Keep doing it. Leap and the net will appear.Know your subject. Yes, getting rich IS about LUCK. Luck stands for Labour, Under Correct Knowledge. This means work and effort which is made effective by expertise.Be generous. Give. Give of your time, your respect and your effort, to people who deserve it. This stops scarcity mentality and it signals to the universe that you are not keeping score. In any case, we teach best that which we most need to learn.Don’t get daunted by your dreams. Anything is possible if you break it down into small, sequential tasks. If I ever get a bit phased by any of my own intentions, I bring to mind Michel Lotito, the Frenchman who ate a Cessna 150 aircraft. (I learnt to fly in one of those and consider it no loss). How did he do it? It took two years. One tiny piece at a time.

You don’t have “nothing”? Yes you do. You a functioning body with a brain in it. There are tons of millionaires who have started just that. You add to that hard work and perseverance and you have a winning combination. There is a large pizza chain here in the middle Atlantic states. The founder came here from Naples with a suitcase. He worked in Italian restaurants saving his money and gaining skills. He final was able put together a down payment open his own shop. One day a sign went up he was going to close for a week for renovations. He put a hole in the wall and opened the first drive through pizzeria. Now there are over 60 shops. How about a black kid born without arms. Doomed to failure right? He is one of the top NASCAR engineers in the country. He has a baccalaureate and master’s degrees from Clemson University in mechanical engineering and entrepreneurship, He repairs his own 1963 Impala and his 1955 Nomad.  Uses his smart phone  Jobs, Gates, Zuckerburg in about 30 years have gone from college students to some of the worlds richest people. That is the blessing of the United States is anyone can be anything they want.

By no means am I, or my family rich. There will be many suggestions, many by people who made it. But I will say this, both me, and my wife are veteran entrepreneurs, and currently working on 3 separate businesses; 2 of which are in rapid growth phases, 1 still nurturing. Here are some things to consider on the path to “rich”. Forget about the word rich. Professional athletes, lotto winners, trust fund babies are “rich". Focus on generating passive “wealth". Example, a plumber, who can hire multiple other plumbers and apprentices, who then has free time to do other ventures, and develops a multi-million dollar real estate portfolio…is wealthy. I use that example because I just meet one the other day.Prepare to work for free. The adage…”pay yourself first.” Doesnt mean depositing money into “your" bank account. But into what is growing your business. My wife, her partner, and me haven't collected a single penny in personal pay from our businesses for 6 months. But we now have expanded into a space that is exceeding all expectations, and is poised to make us “wealthy". We paid “ourselves” first…aka, first rate accountant, retained top employees, best equipment etc etc.Prepare to lose friends. The road to wealthy is lonely, accept it, embrace it, move on. I'm not saying you'll become an asshole. But when you haven't collected a single paycheck in 6 months, you just cut a check to your accountant for his retainer, fired an employee who is also a friend etc etc…and because of that the utility company is threatening to shut off the power to your home…then your friend complains about you being late for a dinner…yeah…a disconnect between priorities.Find your B.H.A.G, and jump into it. It stands for B. Big, H. Hairy, A. Audacious, G.Goal. When you've seemingly found the business or idea for wealthy, make a goal that keeps you up at night. For it's shear audacity. If you're not think “what the #$%& am I thinking”, it's not big enough. Never underestimate fear and desire as a renewable power source to drive you during the rough times.Enjoy the f###ing journey. Regardless of your success, your embarking on a journey that few take. Fewer will succeed, but if you enjoy it, it'll be a more enriching experience.Good journey to you! Sorry…one more, Find a mentor, use them, heed their advice, respect their advice.

Why fill your bucket? Money isn’t real — it’s a human construct that helps us facilitate exchanges of value in a more convenient manner. In and of itself money is only worth as much as what we can do with it. Given that, why do you want to get rich? Is it to look good in front of others? Is it to feel secure about your future? Is it because it represents your self worth? Without knowing the motivation behind why you want more money, that you’ll be under money’s control rather than the other way around.How big is your bucket?. Richness is relative. Where $10k USD is a pittance for Bill Gates, it’s a fortune for those who live in poverty. Know what your number is. Do you want $100k? $1m? $10m? Starting with our “why” gives us motivation to work towards a target, but we must define a target to know whether we’ve “filled the bucket”.How much do you have in your bucket?. With a target in mind, it’s time to understand where you currently are. How much money do you have in the bank? What do you owe? What will you need to spend on? Only by knowing how big our bucket is and how much of it is already filled can know we what we’re missing.Plug the leaky bucket. We already know that the bucket is getting filled every month, but how is it leaving? Given our needs, we’ll always have “holes” in our bucket for food, rent, transportation etc. but could you reduce the size of those holes by eating cheaper or even eliminate some holes like by giving up cigarettes? Just like how we wouldn’t drink water from a leaky cup and expect to quench our thirst, we can’t live a “leaky” life and expect to become rich.Actively fill the bucket. Plugged up the extra holes in your bucket? Now it’s time to figure out how you can fill it up faster. Could you…get a raise? Start a side-hustle? The key here is understanding the way for you to get your bucket filled faster is delivering more value to others and ensuring they recognize that.Passively fill the bucket. As good as it is for you to fill your own bucket, it’s important to recognize that you only have 24 hours in a day and to fill up your bucket faster you’ll need help which means you’ll be outsourcing your bucket filling. You can do this either by owning a company where employees deliver value to customers and your bucket gets filled as a result of profit or by owning stocks and bonds that deliver additional cash to your bucket. Either way the key here is that you’re not trading time for money and that this can be scalable in the long run.Separate your buckets. As you fill up your bucket there’ll be so many opportunities to create new holes in your bucket whether it’s to have a better lifestyle, buy something fancy or simply because you think you deserve it. That’s why you’ll eventually need bucket with no holes that will sit there and continue to collect cash for you. Keep this separate to your daily spending bucket and watch as over time your bucket overflows!

Here is the business plan Title: STREET FOOD : PANI PURI Location (assumptions) — Near girl's college Business: Street cart selling of Pani puri / Bhel puri (run by women)  Here is a SWOT analysis STRENGTHS The food-cart will be operated by two women employees. People say you can't become rich fast, that’s because they failed to do so. We always hear things about people becoming rich overnight, and if they can do it, then you can do it too. The key is not believe in yourself or be persistent (it’s definitely helpful but not the key) The key is to seek for opportunity. When the tablets first went popular, everybody thought it should cost hundreds of dollars. however, in some Asian factories, the price of an android tablet can be as low as $30, many people bought them and resold on eBay and took more than 10 or even 20 times of profit. You see, most people didn’t see the opportunity, because once they saw the price, they believed in it. If they have asked themselves, “Does it actually worth that much?” or “where can I get it cheaper?” they’ve probably found a new opportunity. Sometimes a question is all it takes to find a opportunity. It’s not impossible, not even difficult, but you have to keep an open mind. The path of becoming rich is the process of find more and more opportunities. Working hard can't make you rich, because it is something that everybody could do. Finding opportunities can make you rich, because most people doesn't even bother to look for them.

I answered this from another question, What are some of the legit ways of getting very rich before I turn 30?, but I'll try to sum it up. I'm assuming that by "What is the good way..." you mean "What is the best chance I have..." I'm taking the stance that you're being altruistic and want to do this legally. First and foremost, it's to get rid of any bad debt you may have. Debt such as a mortgage, particularly on investment property that produces income, don't really count. 1. Have confidence. By this, I mean that you need to imagine yourself as already having achieved what you want. If that means that you need to write it down every single day, do it. If it means you just need to say it in the mirror a few times a day, do it. You'll find out what works best for you. 2.  You need to plan out your life. Set long-term, medium-term, and short-term goals. Once you have those, break them down into finer and finer components, until it's impossible for you to break them down any further. 3. Save your money. Always save as much of it as you can, and don't EVER touch the savings, no matter what, unless you have a true emergency. Always find ways around touching that money. If it means you skip out on a night with your buddies or have to eat at home when you wanted to eat out, so be it. Every time you get paid, set aside as much of a chunk of that money as you can. 10% is a good rule of thumb, but if you can do 50%, go for it. Watch how quickly it will multiply. 4. What are your interests? Is there something you're better at than anyone else? Do you enjoy it? If the answer is "no" to any of these questions, re-evaluate yourself, and dig deep. Even if your answer to the second question keeps coming up as a "no", there is probably a unique combination of things you enjoy that you can merge together, and be exceedingly good at them. Now your next step is to figure out if there is a way to monetize those things. If not, you can always repeat this step. These are a few things you can do. If you follow them, you'll be on the right path to having the right mindset for getting rich. It's a slow process, but having goals will speed it up immensely. Read more here: http://millionaireby30blog.wordpress.com/

The most important first step is to always live below your means. In other words live on 90% of your income or less. That may seem hard but there is someone who makes 90% of what you do and gets along fine. The second step is to invest your savings wisely. Stocks and real estate are the two best ways. Your own business is a third but has more risk. Lots of business owners make less than they could working for someone else. As an example, someone who starts at age 25 and invests $ 100.00 a week into the stock market can expect to retire with 1.2 million dollars. Lots of people tend to spend 105% of what they make. If they get a raise they will quickly find a way to spend it. Something I read on a Facebook post this morning went something like this: Rich people are rich because they live like they are poor.Poor people are poor because they live like they are rich. Warren Buffet still lives in the house he bought 60 years ago for around 60 grand.H. L. Hunt drove a beat up old pickup truck until the wheels fell of it.

One of the ways to be rich is to stop spending more money going out than coming in. Take at least 10–15% of your paycheck and always pay yourself first. Put it into an interest yielding account. I know this sounds like old school because it is time tested. Next start a plan to pay off your credit cards (or any debts). I know this seems like stating the obvious but you have to get to a point first where you pay off your credit cards and smaller debts so that you are not paying high interest rates each month. You start with the highest paying interest ratecard and work your way down till they are paid off. Pay the minimum on the rest but do not spend any money on those cards. The goal here is to establish yourself so you are your own bank. Have a couple thousand dollars saved in terms of emergency funds. Have a separate account that you agree to make deposits you will never ever touch that yields interest. Goal is to have 2–3 thousand in emergency funds you can replenish. Then save 10,000 to 20,000 in the other account (minimum). Once you have that targeted amount saved up. you can open up a mutual fund or Roth IRA. Learn the differences. You can start investing in stocks too. Again the goal here is to save no matter what and get your saved money into investments that will in the long term yield a ROI (return on investment). Stsrt investing in real estate, tech, health stocks and some trends whatever you do just make sure you diversify your portfolio (for either short or long term using investment growth strategies ). Obviously work with a professional organization that is reputable who handles stock, investments, etc. Maintain this diversified portfolio and keep you savings pattern. Again the goal here is to keep more money coming in than spending it. In 10, 15, 20 years if you continue this trend diversifying and saving you will be comfortably rich. You can also at any point invest your money in a startup or real estate deals as you accumulate your nest egg. I am not a financial consultant. I just come from a poor family that became rich because we did these things. And my grandfather left a legacy we continue. I also learned from and researched a lot of rich people to learn what their habits are as an adult. And they continue to live well but modestly because they know the value of saving money and having financial freedom in the long run.

What are some ways to start a business? Brands, Businesses, Companies have come a long way since they began as a way to tell one person's cattle from another. Before we discuss the steps of how to find your perfect brand name and start your new business, we first need to understand what a brand is and what are the characteristics of a good brand. What is a brand? A brand is the personality that identifies a product or service. What characteristics does a good brand name have? Memorable and easy to pronounce. No more than 2 or 3 syllables. The name should relate to your business. Avoid using initials or abbreviations. You want your name to communicate to your customers. A good brand hints at it without directly saying it. Brand name should be unique. Many brand names are made of combining two words to make a new word. Brand name should appeal to your target customer 6 Steps to finding the perfect brand name: Finding the perfect name can feel like a huge and daunting task, but if you break down it down into steps in a process it will feel much easier to accomplish. 1) Brainstorm & Lists When I begin to come up with possible company or brand names, I start by brainstorming. For example if my company was a travel company in San Francisco. I would start by writing down all the words that relate to travel and then all the words that relate to San Francisco. Then I would write a third list of all the words I would like associated with the name and what the company should be known for. 2) Thesaurus & Google Image Once I have a list of words, I add to that list by looking online in Thesaurus.com - The world's favorite online thesaurus! - The world's favorite online thesaurus! - The world's favorite online thesaurus! for others similar words. This will double your list and increase your chance of finding more interesting words you may not have thought of. In addition. I will type in some of these words into Google and look under images. I use this to generate more ideas about the name concept. Sometimes an image, will give you an idea or a word you hadn't thought of. 3) Mix & Match Once you have these lists you can start putting words together. It's a bit daunting at first, but keep trying to put words together. Be sure to keep the name short and simple. This step will take a bit of time, as you go back and forth between this step and steps 1 and 2. 4) Web domain name Once I have narrowed the list down to some of my favorites, I usually like to see what my website possibilities will be with the name. This also helps me see what names are already being used. I usually go to Make Your Own Way | GoDaddy to check the availability of the domain name. This will narrow down your list significantly. 5) Favorites list & getting feedback With my short list of my favorite names, I ask for feedback from friends and colleagues to see which names resonate. You can also post it on a forum, like LinkedIn or Facebook or maybe a forum specific to your line of business. Depending on the project, I may prefer to keep it a bit of a secret and keep it among trusted friends and colleagues. 6) Legality Lastly once you have your name or names, you will need to be sure it is legally available. Check with your local county to be sure your business name isn't the same as that of an existing corporation, LLC, or limited partnership in your state. Finding a good brand name takes time and hours of hard work, but having a process to follow will make it easier. Often I find I have to revisit previous steps in the process. However with continued effort you will find the right name and when you do you will not only have a brand that attracts your customers, but a brand name you will be proud of.

As author Thomas C. Corley found in his multi-year study of self-made millionaires, the rich "do not rely on one singular source of income," he writes in "Change Your Habits, Change Your Life." In fact, "65% had at least three streams of income that they created prior to making their first million dollars," Corley says, such as real-estate rentals, a side hustle or a part-time job. Once you start bringing home two paychecks, try Jay Leno's strategy: Save the bigger of the two checks and live on the other. It not only frees up more cash that you can save and invest, but it helps prevent lifestyle inflation, which is when you increase your spending as your income increases. Save to invest "Investing money is how you will get super rich," says self-made millionaire Grant Cardone. "The only reason to save money is to one day invest money." The only reason to save money is to one day invest money. Grant Cardone SELF-MADE MILLIONAIRE In fact, how much you save and invest is often more important than the size of your paycheck, says personal finance expert Ramit Sethi. "On average, millionaires invest 20% of their household income each year. Their wealth isn't measured by the amount they make each year, but by how they've saved and invested over time," he writes in his book, "I Will Teach You to Be Rich." Ready to put your money to work? Read this investing guide for beginners. Automate your finances Once you've committed to investing your money, the easiest way to stick with it over time is to make good spending/shopping decisions . Set up a regular transfer so that money from your paycheck is sent to your savings or investment accounts every month, before you even see it. Say one of your 2020 goals is to put $2,000 into an emergency fund. Start by figuring out how much you'd have to save per paycheck over the course of the year to reach that goal. Then set up an automatic transfer so you move that amount from your checking account to your savings each time you get paid. If you have even bigger wealth goals, automation can help get you there, too. It helped one millennial, Grant Sabatier, save over half his income and eventually become a millionaire. "Automation is essential," he tells CNBC Make It. "When I first started saving and investing, I was a little more old school — I was trying to invest as much as possible into the online savings accounts I had set up, and it was a pretty manual process. Now, one of the biggest recommendations I make is to automate as much of your savings as possible." Build relationships with successful people Your community matters. It can even affect your net worth, says self-made millionaire and author Steve Siebold: "In most cases, your net worth mirrors the level of your closest friends. … We become like the people we associate with, and that's why winners are attracted to winners." We become like the people we associate with, and that's why winners are attracted to winners. Steve Siebold Coreley agrees: "Wealthy, successful people are very particular about who they associate with," he writes. "Their goal is to develop relationships with other success-minded individuals." If you don't have highly motivated people in your network, Corley suggests joining groups for people who share your same career goals or personal interests. Think big If you set your expectations exceptionally high and are up for any challenge, you're on the right track. After all, "no one would ever strike it rich and live their dreams without huge expectations," Siebold writes. Investing in Equity, Mutual Funds etc. will get you nowhere. It will take you decades and more to finally to MAYBE save enough money to retire peacefully. So use leverage. If you are familiar with compounding, you’ll understand how important leverage is. In short: Using Leverage can get you 20 years worth of gains in 2 years. Imagine what you could do in 20. Of course that also multiplies the risk. But I could not work for 40 more years in a shitty job for the rest of my life just so one day I might not have to work anymore. I took some extra risks, so improve the quality of my life. When you have enough money coming in passively that pays for all your expenses and more, you can call yourself financially free. What I did was, along with my job, the extra money I was saving, Instead of investing it in stocks or mutual funds or other slow ways,  I used leverage, and put in my money in my side hustle. I had 3 side hustles. #1 Small Businesses like Food and Tea stalls. #2 Flipping Real Estate #3 Swing Trading Back when I was 20, I had Rs 20,000 in savings every month, I used that to build my credit score because I had no credit score. I made 2 credit cards just to build to score, so I can qualify for cheaper mortgage rate. Along with my day job, every minute I could spare, would go into my business. My sleep schedule was a mess, but it was all worth it because I could see the light at the end of the tunnel! I kept at it for 2 years. Meanwhile I was setting up my small stalls across the city that were generating phenomenal returns. Reinvesting that money, letting it compound, expanding, taking extra risks for extra returns! That’s how wealth is made. That is how one can get rich. TLDR: Get a side hustle. Keep reinvesting back into the business. Let it sit and compound. How to Get Rich: If you’re reading this, the assumption is that you aren't currently and you hope to change that one day. I have good news, although it’s not easy, it is possible. To begin, you have to put making AND SAVING money at the very top of your priorities. I’ll clarify my point: If you aren’t rich, the only way to become rich is to make money and not spend it. Even people who inherited great fortunes (land, homes, businesses) owe it to someone in their family deciding to save some of their money and using it to invest in assets. Here is some very exciting news if you’re young. (When I say young I mean 18–25) If you start saving $100/ week in an IRA (only $5,200 per year) RIGHT NOW, I can tell you with near certainty that you will have $1,000,000 or more by the time you’re 60. Google it. Investing in an IRA every week until you’re 60 will push you into the ranks of the millionaires, if you consider millionaire rich congratulations! You’ve made it. If not, read on… Saving/ investing over the course of your entire life is not attractive to you. Maybe because (a) you want more money or because (b) you want it faster How can you get to $1,000,000 before you’re an old fart? How can you make excess of $1,000,000? I’ll tell you it is no easy task. You can search the internet for answers and you will find HUNDREDS of gurus who say they know. The first thing you’ll want to do is avoid anyone who makes money by teaching others how to make money. This is usually a scheme. The person is usually making more from teaching than for the thing they are teaching you to do. That said— online coaching/ consulting can be lucrative. In general, however if you want to create big money quickly, you need to create a product or offer a widely-needed service. The products that make the most money for their creators are typically products that solve a problems for others. If you can identify a problem and create the solution for it, you are well on your way to generating massive income. This process is called innovation. Think about products you use everyday and learn how they came about. The beauty of innovation is that once you identify a problem and solve it, you have something that people will pay money for. If you can create a system so that people can continually purchase your product, you can make money while you devote your time to other lucrative projects. This is a perfect Segway to one of the last keys to becoming “rich”. The rich have multiple streams of income. The rich make money by buying businesses that are fully operational and profitable. They copy and paste this process over and over. The result is enormous sums of cash flowing into their accounts month after month. After years of repeating this process, they have EXCESS cash and it is with all of this excess cash that the rich buy luxuries that make you want to be them.

You have to set rules to live by more than living by rules set by others. You will find that there are no level playing fields and it is difficult to keep your integrity when others don't play fair. Don't drop to their level. Your reputation is something that is difficult to build but easy to destroy. I live by principles some may call them rules: Wake up early. This is key. I wake up at 6am, pray and then meditate to review my prior day and plan my new one. I check futures for equity trading, read business and news headlines, quick check of emails and put my daily schedule together prioritizing it using the Eisenhower Matrix. I start with a few simple things to build momentum as described in Law of Momentum. I workout doing weight and cardio it gets the energy level up for the entire day. Afterwards I eat a good breakfast with a protein drink. I get important decisions made while no one is calling and there are no interruptions. When the day begins I am focused and energized. The top two answers to this question should be, in order: Become financially competent, don’t waste money, try to spend as little money as possible following the principal to ‘spend money primarily to make money or lose less’ and invest in things you understand. Monitor your finances very carefully, identify leaks and maximize is making money. Be willing to work hard, but work at something that can be multiplied such as a product with mass sales potential (especially to a military or government) or a system that can be multiplied (such as a restaurant franchise or multiple location business like a mailbox service or delivery service) or things that very easily expand such as intellectual property (music, games, books, tv / film, apps) and then focus on selling them. Eliminate whatever doesn’t work. You could also hypothetically purchase and sell patents.Do what you love and learn how to make it a business and put every breath in your soul into it, that way even if you fail (and there’s a lot of luck involved) you will still be doing something you love. That’s true wealth.

See here is the problem. People all want to get rich but this usually means some will win and lose in a zero-sum game. Some people will have more of something than others. Some people will have more customers than others. This may create anti-social behavior as some people may not want to share things with others. The truth is that we are supposed to be as efficient as possible, meaning least cost for greatest value. This means people will be expected to do more for less! This is the irony of trying to get rich (rich meaning inefficient or doing less for greater cost). To get business we have to do more for less but this means becoming poorer, not richer. So we want to be rich but are expected to be poorer to get business. This is the irony of capitalism! It might also be a paradox, where people or workers have to be poorer in order to be profitable. Being profitable is a way to create wealth but unless you have a good product or service to sell then this may not work too well. The formula to use I think is: (price - cost) * quantity sold. As you can see in the formula, if your price is not higher than the cost of the product or service then you won't become wealthier or richer. So it's important to make sure the price is higher than the cost. However, certain factors may cause price to go down (competitors, lack of demand in marketplace) and costs to go up (workers want higher pay, raw materials prices go up), meaning becoming less profitable. Being a monopoly means you can sometimes better control these factors. Basically, you want to try to maximize price and minimize cost while maximizing quantity sold. This is a way to get wealthy, but there are factors that can make this not happen or happen less so (business competitors tend to make price go down by perhaps offering something better for the same price, workers demanding higher wages tends to make costs go up, and less customer demand makes quantity sold go down). To get wealthier you need to increase this value (price-cost) and/or increase quantity sold. And if (price-cost) becomes negative and quantity sold becomes less, then this means becoming less profitable or becoming poorer. When (price-cost) is equal to zero (when price=cost) then you break-even meaning you don’t make a profit or a loss. Ironically, it may be that people are more desired being poorer than wealthy by others, because this may mean they are less powerful and will work for less. Workers are the cost to a business and so this tends to want to get minimized. Price is what is charged to the customer and tends to be higher than cost and maximized but factors can affect the price causing it to go down by competitors or lower customer demand or to go up by minimizing supply to demand. The business owner gets the profits (price-cost)* quantity, while the worker just gets their wage (cost to the business owner). The risk to the business owner is when (price-cost) becomes zero or negative as this means no profits are generated or worse that it will make the business owner poorer. So it’s important to try or hope that price is somehow greater than cost. The best way is perhaps socialism where the wealth is divided evenly or more fairly. I have suggested an equal pay for every worker regardless of job (so doctors would make the same as nurses or janitors or teachers), but profits would be shared unequally based on production so this would reward those who did more or a better job than others, encouraging productivity and higher quality. An equal pay would also make it easier to determine who was better for a position since pay is equal (or a variable that is held constant), and people would pick a job based on ability and preference rather than its pay. A Universal Basic Income (funded by a sales tax rather than an income tax) would also be good as this would help people who were elderly, unemployed, or disabled.

We pay a doctor because we cant fix ourselves, reason why a doctor gets paid more because they have a good demand while the supply is really low. So how do you become rich? Become an expert in one of the most in-demand skill and be valuable to your employers or customers. How do you become an expert? Read a ton of books related to your domain. Its quite interesting that we used to wake up early in the morning to study for our exams but as soon as we get employed most of us stop learning. When you read books across multiple domains it has a multiplying effect and leads to a combination of ideas. Here is an example how it works: Lets say you are an Android developer and you read books on finance as well. That will give you an idea to make a finance based Android application. I was an average student when in college, but due to a continuous effort at learning new things I am now in a position where I earn 10X as compared to my class toppers. I still invest a good amount of time & money in reading & upgrading my skills and the return on investment is at least a 1000X for me. There are a thousand ways to get rich and they differ in every country and trade. But what is common between all the paths to obtaining riches is, creating a plan. If you cant find any, you will have to move to another area, city or even another country like I did. You can always return home, when you have reached your goals, but you may never reach your goals where you are today. Don't be intimidated by moving. Once you have found examples of how it is done, spend time to study exactly the steps involved, understand the risks, the difficulties, the time involved. You need to be actively working in that exact industry. Then you can start to craft your strategy to achieve the same goal. Here are the exact steps I took. Joe McCracken's answer to What is the most effective yet efficient way to get rich? It took many years, but it worked and I have seen others, similar to me do the same. Start with a plan that covers all outcomes, you will then know what to do when something unexpected happens. Without a plan, time will just drift away and other events will distract you. Before you know it, it will be too late in your life to start. Make a positive decision and do something about it today.

Don’t believe what others say about working. You do NOT become rich by working hard! (wish someone had told me that 30 years ago!) I have worked by back side for 30 years and haven't come close to becoming rich (sure - I am comfortably off where I currently am, but I am nowhere close to calling myself rich)! The only difference is, I don't want to be rich if it means living a lousy life like some stock broker or banker who eats junk every day. Sure - I would like to be rich, I hope I will be reasonably well off some day, I’ll probably continue to work (though not that hard! - hard work does not make one rich!), but I definitely want more to be a sensible humane person with sufficient money in the pocket for the good things in life (good food, a comfortable home, sufficient money for the small hobbies that I have, and the discrimination to indulge in good things and listen to wise people / read good books). PS - about some people talking about travel and work - I traveled on work to 40+ countries on company tab as part of my work. Sure, I enjoyed it, and you will if you are 30 or 40 - but its charm fades. You don't become rich just because you work and travel to interesting places! PS2 - Being rich is over rated. Being comfortably off is under rated.

Ken Fisher wrote a good book on how to become rich, worth a read. If you are not lucky in business or trading, then it take a long time. You need a large income, if you buy 20 income properties a year for 20 years; you might make $40 million or more. But, income properties often cost $20k to buy a property that pays $10 a month. That may be worth it in 30 years when it’s paid off, but only if you make $600k a year after taxes and invest 2/3. If you can buy property worth $150k for $100k and some quick improvements, you can buy them all day long as long as the rent pays the expenses; but these are not as common as 30 years ago (they always took skill to find, it’s harder now.) I’d say the lessons I learned by not doing them would be get a job with a good income and focus on 1 project at a time (only doing 1 project, outside of your job at work; until you are done or it fails and you give up.)

In a word: leverage. Quick point of reference is that you can be rich but not wealthy and you can be wealthy but not rich and you can be both. Rich is having money, regardless of income or time. A lottery winner is rich (probably temporarily). A pro athlete is rich. Wealth is having an income regardless of your actions. A recording artist can be wealthy as they get residuals on their music. A landlord is wealthy as he/she collects rent. A business owner with multiple locations tends to be wealthy. Trading hours or work for income is never wealthy. Wealth is non-energy income. Once it is built, it keeps the money flowing. To become wealthy you need to leverage your idea(s) and/or skills. Investment in people is the ultimate wealth builder. However, it also is risky. Maybe you start a business with the intent to create residual income. Maybe you invest in someone else’s idea to gain a part of that income. Maybe you leverage you talent or skill (writing, recording, programming, coding, etc). Any plan you implement needs to have a roadmap to gaining you residual income either by performance (stocks, biz) or market (art, goods/services sold). There are hundreds of books and videos and thousands of methods. You need to find what works for you. Just don’t trade hours for income as a wealth building vehicle. It is great for starting out or bill paying, but in and of itself, not a wealth builder.

The key is in the definition of wealth. If you can make sure your basic needs are met, that your need for laughter and play are met and can you give of your time and energy to others you have wealth. And you can live in poverty and do this. I know people who live on $10K a year and are wealthy. Their lives are set up so that they make their own food, use solar, make or trade for things and their expenses are low. They spend half their time in service to others or in play. They are very happy and consider themselves wealthy. They accept their good and bad luck equally, they know that physical pain can be part of life. They tend to flow.I know plenty of execs who have plenty of money and don’t feel or would label themselves as wealthy. They don’t sleep well, they fight what is and I wouldn’t call them wealthy either. The Dali Llama said that the United States was the poorest country had been to and India the wealthiest. In India they may not have access to what other countries do but they have an infrastructure where needs are met and joy and celebration is created on the regular. When you are in the same living conditions as those around you, it’s easier to feel happy and wealthy with your needs met, than if you are around others in higher standards of living leaving you to feel like a victim.So wealth is very dependent on where you live and what you have access to. Maslow’s Hierchy of Needs works so far in most all living situations to describe wealth and happiness.

With the remaining nine-tenth of your earnings, make your budget for necessary expenses. But remember this: what we call our necessary expenses will always grow to equal our income unless we practice self control. Try to cover your necessities, enjoyments and your worthwhile desires within the ninth-tenths part of your earnings. I have prepared a graph for easy understanding. You can see below, if you set aside mere Rs.5000 every month for a year then you will be richer by 50,000 Rupees than you are today.  Now what to do with this money? 2 Make Your Savings Multiply Through Investing These savings we build from our earnings are just a start. Standalone, they are not helpful. But if you invest them at right place with adequate knowledge then you will get returns in unprecedented amount. Following aphorism was found written on a clay tablet in the ruins of Babylon: “A man’s wealth is not in the coins he carries in his purse; it is the income he builds, the golden stream that continuously flows into his purse and keeps it always bulging. However when you get returns, be sure to invest those returns as well. First principle is still applicable here. Keep aside one-tenth of these returns and invest the remaining nine-tenth part. Always play a long term game. Sacrifice your today for a better tomorrow. 3 Guard Your Treasures From Loss You must guard your money with firmness else it will be lost. Misfortune always strikes when you least expect it. Invest only where your principal is safe, where it may be possible to reclaim it when desired. Where you will not fail to get a fair return. Remember this aphorism which was written 1000s of years from today: “Just as weeds grow in a field wherever the farmer leaves some space for their roots, even so freely desires grow in men whenever their is a possibility of them being gratified.” Desires are many but that which must be fulfilled are few. 4. Insure A Future Income No man can afford not to insure a future income for his old age and for the protection of his family no matter how prosperous his business and his investments may be today. It is responsibility of every man to make preparations for a suitable income when he is no longer to work and to make preparations for his family should he be no longer with them to comfort and support them. All of above techniques are useless if you do not follow the 5th one. 5. Increase Your Ability To Earn This is the most vital of all the techniques to become rich. Preceding every accomplishment is a strong and definite desire. You should have strength of purpose and a strong definite desire of getting rich. This is how wealth is accumulated: first in small sums, then in larger ones as a man learns more and becomes capable. Show more interest in your work, more concentration upon your task and more persistence in your efforts. To become rich you must cultivate your own powers, study and become wiser, become more skillful and always be in the front ranks of progress lest you be left behind.

Investing your money to get better returns can make you rich. It is not possible to become rich by just doing job you can just live a normal life. Warren buffet has rightly said that if you don’t find a way to make money while you sleep, you will work until you die. Now a big question is Which is the best way for investment to become rich? Investing in Stock market is the best way for becoming rich as a small investor can also start investing with minimum amount. Below are the examples where investors became millionaires by investing in Stock Market. 1) Rakesh Jhunjhunwala – Successful Stock Market Investor:  Popularly known as Warren Buffet of Indian stock market, Rakesh Jhunjhunwala entered the Indian market in 1985. He inherited the interest in stock trading from his father who used to discuss with his friends and Rakesh used to listen them keenly. He joined the Chartered Accountancy course to acquire a professional degree and completed in 1985. Thereafter, he joined Stock Market and started trading. His first biggest hit was 5000 shares of Tata Tea which he got for Rs 43 and sold for Rs143 in just 3 months. This gave him Rs. 5 Lakh which was a big deal at that time. His next big bet was Sesa Goa. He purchased 4 lakh shares and accumulated huge profits in it. There are a lot of stocks that made large sums of money for him like Lupin, Crisil etc.Today his portfolio is worth over Rs. 20,000 crores / 3.2 Bn Dollars which consists of Titan, Lupin and CRISIL as top holdings now. He is a renowned trader and investor of Indian stock market and called as Indian Warren Buffet. 2) Porinju Veliyath -Midleclass Family member turned to CEO of Equity Intelligence:  Porinju Veliyath was born in year 1962 in the lower middle-class family in Kochi. His early life was full of struggles. He joined various jobs along with studies to support his family. He went Mumbai in 1990 in search of job. He was appointed as a floor trader at Kotak Securities there. Stock Market was totally new field for him. Within a short span of time, he learned the in and out of stock market and became an expert trader. He worked for 4 years there and gained a lot of knowledge. In 1994, he joined Parag Parikh Securities as a Research Analyst and fund manager. In 1999, he returned to Kochi and decided to make money on his own from the stock market. He made his first major investment in ‘Geojit Financial Services’. The stock was trading at a very low value at that time. Proving everybody wrong, this investment gave him manifold returns. In 2002, he started his own portfolio management service (PMS) firm in the name of ‘Equity Intelligence’. Today, he is one of the most well-known investor and fund-manager of recent times. Equity Intelligence stock picks like Emkay Global Financial Services and BCL Industries has rised by 200% in their share prices and IZMO and Vista Pharma rised by 100% in their share prices. 3) Vijay Kedia – From the family of stock brokers now turned to be successful investor:  Born in the family of stock-brokers, Vijay Kedia started his career in stock market in 1978 not because of choice but of compulsion as his father died. So, to earn the bread-butter for his family, he joined the family business of trading and stock-broking. Initially, he was not doing well. But, he did not lose hope and read about the stories of successful investors. He decided to switch in investing. He started learning about the fundamentals of companies. He owned Rs 35,000 at that time and by his own study, he invested the entire amount in a stock named Punjab Tractor. Here stock trading is the best way for making money. You should have proper knowledge and analytical skills. If you don’t have knowledge of stock market then you can hire research analyst who can give you updates regarding market situation and can explain you when and where to invest. By accumulating (or being able to control) income producing assets, stock and real estate among others. In real estate, you can buy a duplex with a small down payment, and have your tenant next door pay you monthly rent, which you pay to the mortgagor. Your tenant, in essence, is “buying” you a house! Over time, the value of your house increases, while the mortgage on the property DECREASES! In addition, you can get a depreciation write-off as well. You can then, leverage your equity and buy an other duplex, and do the same thing. In stock, you should invest in shares of companies that pay dividends. You can automatically reinvest those dividends into still MORE shares, which, the next time around, will return MORE dividends to you. You’ve got to start sonewhere. Hope this helps!

The method by which DESIRE for riches can be transmuted into financial equivalent, consist of 6 definite, practical steps : Step1: Fix in ur mind the exact amount of money you desire (There is a psychological reason for definite ness) Step2: Determine exactly what u intend to give in return for the money u desire (there is no such reality as “something for nothing”) Step3: Establish a definite date when u intend to posses the money u desire. Step4: Create definite plan for carrying out desire and begin at once, whether u are ready or not, to put this plan into action. Step 5: Write out a clear, concise statement of the amount of money u intend to acquire, name the time limit for acquisition, state what u intend to give in return for the money and describe clearly the plan through which u intend to accumulate it. Step 6: Read ur written statement aloud, twice a day, once just before retiring at night and once after arising in the morning. Note : Only one who become “money conscious” ever accumulate great riches. “Money conscious” means that the mind has become so thoroughly saturated with the desire for money, that one can see one's self already in possession of it. Eg:Columbus dreamed of an unknown world, staked his life on the existence of such a world and discovered it! “The greatest achievement was, at first, and for a time, but a dream”

Wealth = Uniqueness X Scale EXAMPLE $1,000,000 = $1,000 X 1,000 clients Can you create a unique product or service, based on your uniqueness (talent, passion, experience, etc.) and sell to 1,000 clients? Or $1,000,000 = $100 X 10,000 clients Same thing here. It doesn’t have to be a $100, it can be 2 different products priced at $50 and which you sell to the same clients. You can change a million to a billion, it doesn’t matter, the principle remains the same. Secret: Before you “do”, understand what you “are.” You embody a WORLD of riches, so first explore that world within. Discover your native treasures. Grow them, nurture them, refine them. Polish your native talents, abilities, God-given gifts, qualities, etc. until they become DIAMONDS. In short, what you should do to become rich, will flow naturally from what you are. Your true nature. Seneca wrote a long time ago: “A happy life is one lived according to its nature.” Thus, Warren Buffett and Pablo Picasso are equally “rich” as they both lived according to their own nature. Picasso once said: “Give me a museum and I will fill it.” Arrogance? I don’t think so. Just a keen and just appreciation of his true nature, and how he could leverage it to produce art. Isaac Asimov, the science-fiction writer, wrote 300 books in his lifetime. He used nothing but an electric typewriter! (No word processor, his technique was never to edit himself while he was writing). So what is YOUR true nature? Many people are looking for a job, but the REAL work lies first in exploring the vast inner world that you contain, and discover the treasures of that world within. Treasures that nobody but you can discern, discover and appreciate. If you don’t appreciate who and what you, neither will the world around you. Honor your talent, honor your gifts, honor the unique being that you have grown into throughout the course of your life. Discover what you are uniquely qualified to do, my friend, and you’ll be so happy doing what you enjoy and providing a useful service that you won’t pay too much attention to this colored piece of paper that people pass around to secure goods and services. Because that’s what it is. Don’t aim to have as many of those pieces of paper as possible. It is just paper. What’s most important is to FEEL ALIVE doing, every day, what you love to do. What no one can stop you from doing. That is true wealth.

Several things, but overall, it’s tougher than it might seem. Avoid debt. It’s easy to borrow money, through getting into debt. But the more one can avoid debt, the greater the chances for financial success. The largest form of debt in a person’s life is a mortgage. It is almost inevitable that to live in nice surroundings, one must have a mortgage. And a mortgage is acceptable, as long as one doesn’t periodically move to a larger mortgage, from a lesser one. But, avoid doing that - live beneath your means, not above your ability to pay, or even AT your ability to pay;Save as much money as you can. No matter how much money you make, save some: do without things that are not ABSOLUTELY ESSENTIAL to your basic survival. You may enjoy life less, but as you get older, with your savings accumulating, you will not have missed the finer things, and you’ll be better off in the long run;Do without those things which are not essential. They require money, and you’re both trying to live conservatively, as well as trying to avoid debt. Sure, that means sacrificing, but it also means more accumulation of money, and as you age, you’ll be increasingly glad that you did.If you can follow these simple guidelines, you’ll be accumulating wealth, as well as moving through life more simply. It may not produce continuing happiness, but it will set you up for later in life, when you’ll look back and be glad that you took these actions to better prepare for the future. But, admittedly, much easier to think about, than to actually execute…

Master your mindset. This means becoming highly aware of how you think, feel, and act, and making permanent changes to adopt a success mindset. This will set you up to be in control of your life.What do you mean by rich? Is it $1 MM? $10MM? By when? Define your goal specifically, and make the undeniable commitment to achieving it no matter what - with the exception of sacrificing your ethics. You can be a moral, generous, person and have wealth.Create a long term plan of action that will enable you to reach your goal. Work backwards until it’s crystal clear what you need to do every single day.Learn how money and investing works so you can take advantage of opportunities to build your wealth and avoid costly mistakes throughout your lifetime.Keep learning! The best in the world are focussed on continual development. Realize that setbacks are normal, and things won’t always go to plan. Don’t give up.

In my experience there are 4 ways to be rich. Inheritance. Your family are already rich and you get some but that means someone in your family already did one of the following 3 options.Gamble. That may mean winning by total chance or professional gambling where you study a lot and increase the odds in your favour. With the latter it overlaps with number 3.Work. This is the option that most people take and can be split generally into 2 categories.Do - Doing a job for a company that is owned by someone else. This is what 99% of people do. Innovation is minimal and getting ‘rich’ this way is hard. Those who do it generally transition into 3b.Innovate - Find a niche in the market and cater for it. This is risky and a lot of new businesses fail but the rewards can be huge. It also takes a huge amount of work generally compared to 3a. Think of all the rich people you know of and likelihood they fit in here. Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg etc.Crime. Rob houses, banks, embezzle (started off in 3a or 3b), launder money, counterfeit money, deal drugs or be a pimp etc etc. Again high risk for the obvious reasons but the rewards can be huge. Crime does pay for some people but they are rare and unless you like being paranoid I would stay clear.So there you have it…….Which one do you choose?

‎The easiest way to become rich is by providing solution to people and organization's problems, and then monetizing your solution to their problems so that they will pay you for helping them solve their problems. The above strategy is only applicable if you want to become rich legally without indulging in crime. Another easy way to become rich is by buying and selling. You can start buying and selling online, but make sure what you are buying and re-selling are what people need and ready to pay for to avoid buying what won't sell. And at the end, it still boils down to providing solutions to people's problems through several ways, including buying and selling mentioned above. Now the question is, how do I achieve the above? 1. Create an action plan Everyone desires to be rich but only few end up becoming rich and you know why? Simply because those that failed to become rich didn't act on their desire to become rich. They only wished and never had an action plan to achieve their wish or goal. You want to be rich? What can you do to solve one or two major problems in your present environment? Acquiring a degree from the best university in the world can guarantee you a good pay job but may never guarantee that you will be rich except you are a problem solver. I grew up in a very poor family in Nigeria, my father worked with the Federal ministry of Agriculture as a low income earner and my mother was into petty trading business that hardly put food on the table. Unfortunately, my parents total income a month was never enough to feed the family, you can imagine the situation yourself. I was only 10 when my father got retired and we relocated back to the village because my parents couldn't afford the house rent in the town. As soon as we moved back to the remote village, we ventured into peasant farming and every other petty human activity done in the remote village to put food on our table. But I didn't know this was only a tutelage process for the greater challenge ahead of me. Haven lived in the village, done dirty jobs and witnessed abject poverty firsthand, I promised myself that I must be rich in order to help my family and community. Out of struggles, I managed to finish secondary school and got admission into higher institution, and managed to graduate but then, no job in the country, and the few available jobs were hijacked by people in government and top management positions for their wards. I ended up working in a very demeaning job that couldn't pay for my daily upkeep to talk of saving for future. Future became bleak for me as I began to lose hope, but something in me kept pushing me not to give up too soon, so I pressed on. Due to my struggles while growing up in the village, I became a workaholic and in fact, smart-thinker always coming up with great ideas. My colleagues saw me as a genius and thought I was from a rich family, but little did they know that I was a village boy who has seen the very worst side of life. To cut the story short, I found my strength in my passion. What was my passion? Writing and trading, so I capitalized on my two main passions and they saved me from poverty today. I changed jobs but couldn't find one that paid me enough to save, I had to start blogging. From blogging about life, health, relationship, etc, I started making money through Google Adsense, and the day I received my very first check in 2011 was like a dream come true. I made close to $1,000, something I have never made in my whole life, I made it online just like that without spending a dime. I put in more effort and the money kept on coming and started saving. From my savings, I ventured into my second passion: trading business, using internet as my selling platform, and today I make nothing less than $100 everyday selling different things online. From my story, you should be able to pin-point what liberated me from poverty: my passion! Wealth is in our individual passions and hobbies. Go back now and study that thing you love doing right from when you were small, not just what you studied in school. That thing you enjoy doing from childhood is where your financial success lay. Another point to take home here in trying to become rich is: use your skill, talent or passion to solve people's problems and then monetize your solution to their problems and watch money roll in with ease. Even though I am not rich right now, but I can see a very bright future ahead of me and I am now in charge of my life; I no longer work for anybody, I have lots of time to myself and I am now working on bigger things that will place my name of the world's richest list sooner by God's grace. So to become rich in life, you must make use of your passion, talent or skill to solve societal problems and then monetize your solutions and scale up from there. One thing about becoming rich is, once you are successful in one business or venture, it will become easier for you to succeed in most other of your financial endeavors. ‎ The internet is a good tool to use to support your goal to become rich, that's if you know how to make good use of it.‎ Hope this helps?‎

Timeless Financial Principles. Don't work for money. Focus on making money work for you.Never say 'I can't afford it, instead say 'how can I afford it?'Never buy things on credit. If you can't pay cash for it then you can't afford it.Focus on investing rather than saving.Pay yourself first, 10% of everything you earn is yours to keep.Know the difference between good and bad debt. Good debt puts money in your pocket, bad debt takes money out of your pocket.An asset puts money in your pocket. A liability takes money out of your pocket. Spend your money buying assets.Turn your working/active income into passive income. Passive income is income that is generated from assets you own.Focus on improving your financial literacy. 9 times out of 10 financial literacy is self taught. It is not taught in school.Always keep an emergency fund, this should be at least 5% of your income.When you do do these things, you'll have more than enough to buy all the thing so you want.

To become rich, you need to stop spending impulsively and try to save as much money as you can. Just when you think you have a lot of money and can splurge on something…STOP! Keep saving up! Eventually you will save up enough to be able to invest that money. Do research on ways you can invest, although the most accessible one would be to do stock trading. As you keep saving up, make sure your bank account has an unofficial “minimum balance” that you never go below. Most rich people became rich by making very good decisions that benefitted them in the long term and also got very lucky. You need to tell yourself that you don’t need to buy things that aren’t necessary, especially if it is something you want just because your friends have it also. Make life decisions that help you fulfill long term goals. Don’t invest too much time on entertainment and short term benefits. Don’t save up so you can buy something big. You have to behave like you are on a tight budget even when you are not so you can have a “buffer” of cash in your bank when you really need it.

This has been answered so many times in so many ways that I'm not sure I can add anything new. However, your question lacks a few criteria that you need to consider. What do you like to do? This is important because you will not achieve any level of success you hate the method necessary to reach your goal. If you like selling, then you are probably half way there. If on the other hand you have already made up your mind that selling is not for you, then your choices will be limited to something else. I've run a number of businesses and it doesn't matter whether it is management consulting or affiliate marketing - when someone tells me they want to be part of my organization but then qualifies the conditions as not involving sales, then I know they are not serious.How hard are you willing to work to get what you want? Carrie Fisher the actress once said that "the trouble with instant gratification is that it takes too long". That does seem to sum up the attitude far too many people have. They want all the good things in life but are not willing to put in the effort.Do you know the difference between having a lot of money and being rich? Read Robert Kiyosaki's Rich Dad Poor Dad books. There are people who appear to be wealthy, but are really quite poor, they owe too much, have too much credit card debt, etc.So back to your original question. What should you do?Find something you can enjoy (you won't always enjoy it, there will be bumps in the road - that's life). Then work at it. The trick though is after an putting in the initial start-up money do not spend more that you earn. Build assets not do-dads (Robert Kiyosaki again). Good luck.
