The stock that I bought kept going down. I was watching my hard earned savings melt each day. It wasn’t supposed to be like this. It was around the year 2000, and buying a tech stock was supposed to be an immediate path to wealth. That’s why I only spent a few hours reading a broker’s report before making the purchase. Cisco was rumored to be interested in acquiring this company. So why do more work? There was no easy way to get more money. I was already working two part-time jobs on campus to help pay for my MIT degrees. The little spending money that I had would have to be stretched further – no going out on weekends until I could rebuild from this disaster. And then Warren Buffett came to speak on campus. Here was this really successful investor who was talking about: Competitive advantageIntrinsic valueInvesting for the long-termListening to Buffett speak made me realize I hadn’t been investing – I had been speculating. I had no investing philosophy. No investment process. I had spent almost no time understanding the industry the company was in. I had no idea if it had a sustainable competitive advantage Or what it was worth. I realized I was going to have to spend considerable time if I wanted to learn how to invest. Time that was already really scarce. I started reading everything I could find on value investing. Buffett Partnership letters. Berkshire Hathaway Annual Letters. Security Analysis. As I learned the basics of investing, I began to understand the more advanced concepts. I was no longer tempted by the hot tech stocks. Now, I was looking for durable businesses. I was fortunate to get an investing job with Fidelity Investments. I found a great mentor there, one who followed the same intrinsic value approach that Buffett advocates. Then I became a Senior Equity Analyst at another firm, then eventually, I became a Portfolio Manager. Now, more than 15 years later, I am the Chief Investment Officer of my own investing firm. I have used the investing readings that I have put together to mentor many aspiring value investors. If you are just beginning to invest, first ask: Are you an investor or a speculator? Will becoming rich make you happy? I think that in general money can help you avoid misery, but it won’t really make you happy. What does? Meaningful relationships, experiences, satisfaction of achieving one’s goals, meditation.

Take a look at the yin-yang symbol. It depicts 2 opposite phenomena united in one circle. Yin could be to make money. Then yang would be the opposite: To share money. Yin can only grow, if yang also grows. This means that you can only make money, if you somehow share money - e.g. by paying tax, investing the money or doing philantropy. That’s how you can become rich. If you choose to do philantropy, here’s some advice on how to do it: “Be careful not to practice your righteousness in front of others to be seen by them. If you do, you will have no reward from your Father in heaven. So when you give to the needy, do not announce it with trumpets, as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and on the streets, to be honored by others. Truly I tell you, they have received their reward in full. But when you give to the needy, do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing, so that your giving may be in secret. Then your Father, who sees what is done in secret, will reward you.” (Matthew 6:1–4)

response.answer_text: To become rich you will need more than one good solid source of income. Successful people usually have more than 4–5 sources of Income. Banker sells products. Insurance guy sells protections through emotions Mutual fund guy sells dreams of making big money by investing FMCG guy sells products which can be consumed Real estate guy sells ambition through emotions Steve Jobs used to sell luxury. Microsoft sells productivity by offering lot of tools. Amazon sells efficiency by providing lot of options and delivering it fast. Facebook thrives on human emotions. So get going. Start SELLING. One day you will become a Billionaire. Alternatively, people also suggest that you should invest and agreed that too. Let compounding act in your favour. But for that you need to start really early. like early to mid 20s. But if you start at 20 with same numbers then your end corpus will be more than 60+ crores. So, start early investing and start Selling. All the best! Thanks!

The question is very vague so I’m not really sure just what it is you want to know. The ways you might get rich are: Marry someone wealthyInherit moneyWin moneyEarn moneySteal moneyThose are pretty much your options. Stealing isn’t something that’s typically recommended because of the increased risk of spending the next decade in a small room with a big guy called Bubba who took the top bunk already. Winning it in any quantity is difficult because of the laws of probability. Inheriting only works if you’ve got wealthy family members who are fond of you. So for most people the options are working for it or marrying it. Not surprisingly people with money aren’t usually inclined to marry poorer people who are only after easy access to wealth. That leaves working for it. You didn’t say anything about what skills you might have so it’s hard to offer much more than that.

You get wealthy when you know how the monetary system works and become an informed and active player in this system. I’ll explain the system in phases. Employee phase: Let’s say you start a job after finishing your education. You start working for others (owner/shareholders of your company). You feel that you’re paid well. This puts you in a comfort zone and thus you yourself close the door of getting rich. You spend life salary-to-salary and end it as a poor middle class. Self-employed phase: If you’re poorly paid as an employee or you realize that being an employee won’t make you rich, you may think of running your own business. As a small business owner you work for yourself. If you could not do it well, you may close your small business and become an employee again. And if you manage it well and have further urge to get rich, you may become a businessman. Businessman phase: In this phase, others work for you. You have leverage of time and money. Failing in business may force you to become an employee or self-employed person again. If you’re successful in business, this may put so much money in your pocket that you may advance to next stage of getting rich. Investor phase: When you have enough money in your pocket, then you may put your money work for you. When your money works for you and it multiplies due to compound interest, you feel rich because you have time to enjoy and financial freedom to afford almost anything. Well there could be following combinations: a) An employee + investor (you have little money to invest and hence can’t get rich) b) A self-employed + investor (You may be better than previous combination but still you won’t be as rich as person with next combination) c) A businessman + investor (This is what to real rich class belongs to. A good business covers their losses in investment and also provides them great leverage of money.) If you notice, on each stage, you need certain personal traits and classified knowledge to succeed. So, the best you can do to get rich is: Get knowledge of how economy worksGet knowledge of finance and budgetingGet knowledge of monetary systemLearn some key skill to productivityLearn management and marketingUpdated knowledge of current affairsAnd the personal traits to develop are: Willingness to learn new thingsCourage to take risksLearn from failures and not to discourage yourselfGreed to get rich

EASY! But first, you have to know what rich IS. The measure of your wealth is not by your possessions and money alone. ( I have that on good authority, for sure). I have known many very wealthy people, I have also known many people with vast amounts of money who were not wealthy, in fact they were desperately poor. So, WHAT IS WEALTH? There are five aspects to being wealthy: Health: your physical and emotional state. If you don’t have your health, you are poor indeed.Spirituality: understanding your place in the universe. Having a concept, as best you can of the nature of the cosmos and what God is as you may or may not conceive of Him.Relationships: having someone to love, and having that love reciprocated. Caring and having people care for you. Friends, relationships.Meaning: having a reason to live, a cause. For most of us, it is meaningful work, or a cause, a passion. For some of us, it is a dedication to helping others.Finances: having enough money so you aren’t under undue pressure to meet basic needs. Having too much money can be a curse. Having the right amount is liberating. Live simply.I feel outrageously blessed to have all of the aspects of wealth, though I’m a little short in number 5. So, that’s a good thing. Helps me remain humble. And, I am humbled by the great wealth I have. I give thanks, several times a day. But I also realize that I am called to give back, to pass it along. That’s not to say I don’t have problems. We all do. It’s the nature of existence, and the fundamental struggle that all living things must face. Strive to be Wealthy, not rich. Strive to do good, be generous, kind and compassionate. Always do the right thing. Create good Karma.

In my opinion, the real richness and wealth comes from having a happy & fulfilled life. Things or money don’t give us happiness. In my life I chased money, initially in my career I took a job only for the money, but did not enjoy at all, even though I was getting money, something big was missing. Luckily I found the job that I enjoyed eventually, of course the money was good, about 12 years of my life went in that, while I was in that job, I wanted fancy things, I bought my 1st BMW, which made me very happy, but I got bored after 6 months. Then I upgraded my BMW to another one much more powerful and even more smooth & prestigious, again after 6 months I got bored. Same thing with the home as well, I bought a good home and I was mowing the lawn forcefully every week, just to to make sure my home value does not go down, so whatever thing you get you will get bored after 6 months. Whatever you buy, you will get bored in 6 months and you want the next better thing. Again after 12 years, I felt like I was just doing it for the money, helping build someone else’s dreams. We all think only the poor get diseases, get malnutrition, once you are wealthy all the problems will disappear, no that is not true, when you are poor you have poor people diseases, once you are rich you get rich people diseases. Same thing, when I was in India, looking at the quality of roads or the lack of roads, I thought the developed nations like USA, Germany, Japan etc have great roads, so life will be perfect there, no it is not, yes they do have great roads, but you know what they have huge traffic problems, they have great roads, great infrastructure, once accident happens, the entire city comes to a grinding halt, so whether you are rich or poor, there is always going to be some problem, some disease, something you are not going to be happy with, even if you have the most expensive fancy car, one day the car breaks down and your life is miserable, to be candid, the fancy cars break down more than the Honda and Toyota, which are much more reliable, so the point is just enjoy what you do, love what you do, do a great job with passion making a difference in someone’s life, everything else falls in place. However if you focus on building something that is useful for somebody, that makes a difference in somebody’s life and do something that gives you a sense of fulfillment, that will not only make you very happy, but also gives you a sense of meaning in life. That is exactly what I am doing now, however that is not easy, I am grateful to have this amazing people in my life that are helping me do that. This makes me feel much more richer, than I had the fancy BMW. If I continue this path, I can buy another BMW, but the point is here, the focus is on building something great, that makes a difference in people’s lives, when you do that so passionately, everything else falls in place. So the focus is not doing something strictly for the money, which is when you are buying the flashy BMW for the sake of buying it. I think that is right way to be truly rich and wealthy. Hope this helps. Good Luck!

There is a simple formula to become rich. The formula is Wealth = max[(Savings)^(Rate*Time)] Step 1: Earn as much as possible and max out your (Savings/Earnings) ratio Step 2: Invest your savings wisely and try to compound it at maximum “Rate” Step 3: Make sure you are able to do Step 1 and Step 2 for as long as possible - Maximize the Time To give a good example, lets consider the famous Warren Buffet. He saved a lot during his younger days. He compounded his money at more than 20% CAGR. He did this over a very long period of time (He started as a teenager and is now in his eighties). Most people speak about his compounding rate, but quite a few forget about the “Time” factor. One reason why he is so much rich is that he has lived long (along with the other two factors). So living a simple, healthy life not only helps you maximize your savings but also gives you a fair shot at maximizing the “Time” factor. How you do on the compounding rate will depend on your financial and behavioral skills, and a bit of luck as well. How you do on maximizing the (Savings/Earnings) ratio will depend a lot on your profession, lifestyle and some other factors. Theoretically, the formula is very simple. In theory, there is no difference between theory and practice, but in practice there is.

Rich is relative.  But over the years, I found out that there are 2 types of people. Those who would prefer to earn more than save more. And those who would prefer to save more than earn more. Which among the two are you? Personally, I fit in the latter category. I find it easier to control what I already have than what I could have. But interestingly, I found out that there is also a huge number who prefer the former category of earning more money than saving. Now, the trick that I found out is about balance, yin and yang, the value of moderation which is one of the most important life skills to have. What I realized is given that I can save easily, I should focus more on earning rather than saving. Another reason why is that you can only save so much but your earning potential is unlimited. Given my personality, I should strive on looking for more ways to earn more money. However, if your personality is of the opposite side of the coin, then you should focus more on saving rather than spending money. You find it already easy to earn and probably have accumulated a lot of wealth. With that scenario, you find that you’re not getting richer but remain in equilibrium. Then it might be time to re-evaluate your spending habits and look for ways on how you can save more (or invest more to assets that can give you income). As much as possible, we should only save to have a decent emergency fund then invest the rest for our money to make more money.

The first thing we need to define is money. Money is stored labor. So money represents access to the labor product of others. From an evolutionary standpoint this implies that being 'rich' means you do not have to spend time getting food, collecting water and maintaining a shelter but can spend your time pursuing mates. As social animals we tend to be status conscious. The rich will often have items that indicate status within a social group that are signals to potential mates. Status items cost much more than their utility value. For example the utility value of a car is pretty much the same as most modern cars are very reliable and well engineered. Ferrari's are difficult to drive, unreliable and expensive to repair, however they are deemed desirable because of our atavistic ape brains. This seems to have been encoded into our DNA by the sexual selection of females primarily, as demonstrating that you have resources to waste. This makes you seem a better mate as those resources could be redirected to survival of offspring.

Brief answer: You’d say the other answers may all be reasonably correct, though for a wrong question. According to plain logic, correct answer for wrong question is wrong --- something positive to negative is negative. – 1 x (+ 1) = – 1. The question should be asked this way: How can I survive? Yes? I become rich to survive and survive better. What is wrong with that? Yes, it is wrong: natural order favour life’s extinction (because it forms recurrent closed cycles that cuts off future for life which is the biological information existence continuation). Competition for the limited material value to get rich and power is the natural mechanism to lock all life in the natural order that lead to life’s extinction (when this life evolve to the level of intelligence) --- this is the natural way to survive in natural system that will lead to human extinction in manmade social system by natural law. Natural order carried by natural process sets human individual present interest against his own ultimate interest to extinct him. We can see that effect: micro-economic competition leads to macro-economic conditions deterioration that leads to most population worse off, future generations worse off, and finally extinction for all life. That is because the micro-economic competition solution is based on the wrong assumption of unlimited material value accessibility and human activities can create material value. The traditional economics confused use value (utility and function) with material value (systematic form of negative thermodynamic entropy, which is expressed as our resources and environment). Regardless it is in the capitalist system or socialist system, we see the same trend because they are all natural order-run manmade social systems. When blind mass follow blind assumption, disaster is bound to happen. More explanation: Life does compete the limited nature given material value to survive in natural process but when nature evolved out intelligence and this intelligence start to use its manmade order to build manmade structure, natural balancing mechanisms on benign level will be disabled and also natural order will start to act against manmade order to pull it back to natural state. This is the natural law: “Natural order cap information evolution at the point of intelligence”. Natural order derives out natural process, and natural process is a recurrent closed cycle that is default to cap life evolution at the point of intelligence and recycle it into energy finally to maintain the thermodynamic existence continuation of the non-living matter. But nature does leave a very narrow path for life to achieve its information existence continuation which is the rational meaning for survival --- use their rationality ability to adopt rational order to connect the natural process into a rational open process that lead to endless future. But due to natural order spontaneously and simultaneously destructing rational order and rational structure, it is extremely difficult to achieve far future. Though that is not a nature made mistake, it is just the natural selection mechanism on system level selection at work. This question (How can I become rich?) is a bit shallow and narrow, a bit childish as a modern human. Before we answer this question, we should answer a series of more meaningful questions first: Rich for what? What is the purpose for getting rich? What is life? What is the purpose for life? What is the relation between material value and use value? What is the relation between life and material value, What is the relation between life and use value? What is an individual’s ultimate interest? What is the relation between individual present interest and his ultimate interest? What is the coincident effect of the stable behavioural strategy of everyone acts according his best of present individual interest? Where does this natural order lead this individual and all human to? How to maximise your interest? How can one fulfil his ultimate interest? When we solve problem we should deal with the fundamental cause of the problem. When we trace the cause of the problem we should trace to the most fundamental cause of the problem. When we have big dream, we should have this dream to the maximum --- the ultimate dream, and realise it. Otherwise, in the end, you have nothing, at all. That is because, the real rich is to own the endless future, is to own the universe. Why we have to be so complicated? Can we be just simple and natural as we did before for billions of years and as the result become the intelligent life as we are? No. That is because the reality is complicated after we become intelligent life, and we no longer can depend on natural order and natural process any more. Put money in the Stock market. Invest money in stocks, bonds, or other vehicles of investment that will give you an annual return on investment (ROI) great enough to sustain you in your retirement. For instance, if you have one million dollars invested and you get a reliable 7% ROI, that's $70,000 per year, less inflation. Don't get enticed by day traders who tell you it's easy to make a quick buck. Buying and selling dozens of stocks every day is essentially gambling. If you make some bad trades — which is unbelievably easy to do — you can losea lot of money. It's not a good way to get rich.Instead, learn to invest for the long run. Choose good stocks with solid fundamentals and excellent leadership in industries that are primed for future growth. Then let your stock sit. Don't do anything with it. Let it weather the ups and downs. If you invest wisely, you should do very well over time.If you want to start trading and you are beginner click here Professional Stocks Signals Provider there are free video tutorials about Stocks.

Start by defining what “rich” means to you, not what others think. Most people think of owning lots of money and objects as the definition of rich. What is it that you want to do with the wealth? What is it that makes you happy? Is not being able to satisfy your need for happiness the true definition of being rich? I focus on looking at the components of who I am: my mind, body, and soul. My mind and soul don’t need material things for them to feel rich. In fact, the more I focus on material, the less my mind and soul feel rich. They feel more like slaves to material wealth. They then don’t have time or the energy to truly feel rich and happy as time is spent seeking how to get more wealth and comparing with others. That generally leads to unhappiness. And when the mind and soul are happy and feeling rich, somehow the body seems to follow! How to achieve richness in yourself does require work, but it has been my personal experience that every positive change to your mind and soul’s richness gives far more happiness than any additional increment in your material wealth. Buying a new pair of shoes gives immediate gratification but does it lead to true long term, personal richness? So you may find that just thinking about what rich means to you may increase your level of richness far quicker than would investing in the share market! It doesn’t mean you should stop holding material wealth; it just means defining what it is for YOU to be happy (not what others say) and then laying out a plan of how to achieve that happiness. For example, I found improving my relationship with my parents to be far more richly rewarding that adding $1750 to my bank account because my shares increased in value. The $1750 was nice and gave me an immediate buzz but that quickly disappeared as I then focussed on trying to get more money. Yet my relationship with my parents and the love and support they give me is a richness that doesn’t stop giving. It is a permanent high. Define your richness goalposts in terms of your true happiness components and you may find you are closer to them than you think.

Easy—be true to yourself, be a good friend, don’t surround yourself with selfish emotional vampires, don’t fall in or out of love too easily, accept that you and everyone else in the world has normal human flaws, and severely limit purchases you make with credit, especially if they require interest payments. Everything in life passes away. Being rich means having trust, love, loyalty, respect, and compassion from others…and giving them to yourself, too. The more you give, the more you’ll get. Give to others what you want to have, and you’ll soon discover a life of wealth and fulfillment. This is what I’ve learned from chasing money, stupidly following my shallow attractions to women who were all wrong for me, and losing people I loved dearly. Money will never buy the best things for you…nor can they be taken. They have to be earned…they have to be given to you freely. And you’ll get them by giving. That’s all I know about life.

That’s a tricky question to answer, and that’s going to depend on your idea of “rich.” If your idea of being rich is someone who makes a massive amount of money very quickly, then you’re either going to have start a unique business, or have some type of talent nobody else does (e.g. athletic, acting, music, etc…). There are also some people who can work their way to the top of the corporate ladder and might make 7–8 figure salaries as CEO’s, Directors, Law Firm Partners, Head Surgeons, but they’ll never be paid billions, the profits go to the people who invested and founded those businesses. However If you’re talking about getting rich by building wealth, that takes financial discipline and wisdom. Most people build their wealth through private investments into stocks, bonds, real estate (flipping and renting homes, not living in them), collectibles, etc… The difference between wealth building and the above is that anyone with a little bit of extra income can do this. But it takes patience, you can’t think about where you want to be tomorrow, you need to think about where you want to be 20 years from now, and where you want your kids to be. People who focus on building wealth almost never look wealthy, but they have the ability do things many people simply can’t like buying their cars for cash, paying for college tuition in cash, being able to help their children buy homes when they’re adults, etc…

First, stop fooling yourself. You don't want to be rich. You want wealth to accomplish something, and for most people it is to make themselves feel secure. Money in itself is nothing. You want security or respect (ego-driven) or perhaps you want to be in the situation to help others you love.  So first of all think about why you want to be rich. By the way this question is written I would take it that you are young or immature. Most likely young.  Life will teach you soon - through a progression of various hard knocks - which direction you can go.  And the truth is you might be able to get what you really want and need without being wealthy.  Most people who have happy lives are not wealthy. And many people who have wealth are not happy.  So go beyond 'I want to be rich' and aim for your true goal. And it might be too early to know. And that is ok.

Make money, and being smart with how you spend your money. It’s that simple. In this day and age it’s very easy for people to be making money, the biggest issue that people have is that they spend way too much or don’t make smart decisions with their money. They don’t save up money in a savings account and instead spend their money on things that they don’t need to impress people that they don’t like. On top of that, the thing that most people spend their money on is on things that are outside of their pay bracket. In other words, people tend to take out massive loans in order to cover the costs. And having debt like that is the best way to kill any kind of wealth that you have. Instead what is suggested in basically every wealth book you’ll ever read is to spend your money wisely. Invest in index funds, put a little bit into a savings account, and live within your own means. To do those things it does require you to do some math and accounting but it’s mainly looking at where your money is going and setting up a budget that works for you. The reason wealthy people do this is so they know where their spending habits are and if it’s a problem, they can curb them. This is also the same tactic that is used to help people get out of debt and develop their own wealth.

The cheeky way you asked the question deserves a quick, simple answer. 3 Steps that work 100% of the time: Spend less than you earnPay yourself firstInvest for the long termRinse and repeat patiently. If you are truly interested in becoming rich, it's important to analyze why you want to become rich, and what rich means to you. For some people, rich means having the ability to spend more time at home with their family. For others, rich means being able to travel the world. And for others, it means not having to answer to anyone. I'd suggest outlining what you want out of life, what will make you happy. Investigate how much money you need to live that life. And then focus on the personal finance equation (spend less or earn more to have wealth). Spend less on things you don't care about, and earn more doing things that bring you closer to your ideal life.

To begin, I am not "rich" but I spend a lot of time around very wealthy and successful people. I have always been very interested in why some people are more successful than others and in turn, more wealthy.  In talking to a man that is a multi millionaire, asking him many questions about becoming wealthy he told me this : "There is no secret to becoming rich, spend much less than you make and invest the rest into things that will make you more money." This makes sense. Look around you and you will notice that your average person is a hyper consumer and never invests in things that will put money back into his pocket.  Find ways to create multiple income streams and use the profits to expand and make more money.  Almost every successful person seems to have a different mindset when it comes to the things they buy vs the average person. Change your mind, change your lifestyle.

Now , people actually make mistakes and buy on liabilities as they think they are assets for example , brand new car . Now if you want to enjoy your life you need to make up assets that can pay your daily/monthly expenses and the excess of money flow can be used for entertainment and foreign trips. This is the best way to get our financial freedom and getting out of the debt trap .

Marry it. Inherit it. Win the lottery. To be self made, you have to work your butt off in an occupation that pays OR build up your own successful business. Then you have to save and invest like crazy - like half your income or more. Then you have to limit the size and frequency of losses. Then you have to define what 'rich' is for you, so you know when it is OK to ease off the throttle. When I was starting out, I thought $2M was 'rich'. Then I had kids, so I upped it to $3M thinking I would subsidize their education and leave them a small inheritance. Now I want to do things like support charities, help a few destitute families I know, and help a relative with an expensive health problem. The more you want to do, the richer you have to be. So I'm still working my butt off, saving like crazy, and learning more about limiting the size and frequency of losses.

This is a loaded question. How quickly would you like to become wealthy? A good way to invest in a retirement account consistently over time. Choose one with low fees and diversify to get a good rate of return. Balance your portfolio annually. In 40 years you could be a multi-millionaire. If you’d prefer a faster method of becoming wealthy (monetarily speaking, of course) look into generating more income while simultaneously driving down debt. The fewer liabilities you have, the more powerful your money is. Also, stop trading your hours for dollars. Research ways to make a residual income. This is money that you make on work you’ve done in the past (like how Michael Jackson’s estate made $75 million in 2017 with him being deceased). One way is again the investment portfolio as mentioned above, creating something like a book or album, starting an online business, or looking into my favorite way: network marketing.

Being rich is not easy. If it were easy, every one would have been rich. It takes years of dedication, hard work,optimism, patience and plenty of failure along the way, to get rich. But yes there is an easy way to get rich, that is to put Power Of Compounding to work for you. Let me share a story with you. Long back, when the inventor of the chess showed the game to an Indian king, the king was so impressed by the new game, that he wanted to reward the inventor. At that time, the inventor replied, “My wishes are simple. I only wish for one grain of rice for the first square of the chessboard, two grains for the second square, four grains for the third square, eight for the fourth square and so on for all 64 squares.” The inventor said, “Please double the number of grains in the next square compared to the earlier square.” The king was amazed to hear that the investor had asked for such a small reward. He happily agreed to the inventor’s request. However after a week, the king’s treasurer informed him that the reward would add up to a huge number—far greater than all the rice that could possibly be produced in many centuries! Do you know how much rice it would be when one reaches 64th square of the chessboard? As said earlier, in the first square of the chessboard there is only one grain. But when you come to the 64th square, it is 18 million trillion grains of rice. This is more than enough to cover the entire surface of the earth. Moral of the story Start investing earlyDon’t touch the amount for a long timeDon’t keep jumping from one investment to another

They still need to work, but one advantage laziness can bring is a willingness to delegate, remove needless steps in a process, and trust in the work of others. I don’t recommend you put it on your resume as a strength, but applying some practical lazy thought to the workplace can be very helpful. The guy who thought up having all the tools he needed and only those at his workbench is considered an organizational genius. Throwing out the equipment we never use so we don’t need to maintain it anymore? Genius! Buying a redundant system so when the one system breaks down we can calmly switch over to the backup and call the repair guy on Monday? Brilliant. Automating that hard to reach valve? You’re everyone’s new best friend. Only the thoughtful lazy will move from this  to this  Sure, if you take it to extremes, you only have these thoughts while lazing about on the couch and never do anything about it. We had a concept in college, called the hassle factor…was it worth the hassle? For the abysmally lazy, the answer will always be no…someone else will probably do it. Unfortunately for them, paper weights can easily be replaced by rocks.

Although this is cliche but still worth mentioning: Becoming rich unlike what is commonly perceived is not an attribute but a habit, which needs to inculcated and practised over at the least a quarter of your life-time. AND IT IS NOT TOUGH: Think about this India is growing at real rate of 7% and taking inflation into account, it is 11-12% in nominal terms. Looks a very meagre return if u calculate the monthly numbers. So for Rs. 1 lakh, u earn what seems to be a petty sum of Rs. 1000. Say u r somehow able to earn 2% nominal returns per month, which isn’t a mammoth ask considering that it is just double of what the country is growing at, and which of course u need to better because not everybody can become rich. Lets do the math now: Rs. 10 lakh would convert to more than Rs. 124 crores over a 30 year time frame. And if u could manage 4% a month, u could achieve this feat in 15 years. Isn’t that good enough for calling yourself rich? and IS IT REALLY TOUGH? The knack to learn over here is consistent returns. What we actually fail at is optimising our money. Our salaries lie idle in our bank accounts, we invest in assets that do nothing for us and most common issue of all, we do not know how to calculate our returns. WE FAIL TO REALISE THE POWER OF MONEY. Take this for an example: Most of us here earn approx. a lakh per month. Say we are able to somehow save the 10 lakh and invest it at 2%, it would become over a crore in the next 10 years. But instead of giving time to this aspect, we continue to concentrate on our jobs. Can we save this amount doing the same job over the next 10 years? Lets look at another example: A person in my office bought a flat (3BHK) in Pune for Rs. 48 lakhs+ Reg. Charges. He managed 18 lakh of his own and took a loan for the rest at 9.5% per year. Now I asked him a question: Would the flat be worth 4.8 crores in the next 10 years. The answer was NO. Now his 18 lakhs would have become 1.8 crores + the SIP of his EMI of Rs. 55k for 10 year tenure would have yielded him: 55000*488= 2.68 crores (at 2% per month). Now imagine how much he lost, but he was still unmoved, indifferent and most of all contend with his decision. So here u get the most important lesson: ACT NOW

My mother told me what she believed to be the greatest method of gaining wealth: saving money. At the time, I had begun working for a consulting firm, earning more than I ever had, previously. I began buying items I could never before afford, and she told me that one day, I’d retire & I should consider the quality of life I’d wanted to live, once I was no longer earning money. She said “Anyone can earn money, but it’s how much a person saves which determines his/her wealth.” She also said that no matter how much or how little a person earns, savings are all that will remain as beneficial assets (aside from a home), when that person is no longer able to earn, or wishes to retire. After I unexpectedly became disabled, I found myself wishing I had saved more & spent less.

Being rich and being wealthy are two different things. Being rich is simply having a lot of expendable money. Typically, these are people with fancy cars, living in a fancy house, wearing fancy clothes. Rich people have usually come into their money in a short time period (think lottery winner, or entertainer). In contrast, being wealthy is someone with sustainable wealth. Wealthy people know how to make money over a long period of time and have the knowledge to keep it. Also, wealthy people are far less likely to needlessly spend on the latest gadgets for instance, they keep close track of their income and expenditure. So, essentially, a wealthy person will always be wealthy, but someone who is rich usually spends excessive money until it is all gone. How many lottery-winners have become bankrupt after only a few years? Although most people in developed countries have the opportunity to become wealthy, very few actually use that opportunity. Being wealthy is about having complete control over your income and expenditure, and foregoing having the latest gadgets or buying things to show-off. Wealthy people actually tend to be more frugal in their spending (even Bill Gates is reported to have been seen shopping at Walmart and Target!) To summarize, to become wealthy, all you have to do is have total control over your personal finances and to be patient. Don’t believe the many “get rich quick” schemes which are advertised, and instead concentrate on ruthlessly saving/investing your money. To become rich simply buy a lottery ticket, cross your fingers and hope for the best! Unless you are one of the very lucky few, coming into a significant amount of money in a short period of time is not something which you can plan for.

What is the key to being truly wealthy? The key to true wealth is to realize wealth is not riches. Riches is the amount of currency you have control of. How many dollars, kunas, dongs, yen, or pounds sterling do you have in your bank account? Wealth is (in practice) what you can do with that currency. What utility does it bring to you. Does a “wealthy” person really live that much better than an average shmoe? Does that 10,000 square foot McMansion really provide that much more use to them than a modest 2,000 square foot house? Having a new luxury car every three years does what exactly compared to keeping your car for 10, 15, or 30 years? They both get you to and from work, errands, and events just fine. The lights go on, and the water coming out of the tap is drinkable. The internet goes to the same places, and netflix does not care what your net worth is. So, in practice, are the rich, mega rich, or so-called wealthy really that much wealthier than the average person? And, that is the key, right there. As soon as you realize that the expensive stuff is no better than the average stuff, you will stop spending your money on stuff you do not need, and start saving and investing. It will end up being a habit, and when you do have a net worth of several million, you will not only be wealthy, you will also be rich.

Even a small amount saved each week / pay cheque will set you on the path. Of course, you can lie, cheat, steal and use under-handed methods to accumulate wealth but there are always costs: people will target you for the money you have. Thieves will break into your home despite the best security system imaginable. Business associates / competitors will scam you. I will use the acronym TANSTAAFL - There Ain’t No Such Thing As A Free Lunch! Making money means working long, hard hours and being frugal. That or work hard and then patent a new process that is used by others who pay you royalties. I know of one gentleman who races automobiles: every car on the road today has four components that he created and patented. He is wealthy because he was creative and invested time and effort in researching, doing creative thinking and so on. If you desire wealth, then embark on the path towards wealth. Read what the wealthy people write - a library is your best starting point.

All I am about to write comes from the book rich dad poor dad. So I’d recomend you to read books of Robert Kiyosaki first..but anyways… I’ll try my best to put it all in my words. First of all think of your money as water filled in a water tank which has a inlet(your income) and a outlet (you spending your money)  There are 3 possible cases you can be in Your out-flow is bigger than your in-flow . Which means you will never have enough money and might already be in debtYour out- flow is as big as your in-flow. Which means you will have all your needs fulfilled but wont have money for any new plans.Your in- flow is bigger than your outlet. You will be having some money left at the end of the day.Now the most important thing that needs to be cleared is, how you define ‘rich’. Being rich does not means having a big inlet but it is about how many days you will survive whwn the in-flow is closed. In other words it depends on how much water you fill in your tank. As you can see, it is physicaly impossible to fill the tank in first 2 cases mensioned above. Which means the only way that you can become rich is by being in the 3rd case. Now the mistake that most of us people make is, we think that if the inlet of our tank is big enough, we would become rich. But you see, the tank will never be filled with water unless the out-flow is smaller than the in-flow. What I mean is, it doesn’t matters how much you earn per month if the money you spend is more than or equal to what you earn. So the first thing you need to do is, minimise your expences 1.Reduce the outlet i.e. reduce your expencess to the minimum. Now to the second step… Now if you look at the way how it works, if the out flow becomes small enough then the tank will start to fill and you will eventualy become rich. But it is a way long process. Thats why the 2nd step is necessary. 2nd step is to increase the number of inlets and/or incease the size of pre-existing inlet . This can be done by either geting a high payed job or by generating a new source of income As it comes down to types of income, there are 2 ways in which you can earn money . ●Active income ● Passive income Active income can be earned in terms of wages, saleries, or by self employed income. (Please google the terms active and passive income for more info. ) But it is quiet difficult to have more than one active income source as you can not work for number of jobs at the same time ( it beccomes exausting and stressful). So the another option you have is passive income . Passive income is the way to earn money again and again for something you did for only once in the past. Ex. You upload a sucessful youtube vedio. Now you will get money every time someone views your video and you dont have to do anything again once you have uploaded the video. Once you have multiple sources of passive income your tank will start filling even faster. 2 . Produce more ways of passive income. The 3rd step revolves around the concept of the water tank. It is investing in assets rather than buying liablities..(google assets and liablities too) An Asset is something that you buy once and that thing earns money for you. Consider that you installed a rain-water harvesting system for your tank. Now the system itself will help filling your tank. Now all you need is some maintanence. A liablity is something that you buy once and it requires more money to sustain…its as if you make a hole at the bottom of the tank. Ex. A car which you give on rent is a asset as it brings you more money (tough money for maintanence will still be required) A car which you use for personal transport is a liablity as it wont bring any money to you but still require money for maintanence and fueling Note: it doesn’t matters if the car helps you save your energy and time (time is not money when it comes to defining an asset ). A object is asset only and only if it brings money to y Read more about these terms.. Assets and liablityPassive incomeInvestment statergiesI belive these things will help you. Best luck on your way to financial freedom.. Please Do read the books of Robert Kiyosaki

In order to be rich, you need to be financially literate. This simply means you need to know the difference between an asset and a liability and how to use your money the right way so that you can generate more income. You need focus on acquiring assets and keeping liabilities low. The more assets you acquire, the more financially independent you will become. Examples of assets are: stocks, bonds, and real estate. Once you invest in an asset, your money will begin working for you. For example, if you invest some money into stocks, you will eventually earn more money without doing any work after you invest. Liabilities are things you buy that don’t generate income after you buy them. Such as: your car, cellphone, or house. Don’t get me wrong, you need liabilities in order to survive. However, you don’t need expensive things such as a big house or a cool car when you can’t afford one. Instead, try to save at least 20 percent of your paycheck so you can invest in assets later on. If you want to learn more about how to be financially literate and how to understand money differently, read “Rich Dad, Poor Dad” written by Robert Kiyosaki and Sharon Lechter. Good luck.

Go into a standard industry with monopolized competitors. This what musk did with SpaceX but it could be any common low cost low tech widget. There will be room for plenty of margin. For $200 you can register a brand at the trademark office giving you a monopoly on that name. Now simply advertise as a high quality high priced brand of a common thing and you will have high margins. Your econ 101 teacher was wrong. Consumers prefer higher priced goods. Try beer, clothes, ice cream, watches, snacks, diet bars, vitamins, t-shirts, car accessories, etc. Use third party manufacturers to produce or pick an item you can make at home without much regulation. The founders of Hawaiian Tropic mixed their first tanning lotion in barrels on the beach. Actress Jessica Alba built a $1 Billion dollar company based simply on the name “The Honest Company”. Brands are POWERFUL and cheap. A trademark gives you a legal and ethical monopoly that government police will enforce for you with seizures of counterfeit goods for simply $200. It's astoundingly powerful

Since you did not define Rich as a dollar amount I’ll go with the long held belief that one million dollars US is rich. Here is a snip-it from Dave Ramsey. I will link you to the full article. If you start putting away $300 a month beginning at age 25, you could reach millionaire status by age 60—and be sitting pretty on a $2 million nest egg come retirement (age 67). That’s just $300 a month! If you waited until age 35 to start investing, you’d have to put away $800 a month to hit the million-dollar mark by age 60. Let’s look at it a different way. If you invested $300 a month for 40 years (age 25 to age 65), you could have $1.75 million. If you invested that $300 a month for 30 years instead (age 35 to age 65), you’d only have $651,400. You’d have to work an extra 10 years (to age 70) to hit $1 million. And you’d have to work until age 75 to hit $1.75 million. Do you want to wait until you’re 75 to become a millionaire? Me neither.

There are a lot of ways but one of the easiest ways out there:- Compound Interest Let's take 2 scenarios. Suppose you're 25, fresh with a job, high hopes and goals for the future. You get a decent salary of around 60k Rs. Per month. You manage to save around 15k every month and you invest it.Let's assume that the rate of interest is around 15% (Any decent investment is bound to give you somewhere around the same).Let's say you save up 15k every month for 10 years which amounts to Rs. 18 lakh without interest would end up amounting to Rs. 41,79,895 (Rounding off to Rs. 42 lakh)A profit of Rs 24 Lakhs.If you never save any money and just keep investing the money you gained as profit in these 10 years till the time you turn 60 (25 more years), you end up with a sweet amount of Rs. 7,90,05,486 (That's 7 cores, 90 Lakhs, 5 thousand and four eighty six).2. Suppose you believe to enjoy every single penny you have in your 20s and decide to start saving when you turn 35 till the time you retire on 60. You would have invested Rs. 45 Lakhs and end up making Rs. 4,92,61,106 ( That's 4 crores, 92 Lakhs, 61 thousand, hundred and six) and that's just excluding the amount invested.So be smart. Start saving early. Compound Interest rocks.

Becoming rich is all about compounding your money faster than the inflation. Stock market is the best place to compound your money. The idea of investing is to compound the wealth over a period of time. Compound interest is an exponential function. The outcome is exponential. Rs 1 at 25% per annum for 10 years become Rs 10. If you compound again for the next 10 years, it becomes Rs 10 x 10 = Rs 100. Let that sink in for a second. Now that Rs 100 compounded for next 10 years will become Rs 1000. So in 30 years you can grow 1000 times if you compound your money at 25% per annum. Just imagine if you compound for ten more years. You will make it 10000 times. If you start at the age of 25. At 65 you can grow your investment 10000 times. This was all about compounding money at 25% and this is how people become rich.  The great Albert Einstein once said “Compound interest is the eighth wonder of the world. He who understands it, earns it … he who doesn't … pays it. My advice is to start saving money early in life and invest it in the stock market via mutual funds. Reason why you should start saving early. Let me give you one example. Ben and Arthur were friends who grew up together. They both knew they needed to start thinking about the future. At age 19, Ben decided to invest $2,000 every year for eight years. He picked investment funds that averaged a 12% interest rate. Then, at age 26, Ben stopped putting money into his investments. So he put a total of $16,000 into his investment funds. Now Arthur didn’t start investing until age 27. Just like Ben, he put $2,000 into his investment funds every year until he turned 65. He got the same 12% interest rate as Ben, but he invested for 31 more years than Ben did. So Arthur invested a total of $78,000 over 39 years.  Believe it or not, Ben came out ahead . . . $700,000 ahead! Arthur had a total of $1,532,166 while Ben had a total of $2,288,996. How did he do it? Starting early is the key. He put in less money but started eight years earlier. That’s compound interest for you! It turns $16,000 into almost $2.3 million! Since Ben invested earlier, the interest kicked in sooner. When both Ben and Arthur turned 65, they decided to compare their investment accounts. Who do you think had more? Ben, with his total of $16,000 invested over eight years, or Arthur, who invested $78,000 over 39 years? This is why we should start saving money very early in our life. You need a thick skin, and the ability to look beyond your partner’s wealth. Rich people, like anyone else, have dysfunctional families too. No, not really. In fact the wealthy keep telling everyone what they are doing and how they can get there, but few people listen. For example how many people live below their means? Look at the “Millionaire Next Door” (book) and you find that many wealthy are not out there buying expensive items. When they do they wait until it fits into their budget. The expensive cars and houses are often just owned by people with massive debt. The wealthy person does not buy those things, they put their money into income producing assets first. In other words they take as much of their income as they can, and use it to create an income. Here is a simplified example. Many people will simply buy a brand new car with a massive loan on it. The person with a more wealthy mindset would prefer to put that money into an investment, and keep putting that money into investments until that investment is putting out enough income that it pays for a car payment, and even then they would buy a used car, and let their income pay for it. As I said it’s a little simplified, but basically whats going on. They budget their money to put as much as possible into investments, creating passive income that will come in if they work or not. The will actually avoid increasing their lifestyle until their passive income exceeds their expenses if they can. But some will increase their expenses, but at a slower rate than their passive income is growing. But then there is more to it. Many people figure out how to make money with little to nothing invested. Although that takes more work. For example there are people who find properties, get them under contract, then sell the contract to somebody else. (This is called wholesaling.) You need to be intelligent, patient, and do a lot of research. I’m just giving the highlights here.

From “most common” to “least common” in terms of difficulty of pulling it off: Form multiple sources of income. Quora Partner Program and some other sites allow for this, although you did have to put in time to get started.Make investments up to the “match” in a company 401k, if you have it available.Form a business of some sort.Make HIGHLY AGGRESSIVE investments with some portion of your income. If you are not inheriting, I think this is your best shot. Sure, the low-cost index funds could get you to about a million on a lower salary, but I’d still not call socking it away for all those years, then having that later “wealth”. It is also NOT developing yourself, it is just “dumb money” so..Which brings up this: have a decent budget for developing yourself, knowledge, and skills.I guess I tend to think that the wealthy, the TRULY wealthy either 1.) Inherited and built from there or 2.) have some sort of business or HIGHLY AGGRESSIVE/unorthodox investing methods that gets them there. And I’m also the type of person to think that the “millionaire next door” people do not have true wealth, since they give up so much for MANY years just to hit the lowest level. I also tend to think the same of the FIRE people, like they stop developing themselves and living… I think to be truly wealthy, you figure out a lifestyle that works, then develop self to become so abundant as to get there, as opposed to slashing everything and never enjoying the moment. But I suppose to each his own. :D I also do not agree with the people on here that say to max index funds and stuff.. I think that is the recipe for upper middle class, but to each his own? ;)

The first 100 times I saw this question on Quora, I thought it was rather funny.   Then it became "wow, these people are serious."  And now is more like "what a dumbass..."   So allow me to express the collective frustration of all Quorans (if there is such term) here, at the nature of your question.   Dumbf**kAnd now the answer: There is no such thing as "get rich quick" in the sense of being generally available, legal or sustainable.  There are short-term opportunities in the sense of being at the right place at the right time, but these are pure luck and dry up quick.  Believe me, if you find yourself in one, you'll notice it. So posting a question on Quora like yours sounds like, "hey I am too lazy to get off my ass and do something with my life, so why don't I reach for the nearest keyboard and find out how to make money rain today."

There are two main ways to become rich. First of all, work to improve yourself. Figure out what you can do to be productive, and learn over time how to do this better. There are a two ways to get wealthy: 1.) Spend less 2.) Make more Spending less is hard, and actually has a finite end to it. You can’t spend less than $0! Making more is also hard, but the upside is unlimited! you could earn an extra $10 a month, or $100, or $1,000, or $10,000, or $1,000,000. Sure, earning a million dollars is EXTREMELY hard. But possible. If you want to get wealthy, I’d focus on finding ways you can earn more money. Likely, this involves leveraging a unique skill that you have.

Absolutely. By historical standards, the vast majority of people alive today are fabulously wealthy. This anecdote puts things in perspective for me. In 1924, less than a century ago, Calvin Coolidge’s son died from an infected blister on his toe. That was the son of a sitting US President, with access to the best health care available. Died from a blister. For all of human history, this was a normal way to die. Today, most of us have access to soap, clean water, cheap antibiotic ointments, and vaccines. The richest and most powerful people in the world couldn’t get that for love or money a century ago. Do you feel rich yet?

Pocket emptying mistakes you do, but RICH don’t DISCLAIMER: This is going to be very long as your financial life depends on it, so bear with me. So, How do RICH people become rich? Why INVESTING? Because here your money will work for you when you’re asleep. Now you’ve $60 and your monthly expenses are $80 that is a money deficit of $20, so what do you do? Here, the next thing comes up. Number 2: Making more MONEY People need to force themselves to do something and something that is HARD? Rare chances of doing it at all. Number 3: Protecting your MONEY You cannot be rich if all your money is taken by financial predators. Do taxes squeeze out all your money? No, Taxes are the expenses of living in a civilized society. Warren Buffet Banks – Interest from cardsBroker – Good broker makes you rich, bad ones? Makes excuses.Departmental Credit card – The worst credit card you can ever own.And a PROTIP, You cannot buy insurance when you need it, do it before. Number 4: Budgeting your MONEY. People say ‘Live below your means’. Is it that simple? If you want to be rich, you need to expand your means. Increase your INCOME, re-prioritize your SPENDING HABITS. Here, making more money will take care of your budget. All you need to do is keeping a check on your CASHFLOW. Cash that is flowing out from your POCKET. Number 5: Improving your Financial Information. You live in an information age. Use this opportunity not only for your entertainment but also for your knowledge. Classify INFORMATION before taking steps. Building your wealth isn’t such a daunting task if you take consistent small steps towards it on a daily basis. Here are a few things you can do: · Automate investments The first thing you can and must do is automate your investments. This will not just make it disciplined but also save you if you forget to do it in one month. · Avoid debts at all costs Debts are one of the biggest reasons for your wealth not building up. If you have debts/loans on you, consider repaying them on a priority basis. And while you do so, try not to default in your repayments as it will affect your credit score adversely. · Follow a strict budget A budget helps you know your income and expenditure. It also allows you to allocate adequate funds for expenses, savings and investments. Being aware of these can help you manage your funds better over a period of time. Have specific goals and tie your expenses and investments to them. This will also act as a plan and help you build your wealth faster and in an effective manner.

In my personal opinion, I think the way to becoming rich is through investing in the stock market. These concepts do not require you to formulate strategies for investing in specific stocks that are performing well. Basic knowledge of the stock market and a good broker to advise you is the way to start investing. Commodity trading has earned me a lot of profit but it does come with risks of its own. Share market is a pool of various methods to earn the most. I guess it depends on what suits you and at what kind of trading you are best. I have always preferred index funds for investment as they are tax efficient, passively managed with a broad diversification for investing your money. India has Nifty 50 and Sensex which has the best 50 and 30 companies respectively in the index that are performing well. There are other investment options as well that can give high profit, too.
